Title: The £1,000,000 Bank-Note
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A beared man in a suit, hat, and tie. Browsing clothing. Graphite filter.
Description: A man is given a bank note worth £1,000,000 as a bet to see whether it would be usable without arousing suspicion.
Blurb: ‘Give me the change, please.’

Title: The $25,000 Jaw
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A clenched fist. Graphite filter.
Description: Croly Addicks is chinless both metaphorically and literally. But things take a drastic turn when the insults and disrespect finally make him snap.
Blurb: “Aw, wadda yuh expeck of Chinless?” returned the brunette stenographer disdainfully as she crackled paper to conceal her breach of the office rules against conversation. “Feller with ingrown jaws was made to pick on.”

Title: 2BR02B
Author: Kurt Vonnegut
Img_description: A solitary,colourless rotary telephone resting on a stooll
Description: In a future where death has been solved, and the population of the United States is stabilised, a father waits nervously for his wife to give birth to triplets.
Blurb: The room was being redecorated. It was being redecorated as a memorial to a man who had volunteered to die.

Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A man in a tux, tipping his hat. Graphite Filter.
Description: The author looks forward to living in his forties.
Blurb: I only woke this morning - To find the world is fair - I’m going on for forty, - With scarcely one grey hair.

Title: About Barbers
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: Half of a stern, staring face. Graphite filter
Description: A man awkwardly does his best to avoid falling into the hands of the worst barber in the barbershop.
Blurb: About this time I was amusing myself trying to guess where he would be most likely to cut me this time, but he got ahead of me, and sliced me on the end of the chin before I had got my mind made up.

Title: About Love
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A man and woman kissing by a window, graphite filter.
Description: A man recounts his love for a woman married to a boring man, and how he had wondered what she, or any woman, found in such men.
Blurb: “There is a proverb that if a peasant woman has no troubles she will buy a pig. The Luganovitchs had no troubles, so they made friends with me.”

Title: According to Their Lights
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: Theatres at New York in 1900. Graphite Filter.
Description: Two men become friends after falling from grace in different ways. But they have differing opinions on what they would be willing to do to get back into society.
Blurb: “I’d marry the Empress of China for one bowl of chop suey. I’d commit murder for a plate of beef stew. I’d steal a wafer from a waif. I’d be a Mormon for a bowl of chowder.”

Title: Across the Straits
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A large steamboat on the sea, graphite filter.
Description: A pair set for New Zealand’s South Island to seek fortune, but start out with losing a half-sovereign.
Blurb: You would sooner know that you fooled your money away on a spree, and made yourself sick, than lost it out of an extra hole in your pocket, and kept well.

Title: An Adventure in Futurity
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A drawing of two men in futuristic gear overlooking an majestic, alien palace with a fight between aliens occurning in the courtyard.
Description: Hugh befriends a strange man named Elkins, whose nationality and race Hugh is unable to pin down. Elkins shows a mysteriously advanced understanding of modern science despite having no public fame or connections.
Blurb: “And do you ever think that present-day New York will some time be as fragmentary and fabulous as Troy or Zimbabwe? That archaeologists may delve in its ruins, beneath the sevenfold increment of later cities, and find a few rusting mechanisms of disputed use, and potteries of doubtful date—”

Title: The Adventure of Black Peter
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of three men looking through a window to see a man slumped over but standing up.
Description: The infamous retired sailor known as ‘Black Peter’ is found in his house speared to the wall by his own harpoon. Holmes is on the case.
Blurb: “This room is not well adapted for a cell, and Mr. Patrick Cairns occupies too large a proportion of our carpet.”

Title: The Adventure of Charles Augustus Milverton
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of a man in a robe and top hat stands in the shadows with his hands clasped.
Description: Sherlock Holmes must help the Lady Evan Brackwell, who has fallen prey to the infamous king of blackmail, Charles Augustus Milverton.
Blurb: “Heaven help the man, and still more the woman, whose secret and reputation come into the power of Milverton. With a smiling face and a heart of marble he will squeeze and squeeze until he has drained them dry.”

Title: The Adventure of Shoscombe Old Place
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of Holmes and a small black dog waiting behind a bush as a horse and carriage approaches.
Description: The trainer of a racing stable comes to Holmes claiming that his master has gone mad and disappears into a crypt every night to speak with a strange man.
Blurb: “He should have been a buck in the days of the Regency—a boxer, an athlete, a plunger on the turf, a lover of fair ladies, and, by all account, so far down Queer Street that he may never find his way back again.”

Title: The Adventure of the Abbey Grange
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Sir Eustace Brackwell, one of the richest men in Kent, is dead, Knocked with his own poker. The infamous Randall Gang is the main suspect.
Blurb: “Well, they did not take much—only half-a-dozen articles of plate off the sideboard. Lady Brackenstall thinks that they were themselves so disturbed by the death of Sir Eustace that they did not ransack the house as they would otherwise have done.”

Title: The Adventure of the Beryl Coronet
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of two men in suits (Holmes and Watson) console a man sitting down with his hand in his hair.
Description: Alexander Holder, the senior partner in the second largest private banking concern in the City of London, was entrusted with the priceless ‘Beryl Coronet’. Now he finds himself asking Holmes for help, after losing three of its beryl jewels to thievery from his own household.
Blurb: At my cry he dropped it from his grasp and turned as pale as death. I snatched it up and examined it. One of the gold corners, with three of the beryls in it, was missing.

Title: The Adventure of the Blue Carbuncle
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: The silly mystery of an abandoned felt hat and Christmas goose turns into an extravagant scandal when the precious ‘Blue Carbuncle’ is found in the stomach of the goose.
Blurb: “My name is Sherlock Holmes. It is my business to know what other people don’t know.”

Title: The Adventure of the Bruce-Partington Plans
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of four men in a room, one standing up holds a large stack of paper.
Description: A clerk is found dead with the plans for the British Navy’s revolutionary new submarine in his pocket.
Blurb: You must drop everything, Sherlock. Never mind your usual petty puzzles of the police-court. It’s a vital international problem that you have to solve. Why did Cadogan West take the papers, where are the missing ones, how did he die, how came his body where it was found, how can the evil be set right?

Title: The Adventure of the Cardboard Box
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of Holmes, Watson and anotehr man peering at a board as the third man arranges two small objects.
Description: Miss Susan Cushing receives a cardboard box with two severed human ears. Scotland Yard suspects a revenge prank from evicted tenants with access to human remains, but Holmes suspects a more sinister plot.
Blurb: “The presumption is strongly against it. Bodies in the dissecting-rooms are injected with preservative fluid. These ears bear no signs of this. They are fresh, too. They have been cut off with a blunt instrument, which would hardly happen if a student had done it.”

Title: The Adventure of the Copper Beeches
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of a lady talking to a sitting Holmes and Watson.
Description: Violet Hunter tells Holmes of her mysterious job offer, giving her a considerable salary with the peculiar caveat of needing her to cut her hair short.
Blurb: “To the man who loves art for its own sake, it is frequently in its least important and lowliest manifestations that the keenest pleasure is to be derived.”

Title: The Adventure of the Creeping Man
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of a woman in bed noticing a man staring through the window.
Description: A famous professor has begun to show extremely disturbing habits after a visit to Prague, including walking on all fours and appearing in places that should be inaccessible to a man of his age. His loyal dog has also begun attacking him.
Blurb: “A dog reflects the family life. Whoever saw a frisky dog in a gloomy family, or a sad dog in a happy one? Snarling people have snarling dogs, dangerous people have dangerous ones. And their passing moods may reflect the passing moods of others.”

Title: The Adventure of the Dancing Men
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Hilton Cubit asks Holmes to explain to him a mysterious set of pictograms that frightens his wife, who refuses to explain why.
Blurb: “What one man can invent another can discover,”

Title: The Adventure of the Devil’s Foot
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: One is dead and two have been rendered insane, and yet not even Holmes can find any evidence of poison or an intruder.
Blurb: To let the brain work without sufficient material is like racing an engine. It racks itself to pieces.

Title: The Adventure of the Dying Detective
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of Holmes, lying in bed, is reaching out towards Watson who his handling a small box.
Description: Upon learning of a bedridden Holmes, Watson finds him gaunt and flushed, claiming to have a disease both fatal and infectious.
Blurb: “For three days he has been sinking, and I doubt if he will last the day. He would not let me get a doctor. This morning when I saw his bones sticking out of his face and his great bright eyes looking at me I could stand no more of it.”

Title: The Adventure of the Empty House
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: With Holmes gone, Watson tries his hand at solving the tragedy of Ronald Adair. Adair has been found shot, but with no gun or trace of an intruder in the room in which he lay.
Blurb: It can be imagined that my close intimacy with Sherlock Holmes had interested me deeply in crime, and that after his disappearance I never failed to read with care the various problems which came before the public.

Title: The Adventure of the Engineer’s Thumb
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Mr. Victor Hatherley tells of how he was hired by a strange man to inspect a hydraulic press, eventually leading to his near death by crushing.
Blurb: Sherlock Holmes was, as I expected, lounging about his sittingroom in his dressing-gown, reading the agony column of The Times and smoking his before-breakfast pipe . . .

Title: The Adventure of the Golden Pince-Nez
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of a man (Holmes) grabbing the hand of a distressed woman in a room with three other people.
Description: A detective comes to Holmes with a case of a dead man, a small sealing-wax knife, and a pince-nez.
Blurb: “There can be no question that this was snatched from the face or the person of the assassin.”

Title: The Adventure of the Lion’s Mane
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Holmes and Stackhurst are walking along the beach when a third friend appears, staggering out from behind a cliff edge to drop dead at their feet.
Blurb: One glimmer of life came into his face for an instant, and he uttered two or three words with an eager air of warning. They were slurred and indistinct, but to my ear the last of them, which burst in a shriek from his lips, were “the Lion’s Mane.”

Title: The Adventure of the Mazarin Stone
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Holmes tells Watson of his plan to foil his would-be assassin using a wax model.
Blurb: “No violence, gentlemen—no violence, I beg of you! Consider the furniture!”

Title: The Adventure of the Missing Three-Quarter
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Overton comes to Holmes for help find his missing rugger teammate.
Blurb: “You must admit that it is curious and suggestive that this incident should occur on the eve of this important match, and should involve the only man whose presence seems essential to the success of the side. It may, of course, be coincidence, but it is interesting.”

Title: The Adventure of the Noble Bachelor
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Lord St. Simon comes to Holmes to ask him to find his missing bride.
Blurb: “Ah, Watson,” said Holmes, smiling, “perhaps you would not be very gracious either, if, after all the trouble of wooing and wedding, you found yourself deprived in an instant of wife and of fortune. I think that we may judge Lord St. Simon very mercifully and thank our stars that we are never likely to find ourselves in the same position.”

Title: The Adventure of the Norwood Builder
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: McFarlane comes to Holmes desperately claiming that despite having all the evidence pointing to him having murdered a man for his inheritance, he is innocent.
Blurb:
“Important fresh evidence to hand. McFarlane’s guilt definitely established. Advise you to abandon case.
 — Lestrade.”

Title: The Adventure of the Priory School
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: The ten-year-old son of one of the richest Dukes of England has disappeared, possibly having been abducted. The principal of his school begs for help from Sherlock Holmes.
Blurb: “Well, now, you do not mean to seriously suggest that this German rode off upon a bicycle in the dead of the night bearing the boy in his arms?”

Title: The Adventure of the Red Circle
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of Holmes with his smoking pipe stares at a sheet of paper in his hand.
Description: A man offers a woman double her lodging rate if she promises to never disturb him. But after his habits distress her too much, she pays a call to Holmes for help.
Blurb: “It was his particular direction that we should always, when he rang, leave his meal upon a chair, outside his door. Then he rings again when he has finished, and we take it down from the same chair. If he wants anything else he prints it on a slip of paper and leaves it.”

Title: The Adventure of the Retired Colourman
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A painter comes to Holmes asking for help finding his wife, who he believes ran off with his neighbour and all their money. Holmes, busy with another case, sends Watson to investigate.
Blurb: “He tore up one of his wife’s photographs in my presence—tore it up furiously in a tempest of passion. ‘I never wish to see her damned face again,’ he shrieked.”

Title: The Adventure of the Second Stain
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Two politicians come to Holmes desperate to regain a stolen document of drastic importance, else even war might be possible.
Blurb:
“You will not see him.”
“Why not?”
“He was murdered in his house last night.”

Title: The Adventure of the Six Napoleons
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Someone has been breaking into stores and breaking plaster busts of Napoleon and nothing more. The Police suspect lunacy, but Holmes has a different motive in mind.
Blurb: “This is certainly very novel.”

Title: The Adventure of the Solitary Cyclist
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Miss Violet Smith comes to Holmes concerning a strange cyclist who has been following her as she leaves her work every weekend.
Blurb: “It was a straight left against a slogging ruffian. I emerged as you see me. Mr. Woodley went home in a cart.”

Title: The Adventure of the Speckled Band
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of a woman with her hand on Sherlock Holmes in plea, nearby is Watson.
Description: A woman asks for help solving the death of her sister with the only clue being the sister’s screams of ‘the speckled band’.
Blurb: At first I thought that she had not recognised me, but as I bent over her she suddenly shrieked out in a voice which I shall never forget, “Oh, my God! Helen! It was the band! The speckled band!”

Title: The Adventure of the Sussex Vampire
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Sherlock Holmes investigates the claim of a blood-sucking woman in Sussex.
Blurb: Our client, Mr. Robert Ferguson, of Ferguson and Muirhead, tea brokers, of Mincing Lane, has made some inquiry from us in a communication of even date concerning vampires.

Title: The Adventure of the Three Gables
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A man comes to see Holmes and Watson, full of threats.
Blurb: I don’t think that any of my adventures with Mr. Sherlock Holmes opened quite so abruptly, or so dramatically, as that which I associate with The Three Gables.

Title: The Adventure of the Three Garridebs
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Two men with the same last name, ‘Garrideb’, claim to be looking for a third. Only then can they pass the test of a dead, eccentric millionaire and inherit his fortune three ways.
Blurb: “He had no kith nor kin—or, if he had, I never heard of it. But he took a kind of pride in the queerness of his name. That was what brought us together.”

Title: The Adventure of the Three Students
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A student has snuck into a university and copied the upcoming exam. Holmes has no time, for such trivial matters, but the quaint clues are enough to pique his attention and set the game afoot.
Blurb: On the table in the window were several shreds from a pencil which had been sharpened. A broken tip of lead was lying there also. Evidently the rascal had copied the paper in a great hurry, had broken his pencil, and had been compelled to put a fresh point to it.

Title: The Adventure of the Veiled Lodger
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A veiled woman with a mutilated face, agrees only to talk to Holmes about her horrid past.
Blurb: “Well, Mr. Holmes, you would hardly say it was a face at all. That’s how it looked. Our milkman got a glimpse of her once peeping out of the upper window, and he dropped his tin and the milk all over the front garden.”

Title: The Adventure of Wisteria Lodge
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A Mr. John Scott Eccles comes to seek Holmes’ advice only to be interrupted by police arriving to interrogate Eccles on a murder from the night before.
Blurb: My mind is like a racing engine, tearing itself to pieces because it is not connected up with the work for which it was built. Life is commonplace, the papers are sterile; audacity and romance seem to have passed forever from the criminal world.

Title: Aepyornis Island
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A wooden, five-masted sailing ship on the sea. Graphite filter. Graphite filter.
Description: A man with a scar across his face tells of how he discovered the famous, monstrous bird ‘Aepyornis.’
Blurb: “Hatched, sir, when my head was pillowed on it and I was asleep. I heard a whack and felt a jar and sat up, and there was the end of the egg pecked out and a rum little brown head looking out at me.”

Title: After the Race
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: Four clinking wine glasses. Graphite filter.
Description: After a successful car race in Dublin, the members of the team, most of different nationalities, set off for a celebratory dinner.
Blurb: In Jimmy’s house this dinner had been pronounced an occasion. A certain pride mingled with his parents’ trepidation, a certain eagerness, also, to play fast and loose for the names of great foreign cities have at least this virtue.

Title: The Alchemist
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A curved glass vial holding a misty gas. Graphite filter
Description: A man searches for answers to the mystery of a curse that has made all of his ancestors die young.
Blurb:
“May ne’er a noble of thy murd’rous line
Survive to reach a greater age than thine!”

Title: All Gold Canyon
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A foggy valley through cliffs. Graphite filter.
Description: In a pristine canyon of lillies, butterflies and deer, a prospector comes looking for gold. But luck turns out to be both with and against him.
Blurb: “Ah, ha! Mr. Pocket! I’m a-comin’, I’m a-comin’, an’ I’m shorely gwine to get yer! You heah me, Mr. Pocket? I’m gwine to get yer as shore as punkins ain’t cauliflowers!”

Title: The All Right ’Un
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: An envelope and letter. Graphite filter.
Description: After being given care by the narrator, a man writes him a letter saying he will repay his kindness by providing him a tipoff on a horse that will for sure win its next race.
Blurb:
He came from ‘further out’,
That land of heat and drought
And dust and gravel.
He got a touch of sun,
And rested at the run
Until his cure was done,
And he could travel.

Title: All Summer in a Day
Author: Ray Bradbury
Img_description: A sunrise above the horizon. Graphite Filter.
Description: Children wait by the windows of their school for a chance to see the Venutian sun.
Blurb: And they, they had been on Venus all their lives, and they had been only two years old when last the sun came out and had long since forgotten the color and heat of it and the way it really was. But Margot remembered.

Title: “allez!”
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A female acrobat inside a raised ring with a crowd watching. Graphite filter.
Description: A girl lives her youth in a circus as an acrobat, eventually falling in love with a clown who joins the show.
Blurb: The man in the tall hat walks in the centre of the ring, holding in front of the horse’s head the end of his long whip, which he cracks deafeningly.⁠ ⁠…“Allez!⁠ ⁠…”

Title: Alone
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A man with a billowing coat looks at a spectral-faced cloud.
Description: A man describes his life of isolation.
Blurb:
From the same source I have not taken
My sorrow—I could not awaken
My heart to joy at the same tone—
And all I lov’d—I lov’d alone—

Title: The Amateur Rider
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A striped jockey on a racehorse. Graphite filter.
Description: A horse manager is shocked at the appearance of a new jockey.
Blurb:
Ought to be under the Dog Act, he ought, and be kept off the course.
Fall! why, he’d fall off a cart, let alone off a steeplechase horse.

Title: Ambition and Art
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A hand delicately holding a small paintbrush. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on the difference between a life of ambition and a life of art.
Blurb: There has been reward — but the end of all -Is dust and ashes.

Title: Anathema
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: The domes of an orthodox church. Graphite filter.
Description: A deacon refuses to denounce a favourite author of his during a rite of anathematization.
Blurb: But something peculiar happened to the archdeacon that morning, something that had never happened before. Perhaps it was the whiskey that his wife gave him with his tea.

Title: And All the Earth a Grave
Author: C. C. MacApp
Img_description: A wooden coffin with a cross. Graphite filter
Description: A coffin factory accidentally overbudgets the marketing team a hundred fold... leading to complete success.
Blurb: The coffin became the new status symbol.

Title: —And Devious the Line of Duty
Author: Tom Godwin
Img_description: Drawing of a man looking at another who is smugly sipping on a drink.
Description: A young lieutenant is willing to die in the line of duty to save Earth and her people, but instead he is tasked with the much stranger mission of breaking up a marriage.
Blurb: “You are thinking, of course, of dying dramatically behind a pair of blazing blasters. But you will soon learn, my boy, that a soldier’s duty is to protect the worlds he represents by whatever actions will produce the best results, no matter how unheroic those actions may be.”

Title: Annabel Lee
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A kissing man and woman, silhouetted in a forest. Graphite filter.
Description: A man pines for a lover from his youth.
Blurb:
And this was the reason that, long ago,
In this kingdom by the sea,
A wind blew out of a cloud, chilling
My beautiful Annabel Lee;

Title: The Ant
Author: Aesop
Img_description: Ants climbing a tree branch. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on the origin of the ant.
Blurb: Ants were once men and made their living by tilling the soil. But, not content with the results of their own work, they were always casting longing eyes upon the crops and fruits of their neighbours, ...

Title: The Apple
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A twisting tree. Graphite filter.
Description: A stranger foists an apple onto Mr Hinchcliff, before telling the story of how he came by it and why he wants it gone.
Blurb: “It never fades. I have had it now for three months. And it is ever bright and smooth and ripe and desirable, as you see it.”

Title: Araby
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: A 20th century city with trams and horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: A young boy is obsessed with his friend’s sister and follows her around with little confidence in speaking to her. When she expresses disappointment at not being free to go to the ‘Araby’ bazaar, the boy promises to go himself and buy her something.
Blurb: At night in my bedroom and by day in the classroom her image came between me and the page I strove to read. The syllables of the word Araby were called to me through the silence in which my soul luxuriated and cast an Eastern enchantment over me.

Title: The Argonauts of the Air
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A propellor plane flying away from an explosion. Graphite filter.
Description: The duo of inventors, Monson and Woodhouse strive to create the first flying machine while the London public laughs at their failed attempts.
Blurb: “I have been talking to Mr. Monson, and he can think of nothing, positively nothing, but that flying-machine of his. Do you know, all his workmen call that place of his ‘Monson’s Folly’?”

Title: The Army Ensign
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A letter and envelope stamped with a wax seal. Graphite filter.
Description: A man finds and reads the diary of an army ensign
Blurb: I was waiting for her and we went along the thick alley, that very same alley where I saw for the first time my incomparable Kate, the queen of my heart.

Title: Asaph
Author: Frank Stockton
Img_description: A man in a suit, hat and with a cane. Graphite filter.
Description: Being a man known for using his head rather than his hands, Asaph plans to help his friend court his sister in exchange for a nice suit and several smaller amenities.
Blurb: “I never before saw a man that would sell his sister for a dictionary!”

Title: Asleep in Armageddon
Author: Ray Bradbury
Img_description: A misty planet.
Description: Leonard Sale crash lands on a planet and has six days to spare before rescue with plenty of food and water as well as a conveniently breathable atmosphere. But his luck turns when he tries to fall asleep and begins to hear voices.
Blurb: No record of insanity in the family for two hundred years. All healthy, well-balanced. No reason for insanity now. Shock? Silly. No shock. I’m to be rescued in six days. No shock to that.

Title: The Ass and the Mule
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A donkey. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on teamwork.
Blurb: A certain man who had an Ass and a Mule loaded them both up one day and set out upon a journey. So long as the road was fairly level, the Ass got on very well: but by and by they came to a place among...

Title: The Assignation
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: Brick walls and a bridge over a canal. Graphite filter.
Description: A man is travelling through Venice on a gondola when a baby falls from a bridge and into the canal.
Blurb: A figure muffled in a cloak, stepped out within reach of the light, and, pausing a moment upon the verge of the giddy descent, plunged headlong into the canal.

Title: An Astrologer’s Song
Author: Rudyard Kipling
Img_description: A shining star. Graphite filter.
Description: A song on the guidance of stars.
Blurb: While the Stars in their courses. Do fight on our side?

Title: Autumn Flowers
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: Small blossoming flowers in the ground (Autumn Crocus). Graphite filter.
Description: In a letter to her lover, a woman writes of why she has run away.
Blurb: That is why, when I have finished this letter (if I can only manage to finish it) I shall give it to a porter and tell him to post it at the very moment when the train starts. And I shall watch him from the window and feel, as if I were actually saying goodbye to you, that painful oppression of the heart.

Title: Azathoth
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A spired building. Graphite filter
Description: (Unfinished) - An unnamed man lives in a world stripped of wonder.
Blurb: It is enough to know that he dwelt in a city of high walls where sterile twilight reigned, and that he toiled all day among shadow and turmoil, coming home at evening to a room whose one window opened not on the fields and groves but on a dim court where other windows stared in dull despair.

Title: B24
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A dusty, barred prison window. Graphite filter.
Description: A convicted man writes to an attorney explaining how he was framed for a murder.
Blurb: May no night pass that you are not haunted by the thought of the man who rots in gaol because you have not done the duty which you are paid to do!

Title: The Babes In The Wood
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A winding tree. Graphite filter.
Description: A dying mother and father entrust their children to their uncle. But the uncle, wanting the inheritance for himself, hires ruffians to do away with the children.
Blurb:
“And if you keep them carefully,
Then God will you reward;
But if you otherwise should deal,
God will your deeds regard.”

Title: The Bat, the Bramble, and the Seagull
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A flying bat. Graphite filter.
Description: A small origin fable.
Blurb: A Bat, a Bramble, and a Seagull went into partnership and determined to go on a trading voyage together. The Bat borrowed a sum of money for his venture; the Bramble laid in a stock of clothes of vari...

Title: The Battle of Washington Square
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A U.S. flag flying on a flagpole. Graphite filter.
Description: A young, vagrant man is drafted and finds that everyone begins to treat him with much more respect, causing him to yearn to be sent to combat and prove himself.
Blurb: In his dreams he, single-handed, held the breach against a prodigious number of the enemy. They charged upon him, but he, though bleeding from a dozen wounds, did not retreat. He held them back; with rifle, bombs, bayonet, even fists, he hurled them back until he was ringed round by piles of the slain.

Title: The Bear and the Travellers
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A roaring bear. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on selfishness.
Blurb: Two Travellers were on the road together, when a Bear suddenly appeared on the scene. Before he observed them, one made for a tree at the side of the road, and climbed up into the branches and hid the...

Title: The Beast in the Cave
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A cave with a stream of sunlight falling in. Graphite filter
Description: A man veers off from a caving expedition and loses his way. Then he hears the patting of feet heading towards him.
Blurb: These impacts were soft, and stealthy, as of the paws of some feline. Besides, when I listened carefully, I seemed to trace the falls of four instead of two feet.

Title: The Beautiful Suit
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A pond full of duckweed. Graphite filter.
Description: A man is given a suit by his mother but never wears it.
Blurb: One night, when he was dreaming of it after his habit, he dreamt he took the tissue paper from one of the buttons, and found its brightness a little faded, and that distressed him mightily in his dream.

Title: The Bee and Jupiter
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A bee on its side. Graphite filter.
Description: A small origin fable for bees.
Blurb: A Queen Bee from Hymettus flew up to Olympus with some fresh honey from the hive as a present to Jupiter, who was so pleased with the gift that he promised to give her anything she liked to ask for. S...

Title: Been There Before
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A hand throwing a jagged black rock near water. Graphite filter.
Description: A man accepts a bet that he couldn’t throw a stone over the length of the nearby river, only to find that there aren’t any stones within miles of the small town.
Blurb:
There came a stranger to Walgett town,
To Walgett town when the sun was low,
And he carried a thirst that was worth a crown,
Yet how to quench it he did not know.

Title: The Beetle Hunter
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: The eye of an angry, staring man. Graphite filter.
Description: A medical man with a passion for beetle collecting finds an ad in the paper perfectly suited for his abilities. But upon meeting the advertisers they give no clues as to why they need a man with such a specific set of skills.
Blurb: “I wish you to come for a short journey with me, to remain always at my side, and to promise to do 25without question whatever I may ask you, however unreasonable it may appear to you to be.”

Title: The Belly and the Members
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A chunk of bread and a goblet of wine. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on teamwork.
Blurb: The Members of the Body once rebelled against the Belly. “You,” they said to the Belly, “live in luxury and sloth, and never do a stroke of work; while we not only have to do all the hard work there i...

Title: Berenice
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A woman clutching her face. Graphite filter.
Description: A man struggles gloommily in life, while his cousin roams through it carelessly, until one day she is struck down by illness.
Blurb: Disease—a fatal disease, fell like the simoon upon her frame; and, even while I gazed upon her, the spirit of change swept over her, pervading her mind, her habits, and her character, and, in a manner the most subtle and terrible, disturbing even the identity of her person!

Title: The Bet
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: Several wine glasses being clinked together. Graphite filter.
Description: A young lawyer bets an older banker that he could voluntarily last in solitary confinement for fifteen years. The banker agrees to the bet, saying he won’t last more than three or four years.
Blurb: “Capital punishment kills a man at once, but lifelong imprisonment kills him slowly. Which executioner is the more humane, he who kills you in a few minutes or he who drags the life out of you in the course of many years?”

Title: Between the Dusk of a Summer Night
Author: William Ernest Henley
Img_description: A sillhouette of an embracing man and woman in a forest. Graphite filter
Description: A short love poem.
Blurb: O, it’s die we must, but it’s live we can.

Title: Beware of the Dog
Author: Roald Dahl
Img_description: A small propellor plane flying away from an explosion. Graphite filter.
Description: A British WWII pilot bails from his plane somewhere near the English Channel, then wakes up in a hospital with a caring nurse and doctor who seem very interested in his squadron.
Blurb: Then I shall say, someone help me to get out. I can’t do it alone because I’ve lost one of my legs. They’ll all laugh and think that I’m joking, and I shall say, all right, come and have a look, you unbelieving bastards.

Title: Beyond Lies The Wub
Author: Phillip K. Dick
Img_description: In a spaceship, three people stare at a slimy, pig-like being drinking water from a bowl on the floor.
Description: A space team purchase a large pig-like alien to eat on their long journey. But the beast turns out to me more than pig-like.
Blurb: “But how can any lasting contact be established between your people and mine if you resort to such barbaric attitudes? Eat me? Rather you should discuss questions with me, philosophy, the arts—”

Title: Beyond the Wall
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A spired building. Graphite Filter.
Description: Mohun Dampier tells of a young woman so beautiful he could never speak to her.
Blurb: I heard a gentle tapping, which appeared to come from the wall behind my chair. The sound was such as might have been made by a human hand, not as upon a door by one asking admittance, but rather, I thought, as an agreed signal, an assurance of someone’s presence in an adjoining room.

Title: Beyond the Wall of Sleep
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A tense, staring eye of a man's face. Graphite filter
Description: A man arrives at a mental asylum, struggling to return his thoughts and attention to the real world whenever he wakes from his vivid dreams.
Blurb: “We are all roamers of vast spaces and travelers in many ages.”

Title: The Big Trip Up Yonder
Author: Kurt Vonnegut
Img_description: A pen writing on lined paper. Graphite filter.
Description: In the year 2185, when people no longer age, several generations of the one family live together in an ever increasingly packed house waiting for gramps to cark it and hand over a large inheritance.
Blurb: This day, Lou would be disinherited for the eleventh time, and it would take him perhaps six months of impeccable behavior to regain the promise of a share in the estate.

Title: Big Two-Hearted River
Author: Ernest Hemmingway
Img_description: Half a dozen swimming trout. Graphite filter.
Description: A man returns to a town, now burnt to the ground. He wanders around looking at the destroyed buildings and the soot-covered animals.
Blurb: “Go on, hopper,” Nick said, speaking out loud for the first time “Fly away somewhere.”

Title: Bill, the Ventriloquial Rooster
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: An angry looking rooster. graphite filter.
Description: A family discover their rooster has the uncanny ability to throw his crow.
Blurb: “Then we remembered that there wasn’t another rooster within five miles —our only neighbour, an Irishman named Page, didn’t have one at the time— and we’d often heard another cock crow, but didn’t think to take any notice of it.”

Title: The Birds
Author: Daphne du Maurier
Img_description: Four birds flying far away in the sky. Graphite Filter..
Description: Nat Hocken opens his door to a tapping sound and is attacked by a manic bird. Strange as the incident is, things only escalate from there.
Blurb: His hammering helped to deafen the sound of the birds, the shuffling, the tapping, and more ominous—he did not want his wife or the children to hear it—the splinter of cracked glass.

Title: The Birds, the Beasts, and the Bat
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A standing swallow. Graphite filter.
Description: A simple fable on loyalty and forthrightness.
Blurb: The Birds were at war with the Beasts, and many battles were fought with varying success on either side. The Bat did not throw in his lot definitely with either party, but when things went well for th...

Title: The Birthmark
Author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
Img_description: A box of surgical instruments. Graphite filter.
Description: A man of science marries a beautiful woman, but he becomes obsessed over a birthmark on her face which he sees as a blemish on what could be perfect.
Blurb: His love for his young wife might prove the stronger of the two; but it could only be by intertwining itself with his love of science, and uniting the strength of the latter to his own.

Title: A Black Affair
Author: W. W. Jacobs
Img_description: A drawing of a man on a sailing ship reeling in fear at a black cat walking by him.
Description: After a ship crew’s favourite cat is under threat of being thrown overboard by the skipper, the cook hatches a plan.
Blurb: ‘You might be old Satan’s brother by the look of you; an’ if the cap’n wants to kill a cat, let it be you.’

Title: The Black Bull Of Norroway
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A shaggy bull. Graphite filter.
Description: A humble young girl claims she would be happy to marry even the ‘Black Bull of Norroway’. Soon after a bull turns up at her house asking for her hand.
Blurb: But the third, the prettiest and the merriest, tossed her head and said, with a twinkle in her eye, “Why so proud? As for me I would be content with the Black Bull of Norroway.”

Title: The Black Cat
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A cat's eyes in the darkness. Graphite filter.
Description: A man suspects his wife’s adopted, black cat to be the source of all his almost paranormal bad luck.
Blurb: In speaking of his intelligence, my wife, who at heart was not a little tinctured with superstition, made frequent allusion to the ancient popular notion, which regarded all black cats as witches in disguise.

Title: Black Fog
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A 20th century city with trams and horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: A rambunctious Ukrainian barges back into his city friend’s life, determined to ‘Conquer Petersburg.’
Blurb: “Listen, you poor, benighted provincial”⁠—I was trying to make him feel ashamed⁠—“here in Petersburg no one gets up before eleven. Lie down on the sofa or ask for some tea.”

Title: Black Joe
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: The silhouttes of two boys jumping on a hill at dusk.
Description: The narrator recounts the story of his childhoold friend.
Blurb: “He gave me a very interesting account of an interview between his father and Queen Victoria, and mentioned casually that his father had walked across the Thames without getting wet.”

Title: The Black Monk
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: The angry eye of a staring man. Graphite Filter
Description: A stressed out, overworked man retreats to the country for a break. There he meets a mysterious monk, who tells the man of his great purpose.
Blurb: I exist in your imagination, and your imagination is part of nature, so I exist in nature.

Title: Black Swans
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A black swan with three signets. Graphite Filter.
Description: A poem on freedom and nostalgia.
Blurb: Oh! ye wild black swans, ’twere a world of wonder - For a while to join in your westward flight.

Title: The Black Veil
Author: Charles Dickens
Img_description: An expressionless woman clutching her face
Description: A distressed woman in a black veil begs a surgeon to come to her house and help someone near death.
Blurb: There was a desperate earnestness in this woman’s manner, that went to the young man’s heart. He was young in his profession, and had not yet witnessed enough of the miseries which are daily presented before the eyes of its members, to have grown comparatively callous to human suffering.

Title: A Blackjack Bargainer
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: Playing cards splayed out over a table. Graphite filter.
Description: Yancey Goree has lost everything to gambling, including his house.
Blurb: The most disreputable thing in Yancey Goree’s law office was Goree himself, sprawled in his creaky old arm-chair.

Title: The Blanched Soldier
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Mr. James M. Dodd comes to Holmes asking for helping regarding his missing friend from the Boer war. The friend’s family claim that their son isn’t missing and is merely on a long voyage, but Dodd insists something is suspicious.
Blurb: When you have eliminated all which is impossible, then whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.

Title: The Blind Man
Author: Kate Chopin
Img_description: A row of pencils of different lengths. Graphite Filter
Description: A blind man walks the street trying to sell pencils.
Blurb: Then something happened—something horrible happened that made the women faint and the strongest men who saw it grow sick and dizzy. The motorman’s lips were as gray as his face, and that was ashen gray; and he shook and staggered from the superhuman effort he had put forth to stop his car.

Title: The Blood of the Martyrs
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: Rusty, worn prison bars viewed from inside.
Description: Professor Malzius, imprisoned by the new national regime, is given the chance to return to his research and experiments at his old university. He must, however, follow all the new rules.
Blurb: Well, it was his own fault. He could have accepted the new regime; some respectable people had done that. He could have fled the country; many honorable people had. A scientist should be concerned with the eternal, not with transient political phenomena; and a scientist should be able to live anywhere.

Title: Blossom and Fruit
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: A kissing man and woman, silhouetted in a forest. Graphite filter. Graphite filter.
Description: An old man thinks back on his past and wonders if he ever figured out what love was.
Blurb: Yes, he thought, that is how most people live their actual lives—skimming it through, in a hurry to get to the end and find out who got married and who got rich.

Title: The Blue Cross
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: A man and priest sit on a bench in front of a bush while two men, one wearing an English style Police helmet look on. Black and white drawing.
Description: Parisian detective Valentin lands in London to track down the international criminal  Flambeau. But with no reasonable clues to follow, he must follow the mystery of a sugar-cellar full of salt.
Blurb: “But what else can we do? Don’t you see we must either follow one wild possibility or else go home to bed?”

Title: The Blue Hotel
Author: Stephen Crane
Img_description: A fist in punching motion. Graphite Filter.
Description: Scully the hotel proprietor wrangles three men at the train station into staying at his hotel. But once in the hotel one of the men spontaneously starts accusing the others of intending to murder him.
Blurb: “Yes, fight! I’ll show you what kind of a man I am! I’ll show you who you want to fight! Maybe you think I can’t fight! Maybe you think I can’t! I’ll show you, you skin, you card-sharp! Yes, you cheated! You cheated! You cheated!”

Title: The Boar-Pig
Author: Saki
Img_description: A pig with its snout along the ground, graphite filter.
Description: Mrs. Philidore Stossen and her daughter attempt to sneak into a garden party only to run into the precocious young Matilda and her pet boar.
Blurb: “A pig is masculine as long as you call it a pig, but if you lose your temper with it and call it a ferocious beast it becomes one of us at once. French is a dreadfully unsexing language.”

Title: The Boarded Window
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: An expressionless woman clutching her face. Graphite Filter.
Description: The story of the past of a dead man comes to light perhaps as an explanation for his sudden death.
Blurb: The man’s name was said to be Murlock. He was apparently seventy years old, actually about fifty. Something besides years had had a hand in his aging.

Title: The Boarding House
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: A 20th century city with trams and horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: Mrs. Mooney hopes that the esteemed Mr. Doran will marry her daughter, but Mr. Doran is having doubts.
Blurb: Young men like to feel that there is a young woman not very far away.

Title: The Body Snatcher
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson
Img_description: Drawing of two men shocked as they shine a light on and remove a blanket off of a body.
Description: Fettes, an old drunk tells of how he used to be the assistant to a famous anatomist. In charge of acquiring corpses for all the students, he begins to notice odd details such as the freshness of the corpses and the hush-hush nature of the men who bring them.
Blurb: ‘I know her, I tell you,’ he continued. ‘She was alive and hearty yesterday. It’s impossible she can be dead; it’s impossible you should have got this body fairly.’

Title: The Bogey-Beast
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: The face of an old woman with wrinkles. Graphite filter.
Description: A content, elderly woman finds a pot of gold in the woods. But it’s not as it seems.
Blurb: Now one summer evening, as she was trotting, full of smiles as ever, along the high road to her hovel, what should she see but a big black pot lying in the ditch!

Title: The Book
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A splayed open book. Graphite filter
Description: (Unfinished) - A mysterious book sends the reader on a psychedelic journey.
Blurb: While I know I am speaking, I have a vague impression that some strange and perhaps terrible mediation will be needed to bear what I say to the points where I wish to be heard.

Title: The Bookshop
Author: Aldous Huxley
Img_description: A wall of books extending into the distance. Graphite Filter.
Description: A man spots a quaint bookshop that seems out of place amongst the cheap and convenient shops nearby in and out of which people rush.
Blurb: “It is our cheap press. The ephemeral overwhelms the permanent, the classical.”

Title: Borderland
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A lone kangaroo in a plain. Graphite filter.
Description: A lambasting of life in the Australian bush and the poets that fantasise it.
Blurb: Dreary land in rainy weather, with the endless clouds that drift — O’er the bushman like a blanket that the Lord will never lift.

Title: The Boscombe Valley Mystery
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Charles McCarthy is found dead by Boscombe Pool just after being seen having an argument with his son James. James however insists that he is innocent.
Blurb: “There is nothing more deceptive than an obvious fact.”

Title: The Boss of the ‘Admiral Lynch’
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A four masted ship. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator tells of a supporter of an ousted Chilean President who refused to surrender.
Blurb: And the king of ’em all, I reckon, the man that could stand a pinch - Was the boss of a one-horse gunboat.  They called her the ’Admiral Lynch’.

Title: The Boston Massacre
Author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
Img_description: A cocked, smoking, shiny rifle. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells of the escalation of conflict between the British soldiers and the Boston people that led to the Boston massacre.
Blurb: He immediately ordered eight soldiers of the main guard to take their muskets and follow him. They marched across the street, forcing their way roughly through the crowd, and pricking the town’s-people with their bayonets.

Title: The Bottle Imp
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson
Img_description: A picturesque town on a coast. Graphite filter.
Description: A man is offered a strange glass bottle by a man who insists it is responsible for all of his wealth.
Blurb: Napoleon had this bottle, and by it he grew to be the king of the world; but he sold it at the last, and fell.

Title: A Bottomless Grave
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A bundle of straw. Graphite filter.
Description: After a father dies, not because he was poisoned by the mother, a family buries him in the garden, not because anything suspicious happened...
Blurb: When I was nineteen years of age my father had the misfortune to die. He had always had perfect health, and his death, which occurred at the dinner table without a moment’s warning, surprised no one more than himself.

Title: Boule de Suif
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A stagecoach wheel, graphite filter.
Description: Ten people from the Prussian-occupied town of Rouen take the chance to escape on a stagecoach on the pretence of commerce, truly planning to never return.
Blurb: “My house was well stocked with provisions, and it seemed better to put up with feeding a few soldiers than to banish myself goodness knows where. But when I saw these Prussians it was too much for me!”

Title: The Bowmen
Author: Arthur Machen
Img_description: an archer stretching a bow on a hill. Graphite filter.
Description: In a battle against the Germans, the English receive help from an unexpected ally.
Blurb: They were like men who drew the bow, and with another shout their cloud of arrows flew singing and tingling through the air towards the German hosts.

Title: The Boy and the Filberts
Author: Aesop
Img_description: Many hazelnuts. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on restraint.
Blurb: A Boy put his hand into a jar of Filberts, and grasped as many as his fist could possibly hold. But when he tried to pull it out again, he found he couldn’t do so, for the neck of the jar was too smal...

Title: The Brazilian Cat
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of a man in a suit rushes into a cage as a large panther outside lunges towards him.
Description: The indebted Marshall King counts his lucky stars when his wealthy cousin Everard invites him to stay at his magnificent Greylands Court, home to a menagerie of animals taken from exploits in Brazil. Everard’s wife, however, clearly wants King gone at once.
Blurb: In the centre of this room, lying in the middle of a golden patch of sunlight, there was stretched a huge creature, as large as a tiger, but as black and sleek as ebony.

Title: The Brogue
Author: Saki
Img_description: A rearing, bridled, dark horse.
Description: The Mullet family try and try to foist off their nightmarishly untamed hunting horse to no avail. Eventually Toby Mullet fools the young bachelor Mr. Penricarde to buy the horse only to regret dooming him to an almost certain fatal fall when he engages a daughter of the Mullet family.
Blurb: “Write ‘Votes for Women’ on the stable door, and the thing would pass for a Suffragette outrage.”

Title: A Bunch of Roses
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A hand delicately holding a white rose. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on grief.
Blurb: Only her memory lives to-night.

Title: The Burden Of Itys
Author: Oscar Wilde
Img_description: A swan with three signets. Graphite Filter.
Description: A poem on the beauty of the Thames river.
Blurb:
When early on some sapphire Easter morn
In a high litter red as blood or sin the Pope is borne.

Title: A Burlesque Biography
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A large sailing ship on the waters. Graphite filter.
Description: The author resentfully capitulates to demands for an autobiography, writing of a lineage of ancestors who get arrested for forgery or thrown off of Columbus’s ship to America.
Blurb: Augustus Twain seems to have made something of a stir about the year 1160. He was as full of fun as he could be, and used to take his old saber and sharpen it up, and get in a convenient place on a dark night, and stick it through people as they went by, to see them jump.

Title: A Bush Christening
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A splash of water in the air. Graphite filter.
Description: After mistakenly thinking he’s about to be branded, a boy runs away from his christening.
Blurb: On the outer Barcoo where the churches are few, And men of religion are scanty, On a road never cross’d ’cept by folk that are lost, One Michael Magee had a shanty.

Title: A Bushman’s Song
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A man travels around unable to find a stable and worthwhile job.
Blurb:
I’m travellin’ down the Castlereagh, and I’m a station hand,
I’m handy with the ropin’ pole, I’m handy with the brand,
And I can ride a rowdy colt, or swing the axe all day,
But there’s no demand for a station-hand along the Castlereagh.

Title: The Butterfly that Stamped
Author: Rudyard Kipling
Img_description: A butterfly perched on a flower. Graphite Filter.
Description: The great king Suleiman-bin-Daoud suffers the complaints of his 999 wives, but is too humble to do anything about it.
Blurb: “Don’t you know that if I stamped with my foot all Suleiman-bin-Daoud’s Palace and this garden here would immediately vanish in a clap of thunder.”

Title: By the Waters of Babylon
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: A man in ragged clothing and with a bow walks through a ruined metal city full of stray cats.
Description: It is forbidden to go East, to the place of the Gods. But a son of a priest has a dream that he shall go there. And go there he does.
Blurb: It is forbidden to travel east. It is forbidden to cross the river. It is forbidden to go to the Place of the Gods. All these things are forbidden.

Title: Cain
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: An old man with long hair and beard. Graphite filter.
Description: A Russian captain of a punitive expedition is visited in the night by a man he has sentenced to death without cause.
Blurb: What would you answer, not to a judge or to the authorities, or even to the emperor, but to your own conscience, should it ask you, ‘Why did you enter upon this terrible, unjust slaughter?’

Title: The Call of Cthulhu
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Etching of a tentacle faced, winged beast bursting out of the ocean.
Description: A man inherits a manuscript from his uncle, describing cases of insanity and mania sprouting at the same time every year around the globe, along with dreams of a titanic, petrifying ‘Thing’.
Blurb: We live on a placid island of ignorance in the midst of black seas of infinity, and it was not meant that we should voyage far.

Title: Caporushes
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A woman with curly locks in a ball gown by a castle. Graphite filter.
Description: After being kicked out of her home, a young girl makes a cap for herself out of rushes so that she does not attract any attention for having fine clothes.
Blurb: When her task was finished she put on her robe of rushes and it hid all her fine clothes, and she put on the cap and it hid all her beautiful hair, so that she looked quite a common country girl.

Title: Captain Rogers
Author: W. W. Jacobs
Img_description: An old, bearded man. Graphite filter.
Description: A man barges into an inn, demanding the innkeeper treat him like a king or else a certain, dastardly past might come to surface.
Blurb: For fifteen years I have lived a decent, honest life. Pray God for your own sinful soul, that the devil in me does not wake again.

Title: A Case of Eavesdropping
Author: Algernon Blackwood
Img_description: A large, ornate bed beneath two glass windows. Graphite filter.
Description: Shorthouse takes up residence in a room as he tries to get his life together, but the neighbours argue at night and he can never catch them and tell them off.
Blurb: “You know she will give you anything. You have only been married a few months. If you ask and give a plausible reason you can get all we want and more.”

Title: A Case of Identity
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A woman comes to Holmes asking for him to find her husband who left her at the altar.
Blurb: “My dear fellow,” said Sherlock Holmes as we sat on either side of the fire in his lodgings at Baker Street, “life is infinitely stranger than anything which the mind of man could invent.

Title: The Case of Lady Sannox
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: Drawing of two men in suits looking at a bed with an arm falling off the side.
Description: The ambitious surgeon Douglas Stone and the brilliant Lady Sannox care little for hiding their affair from the public and the vapid Lord Sannox.
Blurb: But he had promised Lady Sannox to see her that evening and it was already half-past eight. His hand was outstretched to the bell to order the carriage when he heard the dull thud of the knocker. An instant later there was the shuffling of feet in the hall, and the sharp closing of a door.

Title: The Cask of Amontillado
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A brick wall. Graphite filter.
Description: A scorned man invites his rival to down into a cellar to ‘verify that his expensive cask of Amontillado is legitimate.’
Blurb: The thousand injuries of Fortunato I had borne as I best could, but when he ventured upon insult I vowed revenge.

Title: The Cat
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A stern looking cat sitting down outside. Graphite Filter.
Description: The author describes the character of the cat.
Blurb: But watch him as the shades of evening fall, and you see the cat as he really is.

Title: A Catastrophe
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Rusty coins in the palms of someones hands. Graphite filter.
Description: Winslow owns a small shop. He isn’t selling well, and has an outstanding debt to a wholesaler.
Blurb: Winslow was always more or less excited by a customer.

Title: The Cats of Ulthar
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A house cat sitting outside. Graphite filter
Description: The narrator explains how in Ulthar the law against killing cats arose not out of sympathy, but out of fear.
Blurb: It was fully a week before the villagers noticed that no lights were appearing at dusk in the windows of the cottage under the trees.

Title: The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A frog with a blank stare. Graphite filter.
Description: Simon Wheeler tells a tale to the narrator of a man who tamed a frog to jump higher than any other. Wheeler gives no indication that he believes the story to be funny or false despite the wacky plot.
Blurb: He ketched a frog one day, and took him home, and said he cal’klated to edercate him; and so he never done nothing for three months but set in his back yard and learn that frog to jump.

Title: Celephaïs
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A lance-wielding man on an armoured horse. Graphite filter
Description: A man dreams of a majestic city above the sea full of glorious knights, rivers and ships. Desperate to return he drugs himself to sleep over and over.
Blurb: For when as children we listen and dream, we think but half-formed thoughts, and when as men we try to remember, we are dulled and prosaic with the poison of life.

Title: A Certain Lady
Author: Dorothy Parker
Img_description: A young woman with braided hair. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on fickle love.
Blurb:
And all the straining things within my heart 
You'll never know.

Title: The Chain of Aforgomon
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A drawing of a shirtless man with his palm raised to the sky next to a robed man in a garden.
Description: After his death, all memory and evidence of John Milwarp seems to be fading from the world, a diary of his experiments with strange drugs may be the only explanation of the queer phenomenon.
Blurb: Sometimes I almost doubt that he ever existed. It is as if the man, and all that pertains to him, were being erased from human record by some mysterious acceleration of the common process of obliteration.

Title: The Chamber of Life
Author: G. Peyton Wertenbaker
Img_description: Etching of a man looking up a hill at a tall tower with a large globe in the distance.
Description: A man wakes up halfway through drowning in a lake. After clambering up the bank, he starts to piece together a strange series of memories of experimental technologies and a strange world full of beautiful nature and even more beautiful people.
Blurb: “A picture with sound and color, reproducing faithfully the ordinary life about us, its tints and voices, even the noises of the city—or traffic passing in the street and newsboys crying the scores of the afternoon games—vividly and naturally.”

Title: A Chameleon
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A public crowd listens to large policeman with a dark trenchcoat. Hand Drawn.
Description: A policeman tries to find and punish the owner of an unclaimed dog which has bitten a man walking on the street.
Blurb: “So you bite, you damned brute?” Otchumyelov hears suddenly. “Lads, don’t let him go! Biting is prohibited nowadays! Hold him! ah . . . ah!”

Title: A Charm
Author: Rudyard Kipling
Img_description: A bush of lilacs. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on remembrance.
Blurb: Not the great nor well bespoke; But the mere uncounted folk.

Title: A Child’s Dream of a Star
Author: Charles Dickens
Img_description: A shining star. Graphite filter.
Description: A little boy’s sister dies, but he sees her in his dreams.
Blurb: Now, these rays were so bright, and they seemed to make such a shining way from earth to heaven, that when the child went to his solitary bed, he dreamed about the star; and dreamed that, lying where he was, he saw a train of people taken up that sparkling road by angels.

Title: The Child’s Story
Author: Charles Dickens
Img_description: A smiling young boy. Graphite filter.
Description: A traveller meets many people upon a magical journey.
Blurb: I am always remembering. Come and remember with me!

Title: Chiming a Dream
Author: William Ernest Henley
Img_description: A calm beach coast. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on meeting a woman on a beach.
Blurb: A dream of the sea in her eyes—And the kiss of the sea in her hair.

Title: Cinderella
Author: Brothers Grimm
Img_description: A woman with curly locks in a ball gown by a castle. Graphite filter.
Description: A young girl is pushed around by her step-mother and step-sisters until one day she manages to make it into the king’s ball.
Blurb: “No one shall be my wife but she whose foot this golden slipper fits.”

Title: The City Bushman
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A man in a suit and hat. Graphite filter.
Description: A critique of men who romantisise the country while real bushmen toil under the sun.
Blurb: For the drought will go on drying while there’s anything to dry — Then it rains until you’d fancy it would bleach the sunny sky.

Title: The City of the Gone Away
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A stone grave with an wreath shape embossed upon it. Graphite filter.
Description: A man sets up a physician’s practice in a town. Having no experience in medicine matters to him not, and he buys a diploma from an eminent forgerer.
Blurb: Awakening from my dream, I collected my few belongings, bade adieu to my erring parents and departed out of that land, pausing at the grave of my grandfather, who had been a priest, to take an oath that never again, Heaven helping me, would I earn an honest penny.

Title: The City of the Singing Flame
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: Two men walking amongst a city full of aliens.
Description: Philip Hastane’s friend Giles Angarth, a semi-famous author, has disappeared along with another artist. Hastane receives a letter from the missing man, describing a mysterious world he discovered that houses an enchanting fountain of flame and alluring music.
Blurb: The temptation to return is more cogent than ever; the call of that remembered music is sweeter than the voice of a loved woman.

Title: Clair De Lune
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A kissing man and woman, silhouetted in a forest. Graphite filter.
Description: A priest is appalled to discover that his young niece has found a lover.
Blurb: But he hated woman—hated her unconsciously, and despised her by instinct. He often repeated the words of Christ: “Woman, what have I to do with thee?” and he would add: “It seems as though God, Himself, were dissatisfied with this work of His.”

Title: Clancy of the Overflow
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A pencil sketch of sketch itself of a man on a horse being drawn into a binder.
Description: A city man contemplates the life of a rural stock drover.
Blurb:
As the stock are slowly stringing, Clancy rides behind them singing,
For the drover’s life has pleasures that the townsfolk never know.

Title: Clay
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: The face of an old woman with wrinkles. Graphite filter.
Description: Maria, who works at a Magdalene Laundry, is constantly reminded of her unmarried status by the people around her.
Blurb: And when she laughed her grey-green eyes sparkled with disappointed shyness and the tip of her nose nearly met the tip of her chin.

Title: A Clean Well Lighted Place
Author: Ernest Hemmingway
Img_description: several men at a bar. Graphite filter.
Description: Two waiters discuss the lone, elderly man left in their cafe.
Blurb: “I wish he would go home. I never get to bed before three o’clock. What kind of hour is that to go to bed?”

Title: The Clockmaker
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson
Img_description: An ugly, broken window. Graphite filter.
Description: After a glass is left unattended for weeks, the micro-organisms develop society and science and begin to question the workings of their universe: the room.
Blurb: The cultus of the Clockmaker succeeded in the place of earlier religions, water worship, ancestor worship and the barbarous adoration of the chimney piece.

Title: A Clump Of Lilacs
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A bunch of lilacs flowers. Graphite filter.
Description: Army officer and student Nikolai accidentally blotches his survey drawing, his bluff that it was just a small bush fails. He is distraught and sure that the examiners will accuse him of having copied the survey from someone else, but his wife comes up with a plan...
Blurb: Nikolai Yevgrafovitch Almazof hardly waited for his wife to open the door to him; he went straight to his study without taking off his hat or coat. His wife knew in a moment by his frowning face and nervously-bitten underlip that a great misfortune had occurred.

Title: The Cobbler Turned Doctor
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A small glass vial with smoke inside. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on charlatanry.
Blurb: A very unskilful Cobbler, finding himself unable to make a living at his trade, gave up mending boots and took to doctoring instead. He gave out that he had the secret of a universal antidote against ...

Title: The Colour out of Space
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Drawing of two men looking out a window at smoke or steam rising out of a well.
Description: A meteorite crashes into a small town in a burst of light. Upon taking samples of the rock, scientists discover peculiar qualities including an indescribable emitted light and a perpetual heat.
Blurb: Into the fine flavour of the pears and apples had crept a stealthy bitterness and sickishness, so that even the smallest of bites induced a lasting disgust. It was the same with the melons and tomatoes, and Nahum sadly saw that his entire crop was lost.

Title: Come-By-Chance
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: Looking through the postal guide, the narrator discovers the isolated and hard-to-find, mystical location of ‘Come-by-Chance.’
Blurb: No location was assigned it, not a thing to help one find it, Just an N which stood for northward, and the rest was all unsaid.

Title: Coming
Author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
Img_description: Two old-fashioned suffragettes with 'votes for women' sashes
Description: A short poem on women’s emancipation.
Blurb: Now, for the world for which she was created - Comes woman to her own.

Title: The Coming of the Ice
Author: G. Peyton Wertenbaker
Img_description: Drawing of a man surrounded by knee-high people with large heads and helmets. Outside are strange buildings and flying ships.
Description: The last man on earth tells of his life as the first man to gain immortality through surgery.
Blurb: I recall only chaotic visions of fire and thunder and hell. It was all incomprehensible to me: like a bizarre dream, things happened, people rushed about, but I never knew what they were doing.

Title: The Coming-Out of Maggie
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: A man in a tuxedo tipping his hat. Graphite Filter.
Description: Maggie has never had her own “fellow” to take her to the local dance. But one day she turns up with a man taller and more charming than anyone in the hall.
Blurb: Usually at the weekly hops Maggie kept a spot on the wall warm with her back.

Title: The Cone
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: The insides of a factory with large hooks and high walkways. Graphite filter.
Description: The manager of an ironworks gives a tour to an artist secretly having an affair with his wife. The artist is paranoid as to whether the manager knows the truth, and they find themselves coincidentally visiting many parts of the factory capable of crushing, burning and boiling a man.
Blurb: And look at those furnaces of mine, how they rise upon us as we come down the hill. That to the right is my pet—seventy feet of him. I packed him myself, and he’s boiled away cheerfully with iron in his guts for five long years.

Title: Confession
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A brass, ring, door knocker. Graphite filter.
Description: A homeless man must devise elaborate stories on the fly to convince men and women to give him money and food.
Blurb: I was an English apprentice, I said. And they said that I didn’t talk like an English boy. It was up to me to create on the instant. I had been born and reared in the United States.

Title: Confessions of a Humorist
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: A pen writing on lined paper. Graphite filter.
Description: A clerk earns popularity as the towns humourist after a successful speech and a string of clever quips. Soon he is out of his drudgy office job and writing for a weekly publication, but the new work paradoxically begins to remove the humour from his life.
Blurb: I found myself listening to catch available ideas from the conversation of my friends. Sometimes I chewed my pencil and gazed at the wall paper for hours trying to build up some gay little bubble of unstudied fun.

Title: Conroy’s Gap
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: Three men with wide-brimmed hats riding horses in the outback.
Description: A trooper catches a fugitive at Conroy’s gap. But the captive man’s girl hatches a plan for his escape.
Blurb:
D’you know the place? It’s a wayside inn,
A low grog-shanty — a bushman trap,
Hiding away in its shame and sin
Under the shelter of Conroy’s Gap.

Title: Cool Air
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A man in a suit with bandages wrapped around all of his facial features in a wary posture with his hands lifted slightly.
Description: A man moves into a lodging downstairs from a doctor who keeps himself to his room in freezing conditions and experiments with chemical concoctions.
Blurb: You ask me to explain why I am afraid of a draught of cool air; why I shiver more than others upon entering a cold room, and seem nauseated and repelled when the chill of evening creeps through the heat of a mild autumn day.

Title: Counterparts
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: Wine being poured into a glass. Graphite filter.
Description: A man has difficulties with his boss, and resorts to drink.
Blurb: “Eh? Are you going to stand there all day? Upon my word, Farrington, you take things easy!”

Title: A Country Doctor
Author: Franz Kafka
Img_description: A bunch of medical instruments incl tweezers and scissors. Graphite Filter.
Description: A country doctor is desparate for a horse to make it to a dying patient when a pair of horses and a groom appear in his house out of nowhere.
Blurb: “In such cases the gods do help. They send the missing horse, even add a second one because it’s urgent, and even throw in a groom as a bonus.”

Title: The Country of the Blind
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A drawing of a man overlooking a cliff and seeing people walking on paths far away.
Description: A mountain-climber has a fall and finds himself in a geographically isolated region between the mountains. He discovers a culture of people who have lived so long by themselves they have developed peculiar qualities.
Blurb: They turned their faces this way and that, and Nunez gesticulated with freedom. But they did not appear to see him for all his gestures, and after a time, directing themselves towards the mountains far away to the right, they shouted as if in answer.

Title: The Coup De Grâce
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A soldier next to a cannon. Graphite filter.
Description: A solider finds his friend mortally wounded after a battle. With a revolver in hand, He ponders what he ought to do.
Blurb: For that which we accord to even the meanest creature without sense to demand it, denying it only to the wretched of our own race: for the blessed release, the rite of uttermost compassion, the coup de grace.

Title: A Coup D’etat
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A crystal crown sitting on a round, cloth-covered table
Description: After the monarchy falls in Paris, a part-time revolutionary leader in the small farming town of Canneville struggles to motivate his volunteers to oust the local, royalist-loyal mayor.
Blurb: “Here, my friends, go eat and drink; only leave me a detachment of ten men to guard against anybody’s leaving the town-hall.”

Title: The Crab and His Mother
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A small crab on the sand next to a branch. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on hypocrisy.
Blurb: An Old Crab said to her son, “Why do you walk sideways like that, my son? You ought to walk straight.” The Young Crab replied, “Show me how, dear mother, and I’ll follow your example.” The Old Crab tr...

Title: The Creatures That Time Forgot
Author: Ray Bradbury
