Img_description: A misty valley among tall cliffs. Graphite filter.
Description: A boy is born into a race of people who live only eight days.
Blurb: What kind of life is this where every last instant is drenched with fear and alert with death? Am I to be denied even some bit of real life?

Title: The Crooked Man
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Mr. James Barclay is found dead in his room, with his wife unconscious on a chair. Holmes is on the case.
Blurb: His mistress had ceased to scream and was stretched insensible upon a couch, while with his feet tilted over the side of an arm-chair, and his head upon the ground near the corner of the fender, was lying the unfortunate soldier stone dead in a pool of his own blood.

Title: Cry From a Far Planet
Author: Tom Godwin
Img_description: A large tiger-like being bites on the elbow of a man in front of spaceship controls.
Description: An explorer tries to communicate with the natives of a far away planet, but the aliens are heavily suspicious of him.
Blurb: “The damned communication barrier has been the cause behind the loss of every ship. And there is nothing we can do about it. We’re stymied by it....”

Title: The Crystal Egg
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A misty planet. Graphite filter.
Description: A curious, crystal egg begins to show visions that become clearer every day. Two friends try to investigate its meaning.
Blurb: The clergyman, without any ceremony, asked the price of the crystal egg. Mr. Cave glanced nervously towards the door leading into the parlour, and said five pounds.

Title: Cynthia
Author: Aldous Huxley
Img_description: A braided woman touching a tree. Graphite Filter.
Description: A man writes of meeting his eccentric friend who recounts his new obsession with a woman he met at the theatre.
Blurb: “I can sympathize with people’s pains, but not with their pleasures. There is something curiously boring about somebody else’s happiness.”

Title: Dagon
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Mud-caked ground. Graphite filter
Description: A WWII POW escapes a German ship and grounds himself ashore a murky, uncharted island.
Blurb: Then suddenly I saw it. With only a slight churning to mark its rise to the surface, the thing slid into view above the dark waters.

Title: The Damned Thing
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: Cat eyes in the darkness. Graphite Filter
Description: Hugh Morgan has died, and investigators slowly learn of the inexplicable, violent and perhaps supernatural way in which he did.
Blurb: The bushes were now quiet, and the sounds had ceased, but Morgan was as attentive to the place as before. ‘What is it? What the devil is it?’ I asked.

Title: Daniel Webster and the Sea Serpent
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: Bubbles in the water. Graphite filter
Description: Dan’l Webster and his friends are fishing when they catch on the lines the leviathan from scriptures herself.
Blurb: “Dan’l Webster hated to do it. But he couldn’t have a sea serpent living in Green Harbor River and scaring the stock—not to speak of the universal consternation and panic there’d be in the countryside when such a thing was known”

Title: A Dark Brown Dog
Author: Stephen Crane
Img_description: The face of a brown dog. Graphite filter.
Description: A child adopts a wandering dog into his family.
Blurb: The father of the family, it appears, was in a particularly savage temper that evening, and when he perceived that it would amaze and anger everybody if such a dog were allowed to remain, he decided that it should be so.

Title: The Dark Eidolon
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A rearing, bridled horse. Graphite filter.
Description: A beggar boy is trampled by an indifferent young prince and is taken in by a powerful wizard and trained in dark arts. One day, the beggar boy has become a famed sorcerer and the prince a king, and revenge is due.
Blurb: But never could he forget the miseries of his boyhood in Ummaos and the wrong he had endured from Zotulla; and year by year he spun over in his thoughts the black web of revenge.

Title: The Darling
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A young woman with braided hair. Graphite filter.
Description: An affectionate woman is known by everyone as ‘Darling’. She cannot bear being alone and latches onto the first man that comforts her.
Blurb: “Pity me, good people, all alone in the world!”

Title: A Day in the Country
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A little song-bird carrying a crumb in its mouth. graphite filter.
Description: A little beggar girl asks help from a man named Terenty.
Blurb: “In the count's copse Danilka stuck his hand into a hole in a tree, and he can't get it out. Come along, uncle, do be kind and pull his hand out!”

Title: The Daylight Is Dying
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: The sunrise. Graphite filter.
Description: A description of night-time in the bush.
Blurb:
When night doth her glories
Of starshine unfold,
’Tis then that the stories
Of bush-land are told.

Title: A Day’s Lodging
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A snow covered, log cabin. Graphite filter.
Description: A man takes shelter from the freezing Klondike region in an abandoned cabin, only to find another man and a woman knocking on the door soon after. After letting them in however, the woman turns out to be the last woman he expected to meet so far from home.
Blurb: “There was a sort of scandal in faculty circles some two or three years ago.  The wife of one of the English professors—er, if you will pardon me, Mrs. Haythorne—disappeared with some San Francisco doctor, I understood, though his name does not just now come to my lips.”

Title: The Dead
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: Multiple wine glasses being clinked together. Graphite filter.
Description: Gabriel Conroy and his wife Greta go to a Christmas party, where Gabriel is expected to make a speech. Through many conversations, Gabriel learns a lot about the other guests, and about his wife.
Blurb: Why is it that words like these seem dull and cold? Is it because there is no word tender enough to be your name?

Title: Dead Woman’s Secret
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A letter and envelope. Graphite filter.
Description: A man and woman grieve over their mother who has passed away. To relive her life, they decide to read some of her letters.
Blurb: He snatched the letter from her and looked for the signature. There was none, but only under the words, “The man who adores you.”

Title: A Deal in Old Masters
Author: Aldous Huxley
Img_description: Drawing of two men and a young woman surrounding a large painting of a young woman in a 19th century dress.
Description: An art dealer shows a painting of a woman to a wealthy man and tells of the love affair behind the picture.
Blurb: “Lady Hurtmore would have been more than human if she had been able to resist him. She was not more than human.”

Title: A Deal In Ostriches
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A wooden, five-masted sailing ship on the sea. Graphite filter.
Description: A domesticated ostrich is reported to have stolen a jewel from off a man’s turban, one worth thousands of pounds and disappeared back into its small herd. Everyone that hears of the rumour turns up to the auction of the herd, desperate for a chance to retrieve the diamond.
Blurb: You’d have thought five ostriches would have ruled cheap on an East Indiaman. But the point was, one of ’em had swallowed a diamond.

Title: A Death Bed
Author: Rudyard Kipling
Img_description: A luxurious, old-fashioned bed under a large window. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on a dying slowly.
Blurb: Some die wholly in half a breath. Some—give trouble for half a year.

Title: A Death in the Country
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: A wooden coffin with a cross. Graphite filter
Blurb: “The clever people they knew were entirely right, but most of them were deadly afraid of death.”

Title: The Death of a Government Clerk
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A man in a tuxedo tipping his hat. Graphite Filter.
Description: Ivan, a government clerk, accidentally sneezes on a general and is mortified.
Blurb: He saw that an old gentleman sitting in front of him in the first row of the stalls was carefully wiping his bald head and his neck with his glove and muttering something to himself.

Title: The Death of Halpin Frayser
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: The intense staring eyes of a man.
Description: A man wakes up in a forest speaking the name “Catherine LaRue”—a name he doesn’t even recognise himself.
Blurb: The man was Halpin Frayser. He lived in St. Helena, but where he lives now is uncertain, for he is dead.

Title: A Defenceless Creature
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A man with a suit and cane, tipping his hat. Graphite Filter.
Description: A bank manager struggles to deal with a particularly determined old lady.
Blurb: “I’ve had the law of three lodgers, and I will make you flop down at my feet for your saucy words!”

Title: The Defenders
Author: Phillip K. Dick
Img_description: Drawing of two men, one looking down a long tunnel filled with large metal mortar shells.
Description: Humanity has retreated underground to avoid the horrors of a permanent war, but strange messages are coming from the proxy war-robots running the surface.
Blurb: Now the surface was a lethal desert of slag and rolling clouds. Endless clouds drifted back and forth, blotting out the red Sun. Occasionally something metallic stirred, moving through the remains of a city, threading its way across the tortured terrain of the countryside.

Title: Demir-kayá
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A wood fire. Graphite filter.
Blurb: Wounded and bleeding, Demir-Kayá lay by the fire in the inaccessible cave where he found refuge with wild shepherds of the mountains. But in the middle of the night a bright angel with a flaming sword appeared before him.

Title: The Demon of the Flower
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A leafy vine. Graphite filter
Description: On a strange planet, the human-like inhabitants are ruled by a lordly class of predatory plants, led by a single, large, godly flower. But a high-priest known as Lunithi strays from unquestioning worship when it his own betrothed that is asked to be sacrificed.
Blurb: There were dim myths of some primordial ruler who had dared to refuse the required sacrifice; and whose people, in consequence, had been decimated by a mortal war with the serpentine plants.

Title: The Descendant
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: An old man with a long beard and long hair. Graphite filter
Description: (Unfinished) - Williams befriends a man known to have been a scholar but has now become mad. Eventually the man reveals his strange past.
Blurb: In London there is a man who screams when the church bells ring.

Title: A Descent into the Maelstrom
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A wooden, five-masted sailing ship on the sea. Graphite filter.
Description: Overlooking the ocean from atop a craggy cliff, one man tells another of how he and his two brothers were dragged into the maelstrom below and how he survived.
Blurb: “Here the vast bed of waters, seamed and scarred into a thousand conflicting channels, burst suddenly into phrensied convulsion.”

Title: Desiree’s Baby
Author: Kate Chopin
Img_description: A blanketed baby in a basket. Graphite filter.
Description: Desiree, once found as an abandoned toddler, now has her own child. But her husband, usually a calm man, has become aggressive and reclusive for an unknown reason.
Blurb: It was no wonder ... that Armand Aubigny riding by and seeing her there, had fallen in love with her.

Title: The Detective Detector
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: The silhouette of a gun pointed down and a hand raised in fear. Graphite Filter.
Description: A criminal makes the preposterous claim of being able to track down a New York detective.
Blurb: “When our burglars walk into our houses and politely demand, thousands of dollars’ worth of jewels, and then dine and bang the piano an hour or two before leaving, how do you, a mere murderer, expect to come in contact with the detective that is looking for you?”

Title: The Devil and Daniel Webster
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: A pitchfork lying next to a clump of hay. Graphite filter.
Description: After hardship and sickness, the farmer Jabez Stone sells his soul to the devil for good fortune. Come the day of his reckoning, he wonders if the famous lawyer Daniel Webster could help him out.
Blurb: “Mr. Stone is an American citizen, and no American citizen may be forced into the service of a foreign prince. We fought England for that in ’12 and we’ll fight all hell for it again!”

Title: The Devil in Iron
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: In a forest, Conan looks at a strange murky creature.
Description: A lord of a coastal town allows a princess to ‘escape’, hoping that it will draw out the formidable barbarian Conan for an easy capture.
Blurb: “If we could trap Conan on that island, alone, we could hunt him down at our leisure, with bows, as men hunt a lion.”

Title: A Diagnosis of Death
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: An old man with long hair and beard, Graphite filter
Description: Hawver rents out a house from a doctor gone AWOL, only for the doctor to mysteriously appear in the house and leave again.
Blurb: “He held that it was possible in the case of many a person in good health to forecast his death with precision, several months in advance of the event.”

Title: The Diamond Maker
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: An old man with a long beard and long hair. Graphite filter.
Description: The protagonist meets a man who claims to ‘make’ diamonds, and is sick and tired of no one believing him.
Blurb: No doubt it is very absurd. You will not believe me even when I tell you, so that it is fairly safe to tell you. And it will be a comfort to tell someone.

Title: Dick Whittington and His Cat
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A house cat sitting outside. Graphite filter
Description: A poor boy decides to go to London, where he hears people sing and dance all day long and the streets are filled with gold.
Blurb: How far it was and how many days they took over the journey I do not know, but in due time Dick found himself in the wonderful city which he had heard so much of and pictured to himself so grandly. But oh! how disappointed he was when he got there.

Title: The Die-Hard
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: An old man with white hair and beard.
Description: An isolated old man take the imaginative and young Jimmy under his wing, telling him how much better he believes life was before 1850.
Blurb: And then there was Carrie, the cook. She’d have to be a slave again, of course, and though Jimmy Williams didn’t imagine that she’d mind, now and then he had just a suspicion that she might.

Title: The Dimension of Chance
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A forest valley between rocky cliffs and hills. Graphite filter.
Description: Two American soldiers piloting a plane chase after another plane holding a Japanese spy. The fleeing plane disappears into a blurry cloud and the Americans follow, finding themselves somewhere logic does not apply.
Blurb: From their new and close vantage, however, there was only one stream, which, flowing down the valley-bottom against the barring slope, ran turbulently uphill in a series of skyward-leaping rapids and cascades!

Title: The Disappearance of Lady Frances Carfax
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Holmes sends Watson to Lausanne, Switzerland to find the missing Lady Frances Carfax.
Blurb:
“Where is your warrant?”
Holmes half drew a revolver from his pocket. “This will have to serve till a better one comes.”

Title: The Disciple
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A big steamboat on the water. Graphite filter.
Blurb: Not even half an hour had passed before the table was covered with heaps of banknotes, little stacks of gold and piles of silver. The banker was losing all the time, and, with all this, his portrayal of amazement and indignation was done with exceeding verisimilitude.

Title: The Disintegration Machine
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: An assortment of cogs and gears. Graphite Filter
Description: A journalist and a scientist investigate a man who has claimed to invent a machine that can disintegrate and subsequently reintegrate anything put in its view.
Blurb: There is a Latvian gentleman named Theodore Nemor living at White Friars Mansions, Hampstead, who claims to have invented a machine of a most extraordinary character which is capable of disintegrating any object placed within its sphere of influence.

Title: Doc Mellhorn and the Pearly Gates
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: A ford Model T parked on a rural road.
Description: Doc Mellhorn finds himself in the great above, but isn’t ready to put down his stethoscope and accept a life of leisure, so he drives away from the pearly gates towards the ‘other place’ in search for patients.
Blurb: “Of course, back on earth a lot of her patients died. But that was because when she didn’t like a patient, she poisoned him. Well, she can’t poison anybody here and I’ve kind of got her out of the notion of it anyway.”

Title: The Doer of Good
Author: Oscar Wilde
Img_description: Half of a portrait of an old, tired, bearded man. Graphite Filter
Description: A man walks and finds people suffering for His Blessings.
Blurb: ‘But I was blind once, and you gave me sight. At what else should I look?’

Title: The Dog
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A panting dog or fox. Graphite filter.
Description: The author describes the character of the dog
Blurb: A dog without work is like a man without work, a nuisance to himself and everybody else.

Title: The Dog and the Shadow
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A fox-like dog panting outside in the snow. Graphite filter.
Description: A simple fable on restraint and karma.
Blurb: A Dog was crossing a plank bridge over a stream with a piece of meat in his mouth, when he happened to see his own reflection in the water. He thought it was another dog with a piece of meat twice as ...

Title: A Dog’s Tale
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A dog curled up on a chair
Description: A dog tells of its life in a family household.
Blurb: My father was a St. Bernard, my mother was a collie, but I am a Presbyterian.

Title: Don’t Look Now
Author: Daphne du Maurier
Img_description: A venician bridge over the water. Graphite Filter.
Description: ‘She said Christine was trying to tell her something about us, that we should be in danger if we stayed in Venice. Christine wanted us to go away as soon as possible.’
Blurb: John and Laura spot two strange old women while on their trip in Venice, and one of the old women sees something herself.

Title: The Doom That Came to Sarnath
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A non-modern city with a river and bridge. Graphite filter
Description: A city of men forms near an ancient stone city of ugly non-human beings. Disgusted by their neighbours, the men conquer, kill and destroy the city of the beings without remorse, stealing their holy idol as a symbol of conquest.
Blurb: But on the night after it was set up in the temple a terrible thing must have happened, for weird lights were seen over the lake, and in the morning the people found the idol gone, and the high-priest Taran-Ish lying dead, as from some fear unspeakable.

Title: The Door in the Wall
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Drawing of a door with plants and a panther peering out from inside.
Description: A man recounts the story of a magical world he once explored as a child but has never been able to return to since.
Blurb: ...and passed a row of frowsy little shops that were inexplicably familiar to me, and behold! there was my long white wall and the green door that led to the enchanted garden!

Title: Double Cosmos
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A sillhouetted, hooded figure in a cave holding a light. Graphite filter.
Description: A chemist experiments with drugs in an attempt to see into the delirium he experienced after a bout of scarlet fever.
Blurb: Now I rose to my feet and began to walk around the laboratory, tottering a little at first from that loss of control I have mentioned. The other-dimensional figure also rose and walked, with the same shaky and uncertain steps.

Title: The Double Shadow
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A pencil sketch of a cloaked person with two shadows heading of left and right.
Description: A master and apprentice of the occult acquire a tablet with inscriptions that not even the master in all his infamous wisdom can decipher. Emboldened by the mystery, the master endeavours to reveal the ancient secrets within whatever it may unleash.
Blurb: I have no knowledge of this thing nor its intention toward me, and no power to stay its progress. Go forth and leave me now; for I would not that any man should witness the defeat of my sorcery and the doom that may follow thereupon.

Title: The Dream
Author: Mary Shelley
Img_description: The sillhouette of a man and woman holding hands in a forest. Graphite filter.
Description: A woman is in love with the man, and he with her. But their fathers killed each other in battle and she wonders what she ought do.
Blurb: Forbidden pleasures are said to be the most agreeable.

Title: A Dream Lies Dead
Author: Dorothy Parker
Img_description: Clouds. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on dead dreams.
Blurb: Walk not in woe, But, for a little, let your step be slow.

Title: The Dream of a Ridiculous Man
Author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
Img_description: A small, blonde girl opens the jacket of a man to reveal a heart shaped blood stain on his shirt. Finger painting.
Description: A man filled with nihilism decides to end his life, but the thought of a desperate street girl that asked for his help plays on his mind. He falls asleep instead, and dreams of a world without cynicism.
Blurb: I could not die now without having first settled something.

Title: A Dream of Armageddon
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Drawing of a man and woman on an exotic balcony overlooking the sea.
Description: While reading a book on dreaming, a man is approached by a stranger who is eager to talk on the subject, chronicling a romantic series of dreams that unfolded over many nights of sleep.
Blurb: “But why should it be? If, indeed, this battle, this slaughter and stress is life, why have we this craving for pleasure and beauty? If there is no refuge, if there is no place of peace, and if all our dreams of quiet places are a folly and a snare, why have we such dreams?”

Title: The Dream Snake
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: A snake slithering along floorboards. Graphite filter.
Description: An old man tells of his nightmares of a gigantic serpent.
Blurb: My obsession of fear, as I stand there in my dream, is that the serpent will raise itself and peer into the window at me. And I know, in my dream, that if this occurs I shall go insane.

Title: A Dream Within a Dream
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A beach shore with the sun setting. Graphite Filter.
Description: A poem on life and loss.
Blurb: All that we see or seem - Is but a dream within a dream.

Title: The Dreams in the Witch-House
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A gothic, wooden, three storeyed house.
Description: Mathematician Walter Gilman lodges in the infamous ‘Witch House’ that has a long history of being haunted by a mysterious, human-faced rat known by all that dream or see of him as ‘Brown Jenkin’.
Blurb: The horror would appear to pop out of the rat-hole in the corner and patter toward him over the sagging, wide-planked floor with evil expectancy in its tiny, bearded human face; but mercifully, this dream always melted away before the object got close enough to nuzzle him.

Title: The Drover’s Sweetheart
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: Three men with wide-brimmed hats riding horses in the outback.
Description: A country woman talks of her adventurous lover.
Blurb:
He’ll come at night or not at all —
He left in dust and heat,
And when the soft, cool shadows fall
Is the best time to meet.

Title: The Drover’s Wife
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A snake slithering on wooden slats. Graphite Filter.
Description: A bushwoman is living with her four children and dog in the outback when a potentially venomous snake hides itself under the house.
Blurb: “If yer bit,” says Tommy, after a pause, “you’ll swell up, an smell, an’ turn red an’ green an’ blue all over till yer bust. Won’t he mother?”

Title: The Drug
Author: C. C. MacApp
Img_description: Pen drawing of two men, one reaching down into a pen and touching a pig.
Description: Manager Amos Parry sees the results of the company’s new hormonal drug and is disturbed by how it causes one of the laboratory pigs to act ‘unpiglike’.
Blurb: “Let’s say it’s only one per cent awake and walled off from the conscious mind. What would happen if something removed the wall and woke up the other ninety-nine per cent?”

Title: The Dunwich Horror
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A man covering his nose with his hand. graphite filter.
Description: Wilbur Whately ages at an abnormally fast rate, and is considered extremely hideous. Yet something else lives in his house that is much, much worse.
Blurb: Man rules now where They ruled once; They shall soon rule where man rules now.

Title: The Dweller in the Gulf
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A sillhouetted, hooded figure in a cave holding a light. Graphite filter.
Description: Three earthmen seek shelter in a cave from a Martian storm. Curious as to where it leads, the trio investigate the insides of the cave and find a spiraling road descending the insides of a seemingly bottomless gulf.
Blurb: “What’s the use of going further?” said Maspic. “I, for one, have had enough darkness already. And if we were to find anything by going on, it would be valueless—or unpleasant.”

Title: The Eagle and the Beetle
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A mouse poking out from behind some wood. Graphite filter.
Description: An origin fable on eagles and beetles.
Blurb: An Eagle was chasing a hare, which was running for dear life and was at her wits’ end to know where to turn for help. Presently she espied a Beetle, and begged it to aid her. So when the Eagle came up...

Title: The Eagle and the Cocks
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A chicken strutting through a field. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on the consequences of arrogance.
Blurb: There were two Cocks in the same farmyard, and they fought to decide who should be master. When the fight was over, the beaten one went and hid himself in a dark corner; while the victor flew up on to...

Title: The Eagle and the Fox
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A fox-like dog panting outside in the snow. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on betrayal and karma.
Blurb: An Eagle and a Fox became great friends and determined to live near one another: they thought that the more they saw of each other the better friends they would be. So the Eagle built a nest at the to...

Title: The Eagle, the Cat, and the Wild Sow
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A white cat sitting on a stone ledge. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on cunning and manipulation.
Blurb: An Eagle built her nest at the top of a high tree; a Cat with her family occupied a hollow in the trunk halfway down; and a Wild Sow and her young took up their quarters at the foot. They might have g...

Title: Easter Day
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A kissing man and woman, silhouetted in a forest. Graphite filter. Graphite filter.
Description: On meeting a childhood friend, Voznitsin recounts his childhood and his love for the four daughters of a family as a young boy.
Blurb: On his way from Petersburg to the Crimea Colonel Voznitsin purposely broke his journey at Moscow, where his childhood and youth had been spent, and stayed there two days. It is said that some animals...

Title: Egyptian Sorcery
Author: Algernon Blackwood
Img_description: The face of a sleeping young woman, graphite filter.
Description: A man is down on his luck after his investment in Egyptian Securites declines, but a strange dream of Egypt uncovers more than mere financial mysteries.
Blurb: But, even while he hastened, he knew that his personal desire to speak with his friend about Egyptian shares and Delta Lands was not his single object. Behind it, further in among as yet unstirring shadows, lay another deeper purpose.

Title: Elaine’s Tomb
Author: G. Peyton Wertenbaker
Img_description: A close up on the face of a sleeping, freckled young woman.
Description: Two lecturers go on an expedition to examine bodies found in Egypt that have been perfectly preserved for thousands of years. But a curse is inscribed near the tombs, warning of consequences for disturbing the treasures inside.
Blurb: “I can’t begin to tell you everything about them; but what I seized on at once was the suggestion that those people knew a way to revive life in their dead kings.”

Title: Eldorado
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A lance-wielding man on an armoured horse. Graphite filter
Description: A poem of the search for Eldorado.
Blurb: Singing a song, In search of Eldorado.

Title: The Elephant
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: An Indian elephant on a cobbled road. Graphite filter.
Description: A little girl of six is so unenthused by life it worries her parents that she will never be happy again until one day after a dream she begins to want one thing.
Blurb: “Mother⁠ ⁠… could I have⁠ ⁠… an elephant? Only not one that’s painted in a picture.⁠ ⁠… Eh?”

Title: Emerald
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A large, bridled horse rearing up. Graphite filter.
Description: A stallion racehorse, experiences anger, nostalgia and desire while the humans around him use and abuse him as if he had no feeling.
Blurb: And at once, Emerald saw in imagination the short track to the hippodrome, saw almost every house, every kerbstone, saw the sand of the hippodrome itself, the Tribune, the other horses, the green of the grass and the yellow of the track.

Title: The Emperor’s New Clothes
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: A king in a bare gown with no pants walks with his entourage in front of a crowd.
Description: Two swindlers promise a king that they will make him a set of clothes so fine only those worthy are able to see it.
Blurb: Both the swindlers begged him to be pleased to step nearer, and asked if here was not a pretty pattern, and beautiful colours; and they pointed to the bare looms, and the poor old minister kept staring at it, but he couldn’t see anything, because there was nothing to be seen.

Title: The Empire of the Ants
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A drawing of three sailors on a sinking wooden boat.
Description: A ship captain is asked to take his boat to assist a town on the Amazon against an army of... ants.
Blurb: When Captain Gerilleau received instructions to take his new gunboat, the Benjamin Constant, to Badama on the Batemo arm of the Guaramadema and there assist the inhabitants against a plague of ants, he suspected the authorities of mockery.

Title: The Empire of the Necromancers
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A human skull, graphite filter.
Description: After two necromancers raise an undead army with which they plan to become rulers of the land, one of the undead begins to remember his past life.
Blurb: And recalling it, he felt a vague stirring of revolt, a ghostly resentment against the magicians who had haled him forth to this calamitous mockery of life.

Title: The Empty House
Author: Algernon Blackwood
Img_description: A small candle in the dark. Graphite filter
Description: Shorthouse’s Aunt insists that they investigate the local haunted house, where a young woman was said to be murdered by her lover.
Blurb: Facing them, directly in their way between the doorposts, stood the figure of a woman. She had dishevelled hair and wildly staring eyes, and her face was terrified and white as death.

Title: An Encounter
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: A 20th century city with trams and horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: Two young boys take a day off from school to seek adventure.
Blurb: But real adventures, I reflected, do not happen to people who remain at home: they must be sought abroad.

Title: The End of the Story
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: Cover of 'The End of the Story'. A man in a cowl holds a sparkling wand up to a bare-breasted woman partially covered in a robe. Black and white sketch.
Description: Christophe Morand seeks shelter from a storm, finding it in an abbey full of hospitable monks. He is shown around their library, but warned from reading one book in particular.
Blurb: “There is a curse on the pages that you hold in your hand: an evil spell, a malign power is attached to them, and he who would venture to peruse them is henceforward in dire peril both of body and soul.”

Title: Eupompus Gave Splendour to Art by Numbers
Author: Aldous Huxley
Img_description: An alert man with a moustache. Graphite Filter.
Description: A man’s eccentric friend announces his discovery resulting from an obsessive investigation into the meaning of an obscure phrase he had read.
Blurb: “He just suddenly fell in love with numbers—head over ears, amorous of pure counting. Number seemed to him to be the sole reality, the only thing about which the mind of man could be certain.”

Title: Eveline
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: A kissing man and woman, silhouetted in a forest. Graphite filter.. Graphite filter.
Description: The young Eveline contemplates breaking her promise and running away from home.
Blurb: What would they say of her in the Stores when they found out that she had run away with a fellow?

Title: An Evening Guest
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A brass, ring, door knocker. Graphite filter.
Description: An anxious man is sent into an existential panic by an unassuming knock on his door.
Blurb: I do not know what will happen to me tomorrow.⁠ ⁠… Only the shallow, self-satisfied, dull pharisees, or the chosen clairvoyants, with extraordinarily sensitized spirits, know it⁠—or deceive themselves and others into a belief that they know it.

Title: Everybody Was Very Nice
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: An envelope with a wax stamp. Graphite filter
Blurb: The queer thing was that at first I didn’t feel married to Lisa at all. I mean, on the boat, and even at the hotel. She said, “But how exciting, darling!” and I suppose it was.

Title: The Evil Clergyman
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: An old man with long hair and beard. Graphite filter
Description: A man is shown into a room and told not to touch the box on the table in the middle.
Blurb: “I hope you won’t stay till after dark. And I beg of you to let that thing on the table—the thing that looks like a match box—alone. We don’t know what it is, but we suspect it has something to do with what he did. We even avoid looking at it very steadily.”

Title: Ex Oblivione
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A solitary, draping vine. Graphite filter
Description: A dying man explores worlds in his dreams.
Blurb: No new horror can be more terrible than the daily torture of the commonplace.

Title: An Extinct Angel
Author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
Img_description: A young woman with braided hair. Graphite filter.
Description: Once upon a time there was an angel in nearly every home, destined to toil away for their human with no complaint and no ambitions save for the desire to serve...
Blurb: He was apt to come home tired and cross, and in this exigency it was the business of the angel to wear a smile for his benefit—a soft, perennial, heavenly smile.

Title: The Eye of Apollo
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: Drawing of a man in a suit, a woman in a simple dress, a man in white robes and a priest sitting on an ornate chair.
Description: Father Brown and his companion become acquainted with the companion’s new upstairs neighbours, a new religious group worshipping Apollo and claiming the power to stare at the sun.
Blurb: Father Brown found Flambeau and some six other people standing round the enclosed space into which the lift commonly descended. But the lift had not descended. Something else had descended; something that ought to have come by a lift.

Title: The Eyes Have It
Author: Phillip K. Dick
Img_description: A human heart. Graphite filter.
Description: A man learns of a disturbing alien invasion through reading a book.
Blurb: I sickened. The rascal now had her hand, as well as her heart. I shudder to think what he’s done with them, by this time.

Title: Faces in the Street
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A 19th century city with trams and horse-drawn carriages. Graphite Filter.
Description: The author describes the faces of people in the city street.
Blurb: I wonder would the apathy of wealthy men endure - Were all their windows level with the faces of the poor?

Title: The Facts in the Case of M. Valdemar
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A straining hand. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator, a mesmerist (early hypnotist), finds a dying man willing to be mesmerised for experiment.
Blurb: There was no longer the faintest sign of vitality in M. Valdemar; and concluding him to be dead, we were consigning him to the charge of the nurses, when a strong vibratory motion was observable in the tongue.

Title: A Fairly Sad Tale
Author: Dorothy Parker
Img_description: Holding hands. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on finding the wrong men.
Blurb: They broke my heart, they stilled my song.

Title: The Fall of the House of Usher
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A spired castle looming high. Graphite filter
Description: A man comes to the aid of the Roderick Usher and his sister Madeline, who are both ill. Roderick however begins to tell the narrator that he believes the house to be sentient.
Blurb: I know not how it was—but, with the first glimpse of the building, a sense of insufferable gloom pervaded my spirit.

Title: The Farmer and His Sons
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A pitchfork lying next to a clump of hay. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on cunning.
Blurb: A Farmer, being at death’s door, and desiring to impart to his Sons a secret of much moment, called them round him and said, “My sons, I am shortly about to die; I would have you know, therefore, that...

Title: The Farmer and the Fox
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A pitchfork lying next to a clump of hay. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on cruelty and karma.
Blurb: A Farmer was greatly annoyed by a Fox, which came prowling about his yard at night and carried off his fowls. So he set a trap for him and caught him; and in order to be revenged upon him, he tied a b...

Title: Father and Sons
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A pitchfork lying down next to some hay. Graphite filter.
Description: A fable on unity.
Blurb: A certain man had several Sons who were always quarrelling with one another, and, try as he might, he could not get them to live together in harmony. So he determined to convince them of their folly b...

Title: Father Milon
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A knife stuck into the dirt
Description: In Prussian occupied France, an old man is questioned about the suspicious deaths of Prussian soldiers.
Blurb: For a month the German vanguard had been in this village. The French remained motionless, ten leagues away; and yet, every night, some of the Uhlans disappeared.

Title: The Fearsome Touch of Death
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: A tense hand in the darkness. Graphite Filter
Description: A man stands vigil over the body of a deceased recluse, but can’t bear the look of the man’s eyes.
Blurb: “Not superstitious, are you?”

Title: The Feast of Nemesis
Author: Saki
Img_description: A bee, graphite filter.
Description: After Mrs. Thackenbury complains of the difficulties of gift giving holidays, her nephew Clovis postures the idea of a holiday of the reversed kind. Where you give to people you loathe, negative gifts.
Blurb: “Just think how jolly it would be if a recognised day were set apart for the paying off of old scores and grudges, a day when one could lay oneself out to be gracefully vindictive to a carefully treasured list of ‘people who must not be let off.’”

Title: The Female of the Species
Author: Rudyard Kipling
Img_description: A mother holding a baby. Graphite filter.
Description: She who faces Death by torture for each life beneath her breast — May not deal in doubt or pity—must not swerve for fact or jest.
Blurb: A poem on feminine aggression

Title: Ferdinando Eboli
Author: Mary Shelley
Img_description: A soldier in fancy garb, with a sabre, on a horse. Graphite filter.
Description: After a man leaves for war he is captured and has his clothes stolen. On his escape back to freedom he finds a man that looks exactly the same as him and wearing his stolen clothes.
Blurb: You put me out of conceit with myself, to think that one, apparently so like me, should get on no better in the world.

Title: The Festival
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Two men wearing hooded robes. Graphite filter
Description: Destined by traditions passed down from his ancestors, a man heads to Kingsport to partake in a festival of his people.
Blurb: It was the Yuletide, that men call Christmas though they know in their hearts it is older than Bethlehem and Babylon, older than Memphis and mankind.

Title: Filmer
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: An assortment of cogs and gears. Graphite Filter
Description: The nervous genius Filmer has plans to design the first ever machine for heavier-than-air flight. But he has qualms about actually flying the thing.
Blurb: He was a Discoverer and he had Discovered. But he was not a Flying Man, and it was only now that he was beginning to perceive clearly that he was expected to fly.

Title: The Final Problem
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Holmes reveals that he has discovered that a ‘Professor Moriarty’ is behind nearly all of the major crime in London. He decides to submit the evidence to the police and put an end to the mastermind, knowing full well that the nemesis will seek revenge.
Blurb: It is with a heavy heart that I take up my pen to write these the last words in which I shall ever record the singular gifts by which my friend Mr. Sherlock Holmes was distinguished.

Title: The Fish and the Ring
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A gold ring. Graphite filter.
Description: A powerful Baron with the power to see the future foretells that his son will marry a lowly girl from a poor family. Determined to stop this from happening, he rides off to seek the girl before it is too late.
Blurb: But when he got to the river he flung the little thing into the swollen stream, and said to himself as he galloped back to his castle: “There goes Fate!”

Title: The Five Orange Pips
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: John Openshaw comes to Holmes for help. His father received a mysterious letter full of five orange pips, later he was found dead. Then his uncle received the same letter...
Blurb: “There is nothing more to be said or to be done tonight, so hand me over my violin and let us try to forget for half an hour the miserable weather and the still more miserable ways of our fellowmen.”

Title: The Flower-Women
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: Many crowded flowers, viewed from above. Graphite Filter.
Description: Maal Dweb, an all-powerful sorcerer decides to venture out into a world unprotected and unequipped to rediscover the thrill and excitement of a dangerous and difficult adventure.
Blurb: Maal Dweb approached the flower-women with a certain caution; for he knew that they were vampires. Their arms ended in long tendrils, pale as ivory, swifter and more supple than the coils of darting serpents, with which they were wont to secure the unwary victims drawn by their singing.

Title: The Flowering of the Strange Orchid
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Small blossoming flowers in the ground. Graphite filter.
Description: Wedderburn, avid collector of orchids, worries that he hasn’t had any adventure in his life. One day he comes home with exotic orchids he excitedly explains to his cousin were found underneath the foot of a dead adventurer.
Blurb: Every drop of blood, they say, was taken out of him by the jungle-leeches. It may be that very plant that cost him his life to obtain.

Title: The Flying Gang
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells of his satisfaction working for the ‘Flying Gang’.
Blurb: Come out with the pilot engine sharp - And away with the flying gang.

Title: The Flying Man
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A person sitting at the edge of a precipice overlooking a plains. Graphite filter.
Blurb: The Ethnologist looked at the bhimraj feather thoughtfully. “They seemed loth to part with it,” he said.“It is sacred to the Chiefs,” said the lieutenant; “just as yellow silk, you know, is sacred t...

Title: The Flying Stars
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: A woman in a black fur coat feeds small sparrow-sized birds.
Description: Diamonds go missing at a small Christmas party with very few suspects.
Blurb: It was just as if a crystal fountain had spurted in their eyes. In a nest of orange velvet lay like three eggs, three white and vivid diamonds that seemed to set the very air on fire all round them.

Title: The Footfalls Within
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Drawing of a man in a puritan hat stabs at a group of Arabian men with rifles.
Description: Solomon Kane tries to rescue a girl from slave traders when he is himself captured.
Blurb: “I would trade my soul’s salvation to face you and your sword, alone and unarmed, and to tear the heart from your breast with my naked fingers.”

Title: Found on a Drowned Man
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A wax-stamped letter. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells of how he has never loved a woman.
Blurb: In order to love, one must be blind, surrender one's self absolutely, see nothing, question nothing, understand nothing. One must adore the weakness as well as the beauty of the beloved object, renounce all judgment, all reflection, all perspicacity.

Title: Four Men in a Cave
Author: Stephen Crane
Img_description: A cave with a beam of light shining down from an opening. Graphite filter.
Description: Four men explore a cave. After an argument and a fight, they all fall down a slope and find something unexpected deep inside.
Blurb: The four men lay in a heap upon the floor of a grey chamber. A small fire smoldered in the corner, the smoke disappearing in a crack. In another corner was a bed of faded hemlock boughs and two blankets. Cooking utensils and clothes lay about, with boxes and a barrel.

Title: The Fox and the Crow
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A fox-like dog panting outside in the snow. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on cunning.
Blurb: A Crow was sitting on a branch of a tree with a piece of cheese in her beak when a Fox observed her and set his wits to work to discover some way of getting the cheese. Coming and standing under the t...

Title: The Fox and the Grapes
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A fox-like dog panting outside in the snow. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable about sourness and... bitterness (The origin of the expression ‘sour grapes’).
Blurb: A hungry Fox saw some fine bunches of Grapes hanging from a vine that was trained along a high trellis, and did his best to reach them by jumping as high as he could into the air.

Title: The Fox and the Stork
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A fox-like dog panting outside in the snow. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on karma.
Blurb: A Fox invited a Stork to dinner, at which the only fare provided was a large flat dish of soup. The Fox lapped it up with great relish, but the Stork with her long bill tried in vain to partake of the...

Title: Freedom’s a Hard-Bought Thing
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: Long, iron chains falling onto a tense but open hand, palm up. Graphite filter.
Description: Cue has only known being a slave and has never questioned it. Then after both his parents die of sickness, he begins to question the way of things.
Blurb: “The freedom sickness,” said the old woman, and her little eyes glittered like sparks. “Some they break and some they tame down,” she said, “and some is neither to be tamed or broken.”

Title: A Friend of Napoleon
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: Drawing of a man running through the streets holding a wax figure.
Description: A lonely wax museum worker must save his friends when the museum closes down.
Blurb: “Stop! Desecraters of Napoleon, stop! There still lives one Frenchman who loves the memories of his native land; there is still one patriot left. I, I, Jerome Chibou, will save Napoleon!”

Title: The Frog-Prince
Author: Brothers Grimm
Img_description: A dumb-looking frog. Graphite filter.
Description: After a princess loses her ball in a spring, she offers a frog all that he wants if he can bring it back to her.
Blurb: “I told him that he should live with me here, thinking that he could never get out of the spring; but there he is at the door, and he wants to come in.”

Title: The Frogs Asking for a King
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A frog with a blank stare. Graphite filter.
Description: A small origin story for frogs.
Blurb: Time was when the Frogs were discontented because they had no one to rule over them: so they sent a deputation to Jupiter to ask him to give them a King. Jupiter, despising the folly of their request,...

Title: From Beyond
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: The tense, staring eye of a man's face. Graphite filter
Description: After originally being banished from a scientists house for insisting he halt his experiments, a man is invited back to see the new discovery said to open up man’s untapped senses.
Blurb: These things should be left to the frigid and impersonal investigator, for they offer two equally tragic alternatives to the man of feeling and action; despair if he fail in his quest, and terrors unutterable and unimaginable if he succeed.

Title: The Frost Giant’s Daughter
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: The hilt and bottom half of an iron sword. Graphite filter.
Blurb: Across the red drifts and mail-clad forms, two figures glared at each other. In that utter desolation only they moved. The frosty sky was over them, the white illimitable plain around them, the dead men at their feet.

Title: Gabriel-Ernest
Author: Saki
Img_description: Eyes in the darkness. Graphite filter.
Description: Van Cheele finds a mysterious and menacing boy in the forest, who claims to live in the woods by himself.
Blurb:
’What do you feed on?’ he asked.
’Flesh,’ said the boy, and he pronounced the word with slow relish, as though he were tasting it.

Title: The Garden Of The Holy Virgin
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A bunch of lilacs flowers. Graphite filter.
Description: The Holy Virgin Mary walks among a garden where each flower holds the particle of a man.
Blurb: Oppressive silence, as before a thunderstorm, overhangs the world. The air is perfectly motionless. But the flowers tremble and sway in fright as in a tempest, bending to the very ground and extending their heads to the Virgin with boundless entreaty.

Title: The Gateway of the Monster
Author: William Hope Hodgson
Img_description: Two men peer into a room with an ornate bed.
Description: Carnacki is called to a house to sort out the mysterious noises coming from the ‘grey room’, a room where three different people were found strangled to death in generations past.
Blurb: “It passed swiftly ’round the circle, and seemed to probe ever toward me; but only to draw back with extraordinary jerky movements, as might a living person if they touched the hot bar of a grate.”

Title: The Geebung Polo Club
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A gravestone. Graphite filter.
Description: A mountain-side polo club and a posh, city polo club have a match to determine who’s the best.
Blurb: Now my readers can imagine how the contest ebbed and flowed, — When the Geebung boys got going it was time to clear the road — And the game was so terrific that ere half the time was gone — A spectator’s leg was broken — just from merely looking on.

Title: The Ghost in Master B’s Room
Author: Charles Dickens
Img_description: A gothic, wooden, three storeyed house.
Blurb: I trembled and looked over my shoulder; nothing there. I looked again in the glass, and distinctly saw the features and expression of a boy, who was shaving, not to get rid of a beard, but to get one.

Title: The Giant Wistaria
Author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
Img_description: A gothic, wooden, three storeyed house.
Blurb: O, George, what a house! what a lovely house! I am sure it’s haunted!

Title: The Gift of the Magi
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: Rusty coins in the palm of someones hands. Graphite filter.
Description: Della sells her prized locks to buy a present for her husband.
Blurb: There was clearly nothing to do but flop down on the shabby little couch and howl.

Title: The Girls in Their Summer Dresses
Author: Irwin Shaw
Img_description: A woman with a thatched bag and a light summer dress. Graphite filter.
Description: A woman becomes increasingly frustrated with her partner for staring at girls on the street.
Blurb: “She’s not so pretty, anyway,” Frances said. “Anyway, not pretty enough to take a chance breaking your neck looking at her.”

Title: Glamour
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: Silhouette of man and woman kissing in front of balcony. Graphite filter
Description: A man comes into a large inheritance and quits his job to write a novel. But it does not work out as expected.
Blurb: “ I didn’t want to make the best of things—I wanted it all. You can’t compromise with glamour. Or that’s the way I feel.”

Title: The “Gloria Scott”
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Holmes recounts of the case that set him on his path of detective work. He was dining with his friend and friend’s father when he makes a deduction about the father’s past, accidentally shocking his host.
Blurb: Mr. Trevor stood slowly up, fixed his large blue eyes upon me with a strange wild stare, and then pitched forward, with his face among the nutshells which strewed the cloth, in a dead faint.

Title: God Sees the Truth, But Waits
Author: Leo Tolstoy
Img_description: An ugly, broken window. Graphite filter.
Description: A merchant’s wife has a bad dream that her husband’s journey to the fair won't bode well, but he goes nonetheless.
Blurb: “Here is this blood-stained knife in your bag and your face and manner betray you! Tell me how you killed him, and how much money you stole?”

Title: Going Blind
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A pair of elderly hands clutching a cane. graphite filter.
Description: A young man meets a bushman in a hotel. The older man is going blind, and wonders what work he will be able to do in the country once his sight worsens.
Blurb: Darkness fell quickly upon him now—or, rather, the “sort of white blur” increased and closed in. But his hearing was better, he said, and he was glad of that and still cheerful. I thought it natural that his hearing should improve as he went blind.

Title: The Golden Ball
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A woman with curly locks in a ball gown by a castle. Graphite filter.
Description: A girl is taken away to be hanged for losing a golden ball. So her lover sets out to find it.
Blurb: Once upon a time there lived two lasses, who were sisters, and as they came from the fair they saw a right handsome young man standing at a house door before them. They had never seen such a handsome...

Title: The Golden Snuff-box
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A detailed, silver box. Graphite filter
Description: A boy who grows up only ever knowing his parents and no one else, longs to go out into the world.
Blurb: Once upon a time, and a very good time too, though it was not in my time, nor your time, nor for the matter of that in any one’s time, there lived a man and a woman who had one son called Jack, and he...

Title: Gooseberries
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A large, robed man looks chuffed as he eats small berries from a plate while sitting in a chair.
Description: A man tells of his younger brother who retired to the country to relive their childhood.
Blurb: “There ought to be behind the door of every happy, contented man some one standing with a hammer continually reminding him with a tap that there are unhappy people.”

Title: The Gorgon
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A woman clutching her face.
Description: A strange, old man appears and offers an enthusiast of the horrible and deadly the chance to gaze upon the head of Medusa herself.
Blurb: “I can see that you have a taste for horror. The dark and awful secrets of death. the equally dreadful mysteries of life, allure your interest. If you care to come with me, I will show you something which is the quintessence of all horror.”

Title: Grace
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: Communion bread and wine on a table. Graphite filter.
Description: A man has fallen down the stairs at a pub after drinking heavily, and must be helped by his friends.
Blurb: “To tell you the truth, Tom, we’re going to make a retreat.”

Title: The Great Calamity
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A splash of water in the air. Graphite filter.
Description: Two Scots are drinking when one spill some drink.
Blurb:
MacFierce’un came to Whiskeyhurst
When summer days were hot,
And bided there wi’ Jock McThirst,
A brawny brother Scot.

Title: The Great Keinplatz Experiment
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A stunned looking young man with a moustache. Graphite filter.
Description: Professor von Baumgarten attempts to prove the spirit’s ability to wander free from its body, but accidentally swaps his own with that of his young student’s.
Blurb: Had the green man who is depicted upon the signpost of that well-known inn suddenly marched into the room and called for a bottle of wine, the students could not have been more amazed than they were by this unexpected entry of their revered professor.

Title: The Great Return
Author: Arthur Machen
Img_description: A sunrise. Graphite filter.
Blurb: A shadow of its raptures and ecstasies is found in the highest poetry; there are phrases in ancient books telling of the Celtic saints that dimly hint at it; some of the old Italian masters of painting had known it, for the light of it shines in their skies and about the battlements of their cities that are founded on magic hills.

Title: The Greek Interpreter
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A Greek interpreter comes to Holmes after he was forced by a customer to interpret between said man and what appeared to be his bound hostage.
Blurb: ‘if you speak to a human soul about this—one human soul, mind—well, may God have mercy upon your soul!’

Title: The Griffin and the Minor Canon
Author: Frank Stockton
Img_description: Black talons overhanging a wooden edge. Graphite filter.
Description: A griffin from the dreadful wilds hears that a village has a stone image of himself. Curious to know what he looks like, he decides to visit the village and see it.
Blurb: They would offer him the fattest mutton, the most tender beef fish, and game of various sorts, and anything of the kind that he might fancy. If none of these suited, they were to mention that there was an orphan asylum in the next town.

Title: The Grisly Folk
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A man sitting on a precipice overlooking a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: The author creates a hypothetical, historical story of the first of modern men to meet and clash with the Neanderthals.
Blurb: There are the soundest reasons for believing that these earlier so-called men were not of our blood, not our ancestors, but a strange and vanished animal, like us, akin to us, but different from us, as the mammoth was like, and akin to, and yet different from, the elephant.

Title: A Guest Of Ganymede
Author: C. C. MacApp
Img_description: The faces of two men and the face of an alien, background of stars in space. A syringe and a pill float around them.
Description: Gil Murdoch has ferried his wealthy, blind client to a hidden, alien hospital where they will heal his eyes with their firmly-guarded, cure-all virus. But Gil isn’t satisfied with a simple payment, and has other plans for Ganymede and their famous panacea.
Blurb: Murdoch watched Waverill’s face but it showed nothing. He was sure the billionaire already had arrangements to shut him up permanently as soon as he was no longer needed, and he didn’t intend, of course, to let those arrangements work out.

Title: Hamlet
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A human skull. Graphite filter
Description: The renowned actor Kostromsky has been riding the wave of his fame for many years. But one night, after a young, doe eyed student must stand in for the vacant role of Ophelia, Kostromsky faces the prospect of being upstaged for the first time in his life.
Blurb: “Here you, devils, let me come to the curtain! I must go out and tell the people at once that there will be no performance. There’s no Ophelia. Understand! There’s no Ophelia.”

Title: The Hammer of God
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: A man with a large hat and coat ponders over a man lying outstreched on a bench outside of a pub.
Description: A Reverend warns his brother that his visits to the blacksmith’s wife can only end in disaster.
Blurb: “Plenty of horror, sir,” he said; “but not much mystery.”

Title: The Hammerpond Park Burglary
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A gothic, wooden, three storeyed house.
Description: Teddy Watkins hears of the newly married Lady Aveling, her large honeymoon house, and the shiny and sparkling wedding gifts inside. So, posing as a painter he gets himself a good look at the house, and all its open windows.
Blurb: It is a moot point whether burglary is to be considered as a sport, a trade, or an art. For a trade, the technique is scarcely rigid enough, and its claims to be considered an art, are vitiated by the mercenary element that qualifies its triumphs.

Title: The Hand
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A large hand, palm up with tense fingers. Graphite filter.
Description: A stranger comes to town, bringing with him a souvenir hand. He says he cut it off from an enemy and that it still seeks revenge.
Blurb:
“I said:
“ ‘Are all these animals dangerous?’
“He smiled:
“ ‘Oh, no! Man is the worst.’

Title: The Hanging Stranger
Author: Phillip K. Dick
Img_description: A panicked man runs from a man hanging from a lamppost as monstrous bugs fly after him.
Description: Ed Joyce sees a disturbing sight on the street, but no one else seems to care.
Blurb: The lamppost jutted up against the sky—the post and the bundle swinging from it. “There it is. How the hell long has it been there?” His voice rose excitedly. “What’s wrong with everybody? They just walk on past!”

Title: Hansel and Gretel
Author: Brothers Grimm
Img_description: A sparrow eating a crumb of bread. Graphite filter.
Description: Two young children are thrown out of home. Hungry, they soon come across a strange house made of bread and cake.
Blurb: And when they approached the little house they saw that it was built of bread and covered with cakes, but that the windows were of clear sugar.

Title: Happiness
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A dusty, barred prison window. Graphite filter.
Description: A tzar orders his citizens in turn what happiness is.
Blurb: A great tzar ordered the poets and sages of his country to be brought before him. And he asked them this question: “In what does happiness consist?”

Title: The Happy Prince
Author: Oscar Wilde
Img_description: A standing swallow. Graphite filter.
Description: A statue of a prince seeks help from a little swallow to prevent the misery that he can see but not affect.
Blurb: There is no Mystery so great as Misery. Fly over my city, little Swallow, and tell me what you see there.

Title: The Hare and the Tortoise
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A mouse poking out from behind some wood. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on being slow and steady.
Blurb: A Hare was one day making fun of a Tortoise for being so slow upon his feet. “Wait a bit,” said the Tortoise; “I’ll run a race with you, and I’ll wager that I win.” “Oh, well,” replied the Hare, who w...

Title: A Haunted House
Author: Virginia Woolf
Img_description: A cat's eyes in the darkness. Graphite filter.
Blurb: Whatever hour you woke there was a door shutting.

Title: A Haunted Island
Author: Algernon Blackwood
Img_description: Looking out onto a jungle island from a small boat. Graphite filter.
Description: A man stays at a cottage on an island to catch up on his studies, but one night he notices a canoe circling around.
Blurb: I was not surprised to fancy I heard a shout or a cry as I passed from rock to rock, and more than once to imagine that I heard my own name called aloud.

Title: The Haunted Mind
Author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
Img_description: A large, ornate bed beneath two glass windows. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator describes our common experience of waking, interrupted from a dream.
Blurb: You find yourself for a single instant wide awake in that realm of illusions whither sleep has been the passport, and behold its ghostly inhabitants and wondrous scenery with a perception of their strangeness such as you never attain while the dream is undisturbed.

Title: The Haunter of the Dark
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A small candle in the dark. Graphite filter
Description: Artist Robert Blake can see a church from the window of his new house in Providence. Eventually he can bear his curiosity no longer and breaks into the abandoned and locally shunned building, discovering things that were best left alone.
Blurb: During the dark hour praying crowds had clustered round the church in the rain with lighted candles and lamps somehow shielded with folded paper and umbrellas—a guard of light to save the city from the nightmare that stalks in darkness.

Title: The Heavenly Christmas Tree
Author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
Img_description: A spruce tree in the snow. graphite filter.
Description: A poor boy wanders the street on Christmas Eve.
Blurb: “Come to my Christmas tree, little one.”

Title: The Hen
Author: Saki
Img_description: A saber sword.
Description: Clovis has to convince the house guest Jane Martlet to leave on time before her bitter enemy Dora Bittholz arrives next Thursday.
Blurb: “I’m told that the letters which passed between the two women were a revelation as to how much invective could be got on to a sheet of notepaper.”

Title: Henny Penny
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A chicken strutting through a field. Graphite filter.
Description: After Henny-penny is hit on the head by an acorn, she goes around telling everyone the sky is falling down.
Blurb: “the sky’s a-going to fall; I must go and tell the King.”

Title: Her Letters
Author: Kate Chopin
Img_description: A sealed envelope. Graphite filter.
Description: A woman tries to force herself to burn her own mysterious letters.
Blurb: She was thinking; thinking of a way to keep them without possible ultimate injury to that other one whom they would stab more cruelly than keen knife blades.

Title: Hermann the Irascible
Author: Saki
Img_description: An ink pen in the middle of writing. Graphite filter.
Description: The King of Britain hatches a plan to deal with the suffragettes.
Blurb: “Every woman between the ages of twenty-one and seventy will be obliged to vote, not only at elections for Parliament, county councils, district boards, parish-councils, and municipalities, but for coroners, school inspectors, churchwardens...”

Title: Hills Like White Elephants
Author: Ernest Hemmingway
Img_description: Rolling hills. Graphite filter.
Description: A man and woman discuss an unnamed ‘operation’.
Blurb: “And you think then we’ll be all right and be happy.” - “I know we will. You don’t have to be afraid. I’ve known lots of people that have done it.”

Title: The Hills of the Dead
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Drawing of a lion chasing a woman through grass while carrion birds watch on.
Description: Solomon Kane is gifted a powerful staff by a witch doctor and ventures into the jungle.
Blurb: “Where your guns and long knife fail, this save you.”

Title: His Father’s Mate
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A well from bird's eye view. Graphite filter
Description: A man dies in a mine shaft collapse.
Blurb: Without a moment’s warning the treacherous bole slipped round; a small body bounded a couple of times against the sides of the shaft and fell at Mason’s feet, where it lay motionless!

Title: His Last Bow
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A German spy plans to take secret information back to Germany, but has one last rendezvous.
Blurb: Tut, my dear sir, we live in a utilitarian age. Honour is a mediaeval conception

Title: His Wife’s Deceased Sister
Author: Frank Stockton
Img_description: A fountain pen writing on lined paper. Graphite Filter
Description: After publishing a smash hit titled “His Wife’s Deceased Sister”, a humble author struggles to find any more work.
Blurb: “Suppose Raphael’s patrons had tried to keep him screwed up to the pitch of the Sistine Madonna, and had refused to buy anything which was not as good as that”

Title: The History of the Necronomicon
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A splayed open book. Graphite filter
Blurb:
Original title Al Azif—azif being the word used by Arabs to designate that nocturnal sound (made by insects) suppos’d to be the howling of daemons.
Composed by Abdul Alhazred, a mad poet of Sa...

Title: An Honest Thief
Author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
Img_description: The tired face of an old, bearded man. graphite filter.
Description: A man is convinced by his housekeeper to allow an old man to lodge in one of his small rooms. The old man eventually tells of how he himself once allowed a poorer man to live in his house.
Blurb: “Why, what am I to do, Astafy Ivanovitch? I know very well I am a drunkard and good for nothing!”

Title: Honor Among Sportsmen
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: An enormous pig snuffling along the ground. Graphite Filter.
Description: Monsieur Bonticu and his pig Anastasia, and Monsieur Pantan and his pig Clotilde, two of the most fine truffle hunters pairs of Montpont fall into disagreement at the Sunday truffle hunting championship, leading to the ‘ultimate insult’.
Blurb: Anastasie was his pig, a prodigy at detecting truffles, and his most priceless treasure. He once said, at a truffle-hunters’ dinner, “I have but two passions, my comrades. The pursuit of the truffle and the flight from the female.”

Title: The Honour of Israel Gow
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: Three men discuss at a table in the dark with only a small candle illuminating their faces.
Blurb:
As green sap to the simmer trees 
Is red gold to the Ogilvies.

Title: The Horla
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: The intense eye of a staring man. graphite filter.
Description: A man writes in his diary of an affliction that keeps him in a permanent panic. He begins to worry it is an unseen, living entity trying to control him.
Blurb: Oh, the vulture has been used to eat the dove, the wolf to eat the sheep; the lion to devour the sharp-horned buffalo; man to kill the lion with arrow, spear and gun; but the Horla is going to make of man what we have made of the horse and the cow: his thing, his servant and his food, by the mere force of his will. Woe to us!

Title: The Horrible
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: Eight soldiers with rifles on a beach facing an explosion
Description: In response to his men talking of a terrible accident, a general tells two stories to exemplify what real horror is.
Blurb: In order that we should experience horror, something more is needed than emotion, something more than the spectacle of a dreadful death; there must be a shuddering sense of mystery, or a sensation of abnormal terror, more than natural.

Title: The Horror in the Museum
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Black talons overhanging a wooden edge. Graphite filter.
Description: A museum owner, George Rogers, insists that his museum exhibits are more than just wax. (Ghost-written for Hazel Heald)
Blurb: “Even if you did think I made that oblong swimmer in darkness out of wax. If you’d seen it writhing in the underground pools as I did. . . .”

Title: The Horror of the Heights
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A colourful drawing of a early aeroplane flying over purple, tentacled creatures.
Description: Pilot Joyce-Armstrong theorises that there are unexplored ‘jungles’ in the upper atmosphere where new mysteries lie. And with modern aeroplanes with powerful engines, they are now within reach.
Blurb: I have seen the beauty and I have seen the horror of the heights—and greater beauty or greater horror than that is not within the ken of man.

Title: The Horse of the Invisible
Author: William Hope Hodgson
Img_description: Drawing of one man holding a lamp and another holding a fainted woman.
Description: Carnacki must solve a seemingly generational curse afflicting the first-born females of the Hisgin family.
Blurb: “The fifth girl was killed one evening in the park ’round the house; but just how, there seemed to be no exact knowledge; only that there was an impression that she had been kicked by a horse.”

Title: A Horseman in the Sky
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A person sitting at the edge of a precipice overlooking a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A Union sentinel of the American civil war falls asleep on duty, and wakes up to see a confederate scout spot the troops he was meant to be protecting.
Blurb: Well, go, sir, and whatever may occur do what you conceive to be your duty. Virginia, to which you are a traitor, must get on without you.

Title: The Hound
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A round gravestone. Graphite filter
Description: Two graverobbers find and steal an amulet in a grave in a Holland churchyard. But from then on they sense something bestial stalking them and getting closer every day.
Blurb: It was this frightful emotional need which led us eventually to that detestable course which even in my present fear I mention with shame and timidity—that hideous extremity of human outrage, the abhorred practice of grave-robbing.

Title: The House Among the Laurels
Author: William Hope Hodgson
Img_description: Drawing of a spired, gothic house behind a decorated, wrought iron gate.
Description: Carnacki brings a team to investigate a house with what appears to be blood dripping from the ceiling.
Blurb: “By his tone, I could tell that he was feeling something of the strangeness of it all; and the other men, including Wentworth, were so quiet that I was afraid they were beginning to get shaky.”

Title: A House in the Country
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: An oven. Graphite Filter.
Description: Appleby, an old acquaintance from college is found searching for furnishings for his house, which he does not own. Appleby insists that he is simply preparing for retirement very... very early.
Blurb: “‘Life,’ I said to myself, ‘is as empty as a used cantaloupe.’”

Title: How Gilbert Died
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: Two outlaws hole up in a hut from the police.
Blurb: But the smallest child on the Watershed - Can tell you how Gilbert died.

Title: How I Became an Actor
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A pair of hands carefully holding a dozen coins. Graphite filter.
Blurb: On my way I thought to myself: Why didn’t he ask for my stage name? Probably he forgot. Perhaps he guessed that I had none. And in case of an emergency I then and there invented a name⁠.

Title: How Jack Went Out To Seek His Fortune
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A person sitting at the edge of a precipice. Graphite filter.
Description: The young Jack goes out to seek his fortune, making strange friends along the way.
Blurb: Jack gave the word, and the cat mewed, and the dog barked, and the goat bleated, and the bull bellowed, and the rooster crowed, and all together they made such a terrific hubbub that the robbers jumped up in a fright and ran away, leaving their gold on the table.

Title: How M’Ginnis Went Missing
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A rocky creek flowing away from view. Graphite filter.
Description: A man drowns after sleeping by a river.
Blurb:
Let us cease our idle chatter,
 Let the tears bedew our cheek,
For a man from Tallangatta
 Has been missing for a week.

Title: How The Camel Got His Hump
Author: Rudyard Kipling
Img_description: A proud looking camel. Graphite filter.
Description: A fable on the origin of a camel’s hump.
Blurb: But no sooner had he said it than he saw his back, that he was so proud of, puffing up and puffing up into a great big lolloping humph.

Title: How the Favourite Beat Us
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A bridled horse racing down a track. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells of how he lost all of his money on his own horse.
Blurb:
‘Aye,’ said the boozer, ‘I tell you it’s true, sir,
‘I once was a punter with plenty of pelf,
‘But gone is my glory, I’ll tell you the story
‘How I stiffened my horse and got stiffened myself.

Title: How The Rhinocerous Got His Skin
Author: Rudyard Kipling
Img_description: A rhino. Graphite filter.
Description: A fable on the origin of a rhino’s wrinkly skin.
Blurb: In those days the Rhinoceros’s skin fitted him quite tight. There were no wrinkles in it anywhere. He looked exactly like a Noah’s Ark Rhinoceros, but of course much bigger.

Title: How The Whale Got His Throat
Author: Rudyard Kipling
Img_description: A whale launching out of the sea Graphite filter.
Description: A fable on the origin of a whale’s throat.
Blurb: Then the Whale opened his mouth back and back and back till it nearly touched his tail, and he swallowed the shipwrecked Mariner.

Title: A Hunger Artist
Author: Franz Kafka
Img_description: Many strands of bunched straw. graphite filter
Description: A man commits himself further and further upon his art of fasting for weeks at a time.
Blurb: No one had any reason to be dissatisfied with what he had seen - no one, that is, except for the starvation artist, he alone, always.

Title: Hunted Down
Author: Charles Dickens
