Img_description: A man in a tux and with a cane, tipping his hat
Description: Mr Sampson, life assurance manager, distrusts a man that walks into his office by the way he looks.
Blurb: I have known a vast quantity of nonsense talked about bad men not looking you in the face. Don’t trust that conventional idea. Dishonesty will stare honesty out of countenance, any day in the week, if there is anything to be got by it.

Title: The Hunters from Beyond
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: Black talons overhanging a wooden edge. Graphite filter.
Description: Author of horror, Phillip Hastane checks out a bookstore wherein he finds a grotesque imp watching from a corner. He runs to his cousin’s studio only to discover that his cousin has also seen the very same kind of beast.
Blurb: ‘If you could know. what I know, could see what I have seen, you might make something really worth-while out of your weird fiction, Philip.’

Title: Hunting the Deceitful Turkey
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: The smoking barrel of a shotgun. Graphite filter
Description: A turkey fakes an injury to lure a boy away from its nest.
Blurb: She always waited for me, a little piece away, and let on to be resting and greatly fatigued; which was a lie, but I believed it, for I still thought her honest long after I ought to have begun to doubt her, suspecting that this was no way for a high-minded bird to be acting.

Title: The Hyborian Age
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: The hilt and bottom half of an iron sword. Graphite filter.
Description: The fantasy history of the world of Conan the Barbarian.
Blurb: The following age was an epoch of wandering and conquest. Across the history of the world tribes and drifts of tribes move and shift in an everchanging panorama.

Title: Hypnos
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: The tense, staring eye of a man's face. Graphite filter
Description: Through occult study and drugs, two friends delve deeper and deeper into dreams and beyond, until the more experienced of the two passes a metaphysical barrier into unfathomable horror.
Blurb: Of our studies it is impossible to speak, since they held so slight a connexion with anything of the world as living men conceive it.

Title: Ibid
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A human skull. Graphite filter
Blurb:
(“. . . as Ibid says in his famous Lives of the Poets.”
—From a student theme.)
The erroneous idea that Ibid is the author of the Lives is so frequently met with, even among those pretending t...

Title: The Idiot
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: Rusty coins in the palms of someones hands. Graphite filter. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells a story of an ‘idiot’ who helped him in his time of need.
Blurb: For two days I was half starved. On the third day there only remained to me three copecks.

Title: An Idyll of Dandaloo
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A bridled horse racing down a track. Graphite filter.
Description: A Sydney man with his fancy horse comes to race in the small town of Dandaloo and the locals are not happy.
Blurb:
On Western plains, where shade is not,
 ’Neath summer skies of cloudless blue,
Where all is dry and all is hot,
 There stands the town of Dandaloo —

Title: If
Author: Rudyard Kipling
Img_description: A lone man riding away on a horse. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on balance and wisdom.
Blurb: If you can dream—and not make dreams your master; If you can think—and not make thoughts your aim.

Title: If I Were a Man
Author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
Img_description: A man with a suit tipping his hat. Graphite filter.
Description: Mollie Mathewson suddenly finds herself seeing the world through her husband’s eyes, and discovers the perspective of men.
Blurb: ‘Women are pretty much people, seems to me.’

Title: The Illustrious Client
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A general’s young daughter has fallen for a baron whose previous wife died under suspicious circumstances. But the young Violet won’t listen to what anyone says about the baron.
Blurb: “Some people’s affability is more deadly than the violence of coarser souls.”

Title: An Imperial Message
Author: Franz Kafka
Img_description: A letter and fancy, stamped envelope. Graphite Filter.
Description: A man comes from the emperor with a message.
Blurb: If there were an open field, how he would fly along, and soon you would hear the marvellous pounding of his fist on your door.

Title: The Impersonators
Author: C. C. MacApp
Img_description: An outstretched hand gesticulating for someone to stop. Graphite Filter
Description: Inspector Kruger has a difficult time arresting an intergalactic criminal after the wanted man hired 50 shapeshifting slugs to walk around impersonating him.
Blurb: “Damn it,” he said shakily, “you’re the sixth one today!”

Title: Imprisoned With the Pharaohs
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Two of the pyramids of Giza. Graphite filter.
Description: A famous magician travels to Egypt, where he soon finds himself kidnapped and trapped underground. (Ghost-written for Harry Houdini)
Blurb: My hands were tied behind my back, my knees bent to their fullest extent, and my wrists and ankles stoutly linked together with unyielding cords. A stifling gag was forced into my mouth, and a blindfold fastened tightly over my eyes.

Title: In Another Country
Author: Ernest Hemmingway
Img_description: Factory machinery. Graphite filter.
Description: An American soldier in Italy after World War I experiences derision and exclusion from the locals.
Blurb: We only knew then that there was always the war, but that we were not going to it any more.

Title: In Answer to Various Bards
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A bright sunrise over the sea. Graphite filter.
Description: A criticism of the dreary poets who write of corpses and tombs.
Blurb: For it stirs him like a message from his station friends afar — And he seems to sniff the ranges in the scent of wool and tar.

Title: In Defence of the Bush
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A countryman defends the beauty of the country.
Blurb:
Where the sunbaked earth was gasping like a creature in its pain
You would find the grasses waving like a field of summer grain,
And the miles of thirsty gutters blocked with sand and choked with mud,
You would find them mighty rivers with a turbid, sweeping flood;

Title: In Exile
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A stunned looking, moustached man. Graphite filter.
Description: A veteran tries to convince the new exile  how to appreciate the harsh life of Siberia.
Blurb: He is at you about the women, but you spite him; say, ‘I don’t want them!’ He is on at you about freedom, but you stand up to him and say: ‘I don’t want it!’

Title: In the Abyss
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Urchins on the ocean floor. Graphite filter.
Description: After Elstead returns later than expected from a voyage into the deep sea. He announces the discovery of much more than fish and sea-urchins.
Blurb: “You laughed at my explorations, and I’ve discovered a new world!”

Title: In the Avu Observatory
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: eyes in the darkness. Graphite filter.
Description: Woodhouse is beginning his shift at an observatory when, looking through the telescope, something appears to momentarily cover the lens.
Blurb: Suddenly the stars were blotted out. A flash of blackness passed, and they were visible again.

Title: In the Droving Days
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: Three men with wide-brimmed hats riding horses in the outback.
Description: An ex-drover sees an old droving horse being sold at an auction for a pitiful amount.
Blurb:
Straightway the crowd and the auctioneer
Seemed on a sudden to disappear,
Melted away in a kind of haze,
For my heart went back to the droving days.

Title: In the Forest of Villefère
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: A twisting tree. Graphite filter.
Description: A man travelling through a forest meets a masked man who offers to show him the way through.
Blurb:
“A mask!” I exclaimed. “Why do you wear a mask, m’sieu?”
“It is a vow,” he explained. “In fleeing a pack of hounds I vowed that if I escaped I would wear a mask for a certain time.”
“Hounds, m’sieu?”
“Wolves,” he answered quickly; “I said wolves.”

Title: In the Penal Colony
Author: Franz Kafka
Img_description: An assembly of cogs. Graphite Filter.
Description: In a penal colony, a visitor is shown around a torture machine by an officer who is passionate about the local methods of justice.
Blurb: Guilt is always beyond a doubt. Other courts could not follow this principle, for they are made up of many heads and, in addition, have even higher courts above them.

Title: In the Vault
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Drawing of a man with his upper body hanging over a door and reaching out.
Description: An undertaker grows lax in his care for the burial process. Then one day he accidentally locks himself in a vault with several yet-to-be buried coffins and learns to regret having ever disrespected the dead.
Blurb: The undertaker grew doubly lethargic in the bitter weather, and seemed to outdo even himself in carelessness. Never did he knock together flimsier and ungainlier caskets, or disregard more flagrantly the needs of the rusty lock on the tomb door which he slammed open and shut with such nonchalant abandon.

Title: An Incident
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A house cat sitting outside. Graphite filter
Description: The young children, Vanya and Nina are delighted to wake and find out that the cat has had kittens.
Blurb: Vanya and Nina are a long time deciding who is to be the kittens’ father, and, in the end, their choice falls on a big dark-red horse without a tail, which is lying in the store-cupboard under the stairs, together with other relics of toys that have outlived their day.

Title: The Inexperienced Ghost
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Four wine glasses being clinked together. Graphite filter.
Description: Three men of the local club listen to a fourth tell a story of a particularly unthreatening and unhaunting ghost that he claims to have met the night before.
Blurb: Right off I knew him for a ghost. He was transparent and whitish; clean through his chest I could see the glimmer of the little window at the end. And not only his physique but his attitude struck me as being weak.

Title: The Inmost Light
Author: Arthur Machen
Img_description: A bustling city with trams. Graphite Filter.
Description: A man introduces to his old friend a mystery of a missing woman with a potentially supernatural explanation.
Blurb: ‘But it is different in London. You may point out a street, correctly enough, as the abode of washerwomen; but, in that second floor, a man may be studying Chaldee roots, and in the garret over the way a forgotten artist is dying by inches.’

Title: An Inquiry
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: An ink pen in the middle of writing. Graphite filter.
Description: A country man attempts to make an inquiry at a government office.
Blurb: “You give him three roubles,” whispered the porter. — “I’ve given him two already.” — “Give him another.”

Title: The Interlopers
Author: Saki
Img_description: A fallen tree in a forest. Graphite filter.
Description: Two men intent on killing each other meet in the woods, rifles in hand.
Blurb: “When they drag me out from under these damned branches it won’t need much clumsiness on their part to roll this mass of trunk right over on the top of you.”

Title: Into Egypt
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: A speck of a man amongst a vast desert. Graphite filter.
Description: A lieutenant is tasked with the exiling of the ‘Accursed People’ from his nation. Thoughts of sympathy arise in his mind, but are squashed by his military training.
Blurb: As for Willi and himself, they had been friends—yes, even through the first year or so at school. Both of them had meant to run away and be cowboys, and they had had a secret password. Naturally, things had changed, later on.

Title: Invictus
Author: William Ernest Henley
Img_description: A masted ship. Graphite Filter.
Description: A poem on pride and resilience.
Blurb: I thank whatever gods may be - For my unconquerable soul.

Title: The Invisible City
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A man holds aloft a shining, egg-shaped object, dozens of beings with human bodies and elephant-like heads reel back in awe.
Description: Explorers Langley and Furham struggle through the desert searching for the ruins of the city of Kobar, only to come across a city much more fantastical and much, much more uncharted.
Blurb: The depression was bare and empty with no sign of ruins, but was lined with numerous pits that suggested the ground-plan of a vanished city.

Title: The Invisible Girl
Author: Mary Shelley
Img_description: A young woman with braided hair. Graphite filter.
Description: After a rich man discovers that his son and his adopted orphan girl are in love, he casts the girl out.
Blurb: It is burnt by the ghost of a maiden who lost her sweetheart in these parts; he being wrecked, and his body found at the foot of the tower: she goes by the name among us of the ‘Invisible Girl.’

Title: The Invisible Man
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: Two men investigate a piece of armour.
Description: A young woman tells a young man who proposes to her of why she cannot marry anyone.
Blurb: “Not only is your murderer invisible, but he makes invisible also the murdered man.”

Title: Ionitch
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A small hillside town. Graphite Filter.
Description: A doctor arrives for work at a small Russian town and decides to visit the most respected local family. Their small town culture bores him, but he takes a liking to the youthful and energetic daughter, Ekaterina.
Blurb: Before I’d drunk the tears from life’s goblet. . . .

Title: Iron Hans
Author: Brothers Grimm
Img_description: Tall windy trees above a swamp. Graphite filter.
Description: A boy is taken away into the forest by a wild man he frees from a cage. After failing a task set by the wild man he must venture out into a city to find his destiny.
Blurb: And as he still bent down more and more while he was doing so, and trying to look straight into the eyes, his long hair fell down from his shoulders into the water. He raised himself up quickly, but the whole of the hair of his head was already golden and shone like the sun.

Title: The Island of the Fay
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: Rolling, grassy hills. Graphite filter.
Description: A man talks about music and science.
Blurb: In truth, the man who would behold aright the glory of God upon earth must in solitude behold that glory.

Title: The Isle of the Torturers
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A wooden, five-masted sailing ship on the sea. Graphite filter
Description: A plague wipes out the kingdom of Yoros, leaving alive only the king who wears a magical ring that protects him. The king sets off on a voyage to find a new land in which to live.
Blurb: For if once the plague had breathed upon Fulbra, he would bear its subtle contagion always in his flesh; and the contagion would assume its wonted virulence with the ring’s removal.

Title: Italian with Grammar
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A splayed open book. Graphite filter.
Blurb: I found that a person of large intelligence could read this beautiful language with considerable facility without a dictionary, but I presently found that to such a parson a grammar could be of use at...

Title: Italian without a Master
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A splayed open book. Graphite filter.
Blurb: It is almost a fortnight now that I am domiciled in a medieval villa in the country, a mile or two from Florence. I cannot speak the language; I am too old not to learn how, also too busy when I am bu...

Title: Ivy Day in the Committee Room
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: A 20th century city with trams and horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: Political campaigners discuss Irish nationalism.
Blurb: “The working-man is not going to drag the honour of Dublin in the mud to please a German monarch.”

Title: Jack and the Beanstalk
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A solitary, draping vine. Graphite filter
Description: A poor farm boy sells his family’s last possession to a mysterious man in exchange for five beans promised to grow into the very sky.
Blurb: A long long time ago, when most of the world was young and folk did what they liked because all things were good, there lived a boy called Jack.

Title: Jack the Giant-killer
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A bearded man sitting on a throne. Graphite filter.
Blurb: When good King Arthur reigned with Guinevere his Queen, there lived, near the Land’s End in Cornwall, a farmer who had one only son called Jack. Now Jack was brisk and ready; of such a lively wit th...

Title: Jeff Peters as a Personal Magnet
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: A man with a suit and cane, tipping his hat. Graphite filter.
Description: A con-artist starts selling ointments in a town, but has a run in with a constable who says he needs a licence to practice medicine. Determined to run his con the right way, he heads to the mayor’s office to sort it all out.
Blurb: ‘No checks, please, I hate to write my name on the back of a check almost as bad as I do on the front.’

Title: Jerry Bundler
Author: W. W. Jacobs
Img_description: The blurry shadow of a human. Graphite filter.
Description: A group of men talk of ghosts, including a ‘Jerry Bundler’ said to haunt the very house in which they are staying. Two men boast they could dress up as the ghost and give the other a good scare.
Blurb: “A ghost story is a ghost story, sir; but when a gentleman tells a tale of a ghost in the house in which one is going to sleep, I call it most ungentlemanly!”

Title: The Jewess
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A hansom cab. Graphite Filter.
Blurb: “We’ve passed it, pa‑assed it,” a child’s feeble voice rang pitifully. “Right!” shouted an angry bass behind. “To the right, right, r‑r‑right,” gaily and swiftly sounded a chorus in front. Someone gro...

Title: The Jilting of Jane
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A silhouetted man and woman holding eachother in a forest. Graphite filter.
Description: Jane, the servant, falls for a man who is ‘a lot above her’ in station.
Blurb: “William is being led away,” she remarked abruptly, with a catching of the breath, apropos of tablecloths. “Yes, ma’am. She is a milliner, and she can play on the piano.”

Title: Jim Carew
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: Jim Carew, born a man of the town, comes into trouble and is sent away to the outback.
Blurb: Came to grief — was it card or horse? - Nobody asked and nobody cared;

Title: Johnny Pye and the Fool-Killer
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: Pen drawing of a boy fishing in a swirling pool next to a wooden house on stilts.
Description: A young boy’s harsh parents tell him that he’s a fool and the fool-killer will get him someday. So the impressionable lad runs away and spends years trying to find an adult that can make a clever man out of him.
Blurb: For it occurred to him that, if all the doctor’s cleverness got him was being ridden out of town on a rail, he couldn’t be so far away from the Fool-Killer as he thought. And, sure enough, as he was going to sleep that night, he seemed to hear the Fool-Killer’s footsteps coming after him.

Title: Johnson’s Antidote
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: Johnson strives to find a snakebite cure in the outback.
Blurb:
Down along the Snakebite River, where the overlanders camp,
Where the serpents are in millions, all of the most deadly stamp.

Title: Kashtanka
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A fox panting outside in the snow. Graphite filter.
Description: Kashtanka, the dog, gets lost from her drunkard owner and ends up with a new owner who feeds her better and doesn’t beat her. Yet she still finds herself pining for her previous master.
Blurb: From time to time she stopped and, whining and lifting first one chilled paw and then another, tried to make up her mind how it could have happened that she was lost.

Title: Keeping His Promise
Author: Algernon Blackwood
Img_description: A large, ornate bed beneath two glass windows. Graphite filter.
Description: A students furiously studying for his exams is visited by an old friend who appears to be at death’s door.
Blurb: The other made no audible reply, and shuffled so feebly with his feet that Marriott took his arm by way of support. He noticed for the first time that the clothes hung on him with pitiful looseness.

Title: Kew Gardens
Author: Virginia Woolf
Img_description: A woman clutching her face with wide open eyes. Graphite filter.
Blurb: The light fell either upon the smooth, grey back of a pebble, or, the shell of a snail with its brown, circular veins, or falling into a raindrop, it expanded with such intensity of red, blue and yellow the thin walls of water that one expected them to burst and disappear..

Title: The Killers
Author: Ernest Hemmingway
Img_description: A wall clock showing a quarter past seven. Graphite filter.
Description: Two men come into a lunch-room and boss around the server and the lone patron.
Blurb: The cut-off barrels of the shotgun made a slight bulge under the waist of his too tight-fitting overcoat. He straightened his coat with his gloved hands.

Title: The Kiss
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A soldier next to a cannon. Graphite filter.
Description: Ryabovitch is by far the shyest officer in his battalion, with round shoulders and sparse whiskers. But when the local landowner invites the officers for dinner, Ryabovitch receives a startling surprise from one of the young women present.
Blurb: When he woke up the sensations of oil on his neck and the chill of peppermint about his lips had gone, but joy flooded his heart just as the day before.”

Title: The Lady with the Dog
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A kissing man and woman, silhouetted in a forest. Graphite filter. Graphite filter.
Description: An unhappily married man meets a woman walking her dog and falls for her.
Blurb: “That’s only the fashion to say it is dull here. A provincial will live in Belyov or Zhidra and not be dull, and when he comes here it’s ‘Oh, the dulness! Oh, the dust!’ One would think he came from Grenada.”

Title: The Lady, or the Tiger?
Author: Frank Stockton
Img_description: A woman with curly locks in a ball gown by a castle. Graphite filter.
Description: An unchallenged king throws all accused of crime into an arena with two doors, giving them a coin flip chance of death or retribution.
Blurb: When a subject was accused of a crime of sufficient importance to interest the king, public notice was given that on an appointed day the fate of the accused person would be decided in the king’s arena.

Title: The Laidly Worm
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A frog with a blank stare. Graphite filter.
Description: A king remarries to a strange woman. But when the lords at the wedding fawn over the beautiful young princess instead, the new queen curses the young princess.
Blurb: For when her tire-women came to dress her they found coiled up in her bed an awesome dragon, which uncoiled itself and came towards them.

Title: Lamb to the Slaughter
Author: Roald Dahl
Img_description: An oven in a kitchen. Graphite filter.
Description: A woman’s husband admits to her some painful news, she picks up a frozen leg of lamb and delivers some painful news of her own.
Blurb: At that point, Mary Maloney simply walked up behind him and without any pause she swung the big frozen leg of lamb high in the air and brought it down as hard as she could on the back of his head.

Title: The Lancer’s Wife
Author: Jean Richepin
Img_description: Six gunned soldiers near an explosion
Description: Six prisoners remaining from a defeated French army decide to flee and begin the fight again by themselves.
Blurb: “ I mean to go and kill some Prussians; that is all I care about. If you do not wish to do as I do, well and good; only say so at once. I can quite well go by myself”

Title: The Land Ironclads
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Eight soldiers with rifles on a beach facing an explosion. Graphite filter.
Description: Several soldiers in trenches are talking of how they will eventually win the battle when mysterious black fort in the distance seems to move towards them.
Blurb: They crawled to what they judged the edge of the dip and lay regarding the unfathomable dark. For a space they could distinguish nothing, and then a sudden convergence of the search-lights of both sides brought the strange thing out again.

Title: The Land of Counterpane
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson
Img_description: Two toy soldiers in 19th century british uniform. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on children’s toys.
Blurb: And sometimes for an hour or so — I watched my leaden soldiers go,

Title: The Land of Nod
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson
Img_description: A double bed between two tall glass windows. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on dreams
Blurb: But every night I go abroad — Afar into the Land of Nod.

Title: The Last Incantation
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A cloaked woman touching a tree in the sun. Graphite filter.
Description: An old and powerful magician thinks back to his youth, and of the young lover he once lost. He wonders if he, in all his power, could bring her back.
Blurb: But, though these things and the power they held or symbolized were the terror of the peoples and the envy, of all rival magicians, the thoughts of Malygris were dark with immitigable melancholy, and weariness filled his heart as ashes fill the hearth where a great fire has died.

Title: The Last Leaf
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: A maple leaf. Graphite filter.
Description: A young woman is struck with pneumonia, and believes she will go when the last leaf outside her window falls.
Blurb: I’m tired of waiting. I’m tired of thinking. I want to turn loose my hold on everything, and go sailing down, down, just like one of those poor, tired leaves.

Title: The Last of the Flatfeet
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A man in a tux with a hat and cane. Graphite Filter.
Description: A teacher tries to ‘civilise’ a young Indian boy, but the boy has a calling to dance and sing.
Blurb: The Indian Bureau replied in two weeks that his communication had been received and given careful attention; but, inasmuch as it appeared to involve a pig, it had been referred to the Department of Agriculture. The secretary to the secretary to the Secretary of Agriculture wrote Ug that the case had been referred to the Bureau of Animal Husbandry.

Title: The Last Parade
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: The face of a tired, old man. Graphite filter.
Description: Soldiers beg to go home from the war.
Blurb: ‘Have we not done our share?’

Title: Last Week
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A town man is constantly shafted by bushies.
Blurb:
He went for a drive, and he made a start, 
Which should have been made last week, 
For the old horse died of a broken heart; 
So he footed it home and he dragged the cart —

Title: The Last Word
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A 20th century city with trams and horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: A man admits to murder, explaining that he had known the victim since childhood and had seen him in school, in the public, and everywhere else entirely.
Blurb: Yes, gentlemen, I killed him! In vain do you try to obtain for me a medical certificate of temporary aberration. I shall not take advantage of it. I killed him soberly, conscientiously, coldly, without the least regret, fear or hesitation.

Title: The Law Beaters
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A shadow of a pointed gun and a surrendering hand. Graphite filter.
Description: Two men discuss the law while drinking, and compare their past nefarious escapades.
Blurb: “I had a perfect alibi as far as Erskine was concerned, and there was no way of connecting me and Mance. Nobody had ever seen us together.”

Title: Lawkamercyme
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: The face of an old woman with wrinkles. Graphite filter.
Blurb:
There was an old woman, as I’ve heard tell,
She went to the market her eggs for to sell;
She went to the market, all on a market-day,
And she fell asleep on the king’s highway.
There came by a pedlar,...

Title: Lazy Jack
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: a donkey. Graphite filter.
Description: A fable of a boy who can’t do anything right.
Blurb: Once upon a time there was a boy whose name was Jack, and he lived with his mother on a common. They were very poor, and the old woman got her living by spinning, but Jack was so lazy that he would do...

Title: The Leather Funnel
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A saber sword. Graphite filter.
Description: A man visits his mysterious friend who is an avid collector of occult literature and rare artefacts. The friend reveals that he believes sleeping next to the artefacts allows one to see its history in their dreams.
Blurb: “The charlatan is always the pioneer. From the astrologer came the astronomer, from the alchemist the chemist, from the mesmerist the experimental psychologist. The quack of yesterday is the professor of tomorrow.”

Title: A Legend
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: An old man with a long beard and long hair. Graphite filter.
Blurb: The tall, thin, long-haired man, in whose face were so strangely blended the paleness of a life full of starvation and moral impurity and the stern profoundness of inspiration, began to play on his vi...

Title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
Author: Washington Irving
Img_description: A horse and rider in the distance. Graphite Filter
Description: A local legend tells of a headless horseman. But a man comes to the town only interest in the heart of a young woman.
Blurb: I profess not to know how women’s hearts are wooed and won. To me they have always been matters of riddle and admiration.

Title: Leiningen Versus the Ants
Author: Carl Stephenson
Img_description: three ants marching down a branch. Graphite filter.
Description: Leiningen refuses to surrender his plantation to an inexorable army of Brazilian ants.
Blurb: Your obstinacy endangers not only yourself, but the lives of your four hundred workers. You don’t know these ants!

Title: The Leopard Man’s Story
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A lion. Graphite filter. Graphite filter.
Description: The lion-tamer tells a story of deadly revenge in the circus.
Blurb: “And at last one day, sitting in a front seat, he saw what he had waited for. The lion crunched down, and there wasn’t any need to call a doctor.”

Title: Let’s Get Together
Author: Isaac Asimov
Img_description: A man with a hat standing amidst a crowd of walking people. Graphite filter.
Description: Elias Lynn, Chief of the Bureau of Robotics, learns of a plot by the enemy to send ten humanoid robots to infiltrate America, each holding one tenth of a bomb.
Blurb: “It’s going to be up to us to figure out ways and means of telling a humanoid from a human and then finding the humanoids.”

Title: Life is Bitter
Author: William Ernest Henley
Img_description: An old man with grey beard and hair.
Description: A poem on the struggle of life.
Blurb: Let me sleep.

Title: The Lion and the Mouse
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A regal looking lion. Graphite filter..
Description: A small fable about good deeds and karma.
Blurb: A Lion asleep in his lair was waked up by a Mouse running over his face. Losing his temper he seized it with his paw and was about to kill it. The Mouse, terrified, piteously entreated him to spare its life.

Title: A Little Cloud
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: A 20th century city with trams and horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: Thomas Chandler anxiously waits to meet with an old friend who left for London and found success as a journalist while Chandler himself stayed in Dublin.
Blurb: That was Ignatius Gallaher all out; and, damn it, you couldn’t but admire him for it.

Title: A Little Journey
Author: Ray Bradbury
Img_description: A cylindrical rocket blasting through space.
Description: Despite being tricked of her life savings in the past, Mrs. Bellowes truly believes that the charming Mr. Thirkell will make do on his promise of taking her on his rocket ship to see the Lord.
Blurb: This is our rocket. We paid for our trip. And we’re going to take our trip!

Title: The Little Match Girl
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: A ragged girl holding a candle waits outside.
Description: A girl wanders the street with a job to do.
Blurb: Oh! a match might afford her a world of comfort, if she only dared take a single one out of the bundle, draw it against the wall, and warm her fingers by it.

Title: The Little Mermaid
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: Water colour of a mermaid and a prince.
Description: A little mermaid dreams of living among the people on land. But the only way to join them means asking for help from the evil sea witch.
Blurb: When something like a black cloud passed between her and them, she knew that it was either a whale swimming over her head, or a ship full of human beings, who never imagined that a pretty little mermaid was standing beneath them, holding out her white hands towards the keel of their ship.

Title: Little Mother up the Morderberg
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A man sitting on a precipice. Graphite filter.
Description: A young man makes a bet to a group of mountaineers that he could climb their toughest mountain with his mother in tow.
Blurb: “Wouldn’t it be rather a climb, dearest?”

Title: The Little Red Christmas Tree
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A spruce tree in the snow. Graphite filter.
Description: In the future of the 20th century, the Soviet revolution must refrain from eradicating all the bourgeois for fear of ending the revolution by having no one against whom to revolt.
Blurb: Soon they were reckoned at ten, then five⁠—three⁠—two; and finally in all Soviet Russia there remained just one bourgeois. He was a childless widower, Stepan Nilitch Rybkin, a resident of Malaya Zagvozdka, near Gatchino, formerly proprietor of a grocery and poultry store.

Title: Little Red Riding-Hood
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A howling wolf. Graphite filter.
Description: A little girl heads into the woods to visit her grandma, but meets a big bad wolf along the way.
Blurb: “All the better to eat you with, my dear!”

Title: Little Snow-White
Author: Brothers Grimm
Img_description: A fancy silver mirror. Graphite Filter
Description: A queen, obsessed with being the most beautiful in all the land, orders her beautiful step-daughter to be killed.
Blurb: “Looking-glass, Looking-glass, on the wall”

Title: The Loaded Dog
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A black labrador retriver holding a brick-shaped object.
Description: All hell breaks loose when a dopey retriever retrieves the worst thing possible.
Blurb: “Why not blow the fish up in the big water-hole with a cartridge?”

Title: Locked Inside
Author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
Img_description: A wooden door knocker. Graphite filter
Description: A short poem on freedom.
Blurb: She beats upon her bolted door - With faint weak hands.

Title: A Lodging for the Night
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson
Img_description: A brass doorknocker. Graphite Filter.
Description: After a sudden stabbing resulting from a bad bet, a man runs to the streets to look for another place to stay.
Blurb: “I may be dead before morning. Only this once, father, and before God I will never ask again!”

Title: Lost
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A woman tensely clutching her face. Graphite filter.
Description: A boy runs off on one of the family’s horses and gets lost.
Blurb:
The old man walked to the sliprail, and peered up the dark’ning track,
And looked and longed for the rider that would never more come back;

Title: The Lost Inheritance
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Rusty coins in the palms of someones hands. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells the story of what happened to the large inheritance that was meant to fall from his uncle to him.
Blurb: “My uncle,” said the man with the glass eye, “was what you might call a hemi-semi-demi millionaire. He was worth about a hundred and twenty thousand. Quite. And he left me all his money.”

Title: The Lottery Ticket
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A newspaper, mug and glasses on a table. Graphite filter.
Description: A husband’s mind goes wild with imagination at the thought of his wife winning the lottery.
Blurb: And pictures came crowding on his imagination, each more gracious and poetical than the last. And in all these pictures he saw himself well-fed, serene, healthy, felt warm, even hot!

Title: A Love by The Sea
Author: William Ernest Henley
Img_description: A four-masted ship. Graphite filter
Description: A love poem.
Blurb: Black as the cloud of some tremendous spell - The susurration of the sighing sea.

Title: Love of Life
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A jungle of tall, twisting ferns. Graphite filter.
Description: A man is left to find his way out of the Canadian forest on a broken foot.
Blurb: Now and again the wolves, in packs of two and three, crossed his path.

Title: Luck
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: Eight soldiers with rifles on a beach facing an explosion
Description: A clergyman explains the truth behind the success of a famous soldier - blind luck.
Blurb: And there—oh dear, it was awful. Blunders? Why, he never did anything but blunder. But, you see, nobody was in the fellow’s secret—everybody had him focused wrong, and necessarily misinterpreted his performance every time—consequently they took his idiotic blunders for inspirations of genius.

Title: The Lumber Room
Author: Saki
Img_description: A frog staring blankly. Graphite filter.
Description: Young Nicholas is bound at home while his cousins go on a trip due to his know-it-all attitude. Banned from the garden and any fun whatsoever he resolves to sneak into the lumber room to explore.
Blurb: If all the children sinned collectively they were suddenly informed of a circus in a neighbouring town, a circus of unrivalled merit and uncounted elephants, to which, but for their depravity, they would have been taken that very day.

Title: The Lurking Fear
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A gothic, wooden, three storeyed house.
Description: Fifteen villagers are left dead after an apparent lightning strike, but their bodies have signs of lacerations from teeth or claws. A reporter heads to investigate the village and a nearby mansion believed by some to be the source of the terrible happenings.
Blurb: Some said the thunder called the lurking fear out of its habitation, while others said the thunder was its voice.

Title: The Magic Shop
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A suited man with a young boy stand before a leering shopkeeper above a toy tiger and a hand sculpture holding cards.
Description: A father is pulled into a magic shop by his son, where the shopman demonstrates tricks that appear less and less like ‘tricks’ and more and more like genuine miracles.
Blurb: On the floor were magic mirrors; one to draw you out long and thin, one to swell your head and vanish your legs, and one to make you short and fat like a draught; and while we were laughing at these the shopman, as I suppose, came in.

Title: Magnetism
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A sailing ship. Graphite Filter.
Description: A group of men debate the merit of magnetism (mesmerism).
Blurb: The child was quieted, and again he woke up exclaiming that his father was drowned. A month later the news came that his father had, in fact, been swept off the deck of his smack by a billow.

Title: The Major’s Tale
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: Gloved hands resting on its owners dress. Graphite filter.
Description: Bored Union soldiers dress up the youngest orderly in women’s clothing and introduce her to the lieutenant known as a womaniser.
Blurb: Moreover, as most men, whether rakes or not, are willing to be thought rakes, he is very likely to resent a stupid and unjust inference which he suspects you to have drawn from his reticence in the matter of his own adventures—namely, that he has had none.

Title: The Man from Ironbark
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: They eye of an angrily staring man. Graphite filter.
Description: A country man goes to a city barber and doesn’t have a good time.
Blurb:
The barber man was small and flash, as barbers mostly are,
He wore a strike-your-fancy sash, he smoked a huge cigar.

Title: The Man From Snowy River
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: Three men with wide-brimmed hats riding horses in the outback.
Description: A prized, young racehorse escapes into the wild, and so all the best horsemen gather for one glorious chase.
Blurb:
He hails from Snowy River, up by Kosciusko’s side,
Where the hills are twice as steep and twice as rough,
Where a horse’s hoofs strike firelight from the flint stones every stride,
The man that holds his own is good enough.

Title: Man from the South
Author: Roald Dahl
Img_description: A man seen from behind wearing a panama hat. Graphite filter.
Blurb: “Yes. Why not? You win, you take de car. You looss, I take de finger.”

Title: The Man in a Case
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A man in a tuxedo tipping his hat. Graphite Filter.
Description: A schoolteacher tells of a colleague he once had who lived his life as if ‘in a case’.
Blurb: ‘No; marriage is a serious step. One must first weigh the duties before one, the responsibilities . . . that nothing may go wrong afterwards. It worries me so much that I don’t sleep at night’

Title: The Man of the Crowd
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A 20th century city with horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: A man looking out of the window of a coffee shop names the different typical types of people. But he finds an old man whose character he cannot put into a simple box.
Blurb: “The old man,” I said at length, “is the type and the genius of deep crime. He refuses to be alone. He is the man of the crowd. It will be in vain to follow, for I shall learn no more of him, nor of his deeds.”

Title: The Man that Corrupted Hadleyburg
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A letter with a wax seal. Graphite filter.
Description: The town of Hadleyburg is considered to be uncorruptible, and it’s citizens perfectly honest. But a man who finds himself offended by one of it’s people, sets out to prove them wrong.
Blurb: “God knows I never had shade nor shadow of a doubt of my petrified and indestructible honesty until now—and now, under the very first big and real temptation, I—Edward, it is my belief that this town’s honesty is as rotten as mine is; as rotten as yours.”

Title: The Man Who Could Imitate a Bee
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A sketch of a party of six people sitting together with a man in the middle with pursed lips as if whistling.
Description: A young scientist stoops to cheap comedy to gain the interest of a girl and her peers, but the attention quickly turns sour for the young man.
Blurb: Lying in his bed that night the brain of Hervey Deyo entertained two thoughts. One was that Miss Low was a singularly charming girl; the other was he could not interest her by birds alone.

Title: The Man Who Could Work Miracles
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A lit candle.
Description: The cynical and argumentative George McWhirter Fotheringay, when in the midst of arguing that miracles are impossible, accidentally performs one.
Blurb: He pointed resolutely to his candle and collected his mind, though he felt he did a foolish thing. “Be raised up,” he said. But in a second that feeling vanished. The candle was raised, hung in the air one giddy moment, and as Mr. Fotheringay gasped, fell with a smash on his toilet-table, leaving him in darkness save for the expiring glow of its wick.

Title: The Man Who Was Away
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A woman talks of where all her children have gone off to.
Blurb:
The widow sought the lawyer’s room with children three in tow,
She told the lawyer man her tale in tones of deepest woe.
Said she, ‘My husband took to drink for pains in his inside,
‘And never drew a sober breath from then until he died.

Title: The Man With the Twisted Lip
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Holmes, discovered by Watson in a surprising location, tells of the missing Neville St. Clair spotted by his wife in an opium den.
Blurb: “But it is better to learn wisdom late than never to learn it at all.”

Title: The Man with the Watches
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A fancy, analog watch. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator tells of a murder mystery which caused much speculation in the public where three people disappeared from a train and a dead man appeared from nowhere.
Blurb: Who he was, whence he had come, and how he had met his end were each as great a mystery as what had occurred to the three people who had started an hour and a half before from Willesden in those two compartments.

Title: A Man with Two Lives
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: Cliffs in the fog. Graphite filter.
Description: A soldier finds himself trapped by hostiles in a dead-end.
Blurb: I had not gone a hundred yards before I reached the limit of my run—the head of the gulch which I had mistaken for a canyon.

Title: The Mantle
Author: Nikolai Gogol
Img_description: A man by a horse-drawn hansom in the snow.
Description: A low ranking councillor must dig deep to spend half of his yearly earnings to buy a new coat, lest he die from cold.
Blurb: All that was indecisive and vague in his gait and gestures had disappeared. A new fire began to gleam in his eyes, and in his bold dreams he sometimes even proposed to himself the question whether he should not have a marten-fur collar made for his coat.

Title: The Mark on the Wall
Author: Virginia Woolf
Img_description: A vine-overgrown window. Graphite Filter
Description: A woman notices a mark on her wall. The innocuous thing sends her on a trail of thought into philosophy.
Blurb: Why, if one wants to compare life to anything, one must liken it to being blown through the Tube at fifty miles an hour–landing at the other end without a single hairpin in one’s hair! Shot out at the feet of God entirely naked!

Title: Markheim
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson
Img_description: A small, round, framed, antique mirror. Graphite filter.
Description: A man attempts to rob a store after attacking the owner, but finds out there is someone else inside watching him.
Blurb: In many rich mirrors, some of home design, some from Venice or Amsterdam, he saw his face repeated and repeated, as it were an army of spies; his own eyes met and detected him; and the sound of his own steps, lightly as they fell, vexed the surrounding quiet.

Title: The Masque of the Red Death
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: An expresionless carnival mask. Graphite filter.
Description: When a plague ravages a city, a rich prince invites all the well-to-dos to take sanctuary in his castle where they party and revel as though nothing ever changed.
Blurb: The mask which concealed the visage was made so nearly to resemble the countenance of a stiffened corpse that the closest scrutiny must have had difficulty in detecting the cheat.

Title: A May Night
Author: Nikolai Gogol
Img_description: A hand weakly poking out of the water, Graphite filter.
Description: Levko seeks Hanna’s hand in marriage despite his fathers lack of blessing.
Blurb: Old women say that when the moon shines, all those who have been drowned come out to warm themselves in its rays, and that they are led by the witch’s stepdaughter.

Title: The Maze of the Enchanter
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A woman clutching her face with a blank expression. Graphite filter
Description: Young hunter Tiglari ventures into the deadly maze of the enchanter to rescue his beloved Athle.
Blurb: About him he saw the heavy-hooded blossoms that leaned from a winy gloom in venomous languour, or fawned toward him with open corollas that exhaled a narcotic perfume or diffused a pollen of madness.

Title: Measles
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A man with a suit and cane, tipping his hat.
Blurb:
I
It was before dinner and Dr. Iliashenko had just finished bathing with a student named Voskresenski. The warm, southeast wind had whipped the sea into eddies. Close to the shore, the water was murky...

Title: Mechanical Justice
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: Many interconnected gears. Graphite filter.
Description: A university professor demonstrates his new invention to solve all resentment to corporal discipline, an automated flogging machine!
Blurb: A fine-looking attendant came forward and took off the canvas cover from the strange object standing at the footlights. To the eyes of those present, the bright gleaming machine was rather like an automatic weighing-machine, though it was obviously more complex and was much larger.

Title: Memoirs of a Madman
Author: Nikolai Gogol
Img_description: A man intensely staring, Graphite filter.
Description: Poprishchin, lacking in prestige and romantic success, slowly delves into insanity through his memoirs.
Blurb: “I think that it is one of the most refined joys of this world to interchange thoughts, feelings, and impressions.”

Title: Memory
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A jungle of tall, twisting ferns. Graphite filter
Description: In a valley, where ruins of old buildings are covered in moss, a Genie asks a Daemon who built these long-gone buildings.
Blurb: In the valley of Nis the accursed waning moon shines thinly, tearing a path for its light with feeble horns through the lethal foliage of a great upas-tree.

Title: Mesmeric Revelation
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A candle in the darkness. Graphite filter.
Description: A mesmerist questions a knowledgeable but dying man on all the workings of the universe.
Blurb: The result of law inviolate is perfection-right-negative happiness. The result of law violate is imperfection, wrong, positive pain.

Title: The Mice and the Weasels
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A mouse poking out from behind some wood. Graphite filter.
Description: The mice change their tactics in the war against the weasels.
Blurb: There was war between the Mice and the Weasels, in which the Mice always got the worst of it, numbers of them being killed and eaten by the Weasels. So they called a council of war, in which an old Mo...

Title: The Middle Toe of the Right Foot
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A gothic looking house. Graphite filter.
Description: Four men meet at an abandoned house for what appears to be a duel to the death, but it’s not the knives they wield that causes the harm that follows.
Blurb: Each combatant took a knife, examined it critically near the candle and tested the strength of the blade and handle across his lifted knee.

Title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A bucket being carried by someone in a dress. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on getting ahead of yourself.
Blurb: A farmer’s daughter had been out to milk the cows, and was returning to the dairy carrying her pail of milk upon her head. As she walked along, she fell a-musing after this fashion: “The milk in this ...

Title: The Miller, His Son, and Their Ass
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A donkey. Graphite filter.
Description: A miller and his son take their donkey to the market, trying their best to appease everyone on their way.
Blurb: A Miller, accompanied by his young Son, was driving his Ass to market in hopes of finding a purchaser for him. On the road they met a troop of girls, laughing and talking, who exclaimed, “Did you ever...

Title: Misery
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A hansom cab. Graphite Filter.
Description: A cab driver searches for anyone to sympathise with him.
Blurb: If Iona’s heart were to burst and his misery to flow out, it would flood the whole world, it seems, but yet it is not seen.

Title: Miss Harriet
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A hand delicately holding a paintbrush. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells a story of an older woman he met while travelling the countryside. She tends to keep to herself, but upon the man showing her one of his paintings, asks to see him paint.
Blurb: In her eye there lurked a species of insanity, an insanity at once mystical and violent; and even more, a fever, an aggravated longing, impatient and impotent, for the unattained and unattainable.

Title: Miss Winchelsea’s Heart
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A letter and a sheet of paper. Graphite filter
Description: On a trip to Rome, Miss Winchelsea meets a charming young man. But an unfortunate fact about him that comes to reveal itself destroys all of her interest in him.
Blurb: Miss Winchelsea was going to Rome. The matter had filled her mind for a month or more, and had overflowed so abundantly into her conversation that quite a number of people who were not going to Rome, had made it a personal grievance against her.

Title: The Model Millionaire
Author: Oscar Wilde
Img_description: A pair of hands holding some rusty coins. Graphite filter.
Description: Hughie is friendly and well-liked, but a very bad entrepreneur. And his true love’s father will only allow him to marry his daughter if he can make £10,000.
Blurb: He was as popular with men as he was with women, and he had every accomplishment except that of making money.

Title: Molly Whuppie and The Double-faced Giant
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A golden ring. Graphite filter.
Description: Three daughters, abandoned by their parents have multiple run-ins with a violent giant.
Blurb:
“Fee-fi-fo-fum,
I smell the smell of some earthly one.”
“Don’t put yourself about, my dear,”

Title: The Monkey’s Paw
Author: W. W. Jacobs
Img_description: A mummified hand. Graphite filter.
Description: A family come upon a monkey’s paw said to grant three wishes, but with a cost.
Blurb: The first man had his three wishes. Yes, - I don’t know what the first two were, but the third was for death.

Title: The Monster Maker
Author: Ray Bradbury
Img_description: A misty planet.
Description: Hathaway and Marnagan’s ship is hit by an asteroid and they crash land on a planet. Hathaway suspects that the asteroid was sent by the infamous space pirate Gunther.
Blurb: There was nothing but stars, twisted wreckage, cold that pierced through his vac-suit, and silence. He wriggled out of the wreckage into that silence.

Title: Monte Carlo
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: Playing cards splayed out over a table. Graphite filter.
Description: The author lambasts the gambling culture of Monte Carlo.
Blurb: However, one insane idea never forsakes any one of them: “The roulette has laws of its own!” It is only necessary to discover the key to them. And so these lunatics sit whole days through, combining numbers, multiplying them by one another, extracting their square roots.

Title: The Moon of Skulls
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Drawing of a white man and a black man fighting as they fall from a rickety bridge.
Description: Solomon Kane follows the trail of an English girl kidnapped and sold to the Barbary pirates. But he finds much more than mere slave traders on his journey.
Blurb: This could be no other than she whose crimes had become almost mythical—Nakari of Negari, demon queen of a demon city, whose monstrous lust for blood had set half a continent shivering.

Title: The Moon-Bog
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: The full moon. Graphite filter
Description: The narrator meets his friend Denys Barry, who has bought back and restored an ancestral castle in Ireland. He has ambitions to clear away a nearby bog from his new lands but the locals refuse to help him, citing tales of a curse.
Blurb: There were tales of dancing lights in the dark of the moon, and of chill winds when the night was warm; of wraiths in white hovering over the waters, and of an imagined city of stone deep down below the swampy surface.

Title: The Moonlit Road
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A woman clutching her face with wide open eyes. Graphite filter.
Description: A night in which a murder took place is recounted three times, once by the son, once by the father, and once by the mother.
Blurb: I may spare myself the details; it was my poor mother, dead of strangulation by human hands!

Title: The Most Dangerous Game
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A drawing of a man in safari gear smoking a cigarrete under a tree in which a man hides.
Description: A marooned sailor considers himself lucky to find a house on the island, only to discover he may have been better off drowning at sea.
Blurb: Hunting tigers ceased to interest me some years ago. I exhausted their possibilities, you see. No thrill left in tigers, no real danger. I live for danger, Mr. Rainsford.

Title: The Moth
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A moth perched with open wings. Graphite filter.
Description: Hapley and Pawkins are heavy in a dispute about the existence of a certain breed of moth.
Blurb: In his private thoughts Hapley could not forgive Pawkins for dying. In the first place, it was a mean dodge to escape the absolute pulverisation Hapley had in hand for him, and in the second, it left Hapley’s mind with a queer gap in it.

Title: A Mother
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: A 20th century city with trams and horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: Mrs. Kearney’s daughter is hired for a concert ran by the “Eire Abu” society. But things don’t go to plan.
Blurb: Mr Holohan, assistant secretary of the Eire Abu Society, had been walking up and down Dublin for nearly a month, with his hands and pockets full of dirty pieces of paper, arranging about the series of...

Title: A Mother of Monsters
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A corset being tightened from the back. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells of a a woman who sells her unfortunate children.
Blurb: “They tell me that your last child is just like an ordinary child, that he does not resemble his brothers at all.”

Title: A Mountain Station
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: cattle grazing by a fence on a hillside. Graphite filter.
Description: A man struggles to run a mountain farm.
Blurb: I’ve tried to make expenses meet - But wasted all my labours - The sheep the dingoes didn’t eat - Were stolen by the neighbours.

Title: The Mourner
Author: Mary Shelley
Img_description: A rocky, flowing creek. Graphite filter.
Description: Upon finding a grave, a man tells his fiance a story of a young girl he knew as a child.
Blurb: Ellen was more miserable than the imagination of one like you, dear girl, unacquainted with woe, can portray.

Title: The Mouse
Author: Saki
Img_description: A mouse poking out from behind some wood. Graphite filter.
Description: A man is forced to discreetly undress on a public train to rid a mouse that has wandered up his clothes.
Blurb: Furtive stamps and shakes and wildly directed pinches failed to dislodge the intruder, whose motto, indeed, seemed to be Excelsior.

Title: Mr. and Mrs. Vinegar
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: Little fragments of shattered glass. Graphite filter.
Description: Mr. and Mrs. Vinegar must go out and find some fortune after their tiny pickle-jar house breaks. Mr. vinegar proves himself optimistic, but foolish along the way.
Blurb: “I will take the door of the house with me, lovey,” quoth Mr. Vinegar stoutly. “Then no one will be able to open it, will they?”

Title: Mr. Braddy’s Bottle
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: Wine being poured into a glass. Graphite Filter.
Description: Hugh Braddy has never stood up for himself, until one day he is convinced to be more decisive in life.
Blurb: Then, with the air of a man whose mind is made up, Hugh Braddy said a decisive and remarkable thing. - “Mr. Bill Lum,” he said, “I’m going to get drunk!”

Title: Mr. Brisher’s Treasure
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A detailed, silver box. Graphite filter
Description: Mr Brisher tells the narrator of how, while digging in the garden of his engaged’s family’s house, he discovered a chest full of coins. Worried that the father of the house would hand it over to the police, he plans to escape with it all himself.
Blurb: ‘Treasure,’ I kep’ whisperin’ to myself, ‘Treasure’ and ‘’undreds of pounds, ’undreds, ’undreds of pounds.’

Title: Mr. Fox
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A man tipping his hat. Graphite filter.
Description: Lady Mary’s dashing, betrothed Mr. Fox never lets her see the castle he boasts about owning, so she goes to see it herself and finds out the dastardly truth.
Blurb: Lady Mary was young and Lady Mary was fair, and she had more lovers than she could count on the fingers of both hands.

Title: Mr. Ledbetter’s Vacation
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: An open window. Graphite filter.
Description: After an exciting conversation with a strange man about the decline of adventure in the world, Mr. Ledbetter gets into his mind the idea of finally doing something risky for once and decides to burgle a nearby house.
Blurb: “The burglar,” he said, “is the only true adventurer left on earth. Think of his single-handed fight—against the whole civilised world!”

Title: Mr. Skelmersdale in Fairyland
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A woman prancing away through a forest in a flowing, white dress. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator tries to fish out from the Mr. Skelmersdale his notorious story of being taken away by fairies, but the man refuses to talk. Perhaps because people make fun of him, or perhaps for some other reason entirely.
Blurb: “There’s a man in that shop,” said the Doctor, “who has been in Fairyland.”

Title: Mrs. Packletide’s Tiger
Author: Saki
Img_description: A goat standing with rope around its neck. Graphite filter.
Description: Mrs. Packletide endeavours to hunt a tiger and bring it back to her house as a rug sheerly to make jealous a woman that irritates her.
Blurb: In a world that is supposed to be chiefly swayed by hunger and by love Mrs. Packletide was an exception; her movements and motives were largely governed by dislike of Loona Bimberton.

Title: The Murderer
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A housecat sitting outside. Graphite filter.
Description: A troubled man tells erratically of how he had to put down an injured cat.
Blurb: And he did begin in a low, exaggeratedly even tone, but with so many pauses between the words and such curious shudders in his voice that he was clearly keeping back, only with the greatest difficulty, his inner emotion and sorrow.

Title: The Murders in the Rue Morgue
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A screaming woman clutching her face. Graphite filter.
Description: When amateur detective C. Auguste Dupin finds out that an old friend has been arrested for a famous double murder, he takes it upon himself to find the real culprit.
Blurb: “Coincidences, in general, are great stumbling-blocks in the way of that class of thinkers who have been educated to know nothing of the theory of probabilities.”

Title: The Musgrave Ritual
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Holmes recounts of a friend coming to him with a mystery involving a century old riddle, a missing butler, and a hysterical maid.
Blurb: His clothes, his watch, and even his money were in his room, but the black suit which he usually wore was missing. His slippers, too, were gone, but his boots were left behind. Where then could butler Brunton have gone in the night, and what could have become of him now?

Title: The Music of Erich Zann
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Drawing of two men in a garret room, one playing the cello near an open window.
Description: A student lodges underneath an old man and hears extraordinary music coming from upstairs. When the student asks the old man if he could hear the music in person, the old man panics and tells the student to move to a lower floor out of earshot of the music.
Blurb: Thereafter I heard Zann every night, and although he kept me awake, I was haunted by the weirdness of his music.

Title: My Favourite Murder
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A cloth sack. Graphite filter.
Description: Arguing to a judge that there a worse murders than the one of which he is accused, a man recounts one of his other, previous murders.
Blurb: This fair offer he rejected, and I then perceived that it would be better and more satisfactory if he were dead.

Title: My First Aeroplane
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A small propellor plane flying away from an explosion. Graphite filter.
Description: An adventurous man with his head in the clouds finally convinces his mother to let him order one of those new ‘Aeroplanes’. All the instructors are booked out, but the man is sure he can figure out how it works and become the first of his town to fly.
Blurb: Perhaps I did bowl a few people over; but progress is progress.

Title: My Shadow
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson
Img_description: A boy with a wide grin. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on one’s shadow.
Blurb: For he sometimes shoots up taller like an india-rubber ball — And he sometimes gets so little that there's none of him at all.

Title: My Uncle Jules
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: An old man with a long beard and long hair. Graphite Filter.
Description: The poverty-stricken Davranche family holds out hope that an estranged uncle will return from America with a large fortune, after they received a letter saying he had turned his life around and would repay his debts to the father.
Blurb: When my fortune is made I shall return to Havre. I hope that it will not be too long and that we shall all live happily together . . .

Title: The Mystery of Dave Regan
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: The face of a moustached man. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator meets Dave Regan in the bush, a man who is famous for turning up after being declared dead.
Blurb: “Dave used to die oftener than any other bushman I knew. He was always being reported dead and turnin’ up again.”

Title: The Mystery of Marie Rogêt
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: Looking out onto a jungle island from a small boat. Graphite filter.
Description: Amateur detective C. Auguste Dupin investigates the murder of Marie Rogêt, whose body was found in the river Seine.
Blurb: “Yet experience has shown, and a true philosophy will always show, that a vast, perhaps the larger portion of truth, arises from the seemingly irrelevant.”

Title: The Nameless City
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A cave with a shaft of light coming in from above. Graphite filter
Description: An explorer finds a city in the desert with an underground cavern wherein lies mysteries of unfathomable antiquity.
Blurb: “That is not dead which can eternal lie, - And with strange aeons even death may die.”

Title: The Nameless Offspring
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A drawing of two people looking at a sleeping man as a han pokes through a hole in the world.
Description: On a trip of discovery to his place of birth in England, Henry Chaldane happens upon his father’s old friend’s house. But surrounding this house are stories of a terrible, hidden child.
Blurb: We passed several doors which were doubtless those of bed-chambers. All were closed, and one of the doors was re-enforced with iron bars, heavy and sinister as those of a dungeon cell.

Title: The Naval Treaty
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Percy Phelps writes to Holmes and Watson for help after losing an important treaty from his office that could have major political implications.
Blurb: Without going into details, I may say that it defined the position of Great Britain towards the Triple Alliance, and fore-shadowed the policy which this country would pursue in the event of the French fleet gaining a complete ascendancy over that of Italy in the Mediterranean..

Title: The Necklace
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A necklace with a large diamond. Graphite filter.
Description: Mathilde who has lived a life of poverty, borrows a necklace from a wealthy friend to attend a ministry ball.
Blurb: There’s nothing more humiliating than to look poor among other women who are rich.

Title: The New Accelerator
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A chemistry beaker with some liquid inside. Graphite filter
Description: A man meets with his eccentric, genius inventor friend, Professor Giberne, who has invented a new drug. They both agree to give it a try together.
Blurb: “And in this precious phial is the power to think twice as fast, move twice as quickly, do twice as much work in a given time as you could otherwise do.”

Title: The New Catacomb
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A brick wall. Graphite filter.
Description: Two archaeologists, Kennedy and Burger argue over Burger’s discovery of a new catacomb. Burger will only give up his secret if Kennedy tells him the story behind his scandalous affair with Miss Saunderson.
Blurb: My dear fellow, you can remember that the apple you stole from your neighbour’s tree was always sweeter than that which fell from your own.

Title: The Night Came Slowly
Author: Kate Chopin
Img_description: A maple leaf, still attached. Graphite Filter
Description: The narrator ponders nature and men while sitting underneath a maple tree.
Blurb: Some one has said it is better to study one man than ten books. I want neither books nor men.

Title: A Night in Malnéant
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A spired building. Graphite filter
Description: A man grieving over his lost lover finds himself in a peculiar city built entirely around preparing for her funeral.
Blurb: The gray mists and the grayer houses were full of the menace of memory: they were like traitorous tombs from which the cadavers of dead hours poured forth to assail me with envenomed fangs and talons.

Title: The Night-Born
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A young woman with braided hair. Graphite Filter.
Description: A man tells of meeting a white woman amongst the Indians in the Great Up North, and her story of how she came to be there.
Blurb: ‘And for the first time in my life, it seemed to me, I went to bed happy that night, looking out under a corner of the canvas at the stars cut off black by a big shoulder of mountain, and listening to the night-noises, and knowing that the same thing would go on next day and forever and ever, for I wasn’t going back.’

Title: The Nightingale
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: A man with a long moustache lies in a bed as a skeleton with a crowd looks down on him. A little bird sits by his side.
Description: The emperor of China lives in a palace that is a wonder of the world. But one day he finds out that visitors are more amazed by a tiny singing nightingale than his glorious house.
Blurb: “I will hear the nightingale, she must be here this evening; she has my highest favor; and if she does not come, the whole court shall be trampled upon after supper is ended.”

Title: The Ninth Skeleton
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A round gravestone in the grass. Graphite filter
Description: On the way to meet with his lover in ridge of pines, a man finds the sky and the trees turning grotesque, and footprints too slender to be human.
Blurb: All was airless and silent; there were no birds, no insects, no sighing of the pines, no lisping of leaves: a baleful and preternatural silence, like the silence of the infinite void.

Title: Nix Naught Nothing
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A giant, bearded man with a sword and a fur coat. Graphite filter.
Blurb: Once upon a time there lived a King and a Queen who didn’t differ much from all the other kings and queens who have lived since Time began. But they had no children, and this made them very sad indeed...

Title: No Place for a Woman
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A lone horserider staring off into the sky. graphite filter.
Description: The farmer “Ratty Howlett” has made a name for himself chasing down travellers who pass by his lonely location. The narrator finds himself caught and dragged into a conversation, but is surprised to hear that the man has a wonderful wife back at his farm.
Blurb: I was surprised to hear of a wife, for I thought he was a hatter—I had always heard so; but perhaps I had been mistaken, and he had married lately; or had got a housekeeper.

Title: Nobody’s Story
Author: Charles Dickens
Img_description: An old, bearded man. Graphite filter.
Description: A hard-working man’s life begins to turn for the worse after the ‘Bigwigs’ start focusing on the wrong things.
Blurb: He was one of an immense family, all of whose sons and daughters gained their daily bread by daily work, prolonged from their rising up betimes until their lying down at night. Beyond this destiny he had no prospect, and he sought none.

Title: The North Wind and the Sun
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A cloud in the sky. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable about working smarter not harder.
Blurb: A dispute arose between the North Wind and the Sun, each claiming that he was stronger than the other. At last they agreed to try their powers upon a traveller, to see which could soonest strip him of his cloak.

Title: The Nose
Author: Nikolai Gogol
Img_description: A man covering his nose with his hand, Graphite filter
Description: Ivan Jakovlevitch wakes up to find a dismembered nose in his bread. Meanwhile somewhere else in the St Petersburg, Major Kovaloff wakes to find something missing.
Blurb: A carriage drew up at the entrance; the carriage door was opened, and a gentleman in uniform came out and hurried up the steps. How great was Kovaloff’s terror and astonishment when he saw that it was his own nose!

Title: The Nothing Equation
Author: Tom Godwin
Img_description: Drawing of a man curled up in the foetal position on the floor of a futuristic building.
Description: A man is sent to an observatory in the midst of another galaxy for a six month mission. The problem... The past two explorers were driven insane with nothing as an explanation.
Blurb: You feel it watching you and you hear it trying to get in to kill you. One time I bumped the wall and—for God’s sake—take me away from it—take me back to Earth ...

Title: The Novel of the White Powder
Author: Arthur Machen
Img_description: A strange elixir in a glass vial. Graphite Filter.
Description: A woman tries to pull her studious brother away from his desk and into society, but there is an unintentional and unsettling change in his character as a result.
Blurb: There was a look in his eyes that I had never yet seen, and the thought flashed across my mind that it was a look that was scarcely human.

Title: Nyarlathotep
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: An old man with a long beard and long hair. Graphite filter
Description: A man appears in a world of distress and upheaval, amassing followers and causing nightmares.
Blurb: He said he had risen up out of the blackness of twenty-seven centuries, and that he had heard messages from places not on this planet.

Title: The Oblong Box
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A wooden, five-masted sailing ship on the sea. Graphite filter.
Description: While perusing the list of other passengers on a voyage to New York, a man notes that his friend, his friend is to take the boat along with his two sisters and wife. But for some reason, they have booked enough rooms for six.
Blurb: They were sounds occasioned by the artist in prying open the oblong box, by means of a chisel and mallet- the latter being apparently muffled, or deadened, by some soft woollen or cotton substance in which its head was enveloped.

Title: An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A rocky creek in a forest.
Description: A confederate soldier is sentenced to death upon a bridge and thinks of his life.
Blurb: As these thoughts, which have here to be set down in words, were flashed into the doomed man’s brain rather than evolved from it the captain nodded to the sergeant. The sergeant stepped aside.

Title: An Offering to the Moon
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: Drawing of a womans face in front of the moon shining through the clouds.
Description: Morley and his assistant Thorway are investigating ruins theorised to belong to the ancient civilisation of the lost continent Mu. Morley begins to have odd visions of the past.
Blurb: Morley could not have told what it was that he felt and saw in that moment. He was no longer his known and wonted self; and the man beside him was an unheeded stranger.

Title: Oh! The Public
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A train crossing a bridge and puffing smoke. Graphite filter
Description: A ticket collector repeatedly tries to clear his name after offending an arthritic man in front of the public, only to make it worse and worse.
Blurb: “Oh, the public! There’s no satisfying them! It’s no use working and doing one’s best! One’s driven to drinking and cursing it all. . . . If you do nothing — they’re angry; if you begin doing your duty, they’re angry too. There’s nothing for it but drink!”

Title: O’Halloran’s Luck
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: A freckled hand holding a shamrock/clover outside. Graphite filter
Description: Tim O’Halloran has never had much help from the luck of the Irish since his immigration to America, until one day he rescues an unexpected little man from being eaten by wolves in the forest.
Blurb: “By faith and belief, but it is a leprechaun!” cried O’Halloran, and with that he made a grab for the apparition. For you must know, in case you’ve been ill brought up, that a leprechaun is a sort of cobbler fairy and each one knows the whereabouts of a pot of gold.

Title: The Old Australian Ways
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: Three men with wide-brimmed hats riding horses in the outback.
Description: A poem on a new Australian identity.
Blurb: The narrow ways of English folk — Are not for such as we;

Title: Old Bugs
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Whiskey pouring into a glass. Graphite filter.
Description: Old Bugs, a drunkard who works for drink by cleaning in a Pool Room, where he occasionally snaps at customers, warning them off drinking. One day when a young man walks in for a drink, something about this particular customer sets him off.
Blurb: “He shall not drink! He shall not drink!”

Title: The Old City Of Marseilles
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A guitar being played by elderly hands. Graphite filter.
