Description: A man talks of the sinful but beautiful night-life of Marseilles, and of an amazing, mysterious guitarist that he once had the grace of hearing play.
Blurb: The women first, and then all the other visitors after them, got up from their places and surrounded the recumbent old man. From a neighboring dive came the sounds of a concertina harmonica. Someone tiptoed up to the door and closed it without a sound.

Title: The Old Man of the Sea
Author: W. W. Jacobs
Img_description: A cigar being lit over a sleek lighter.
Description: Mr. George Wright asks an old sailor to pose as his rich uncle, therefore raising his chances of taking the hand in marriage of the young Miss Bradshaw.
Blurb: “it’s your game, not mine, and it’s sure to come a bit expensive. I can’t be a rich uncle without spending a bit. ’Ow much did you say you’d got in the bank?”

Title: Old Pardon, the Son of Reprieve
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A bridled horse racing down a track. Graphite filter.
Description: Prized racehorse ‘Pardon’ wins and wins and wins until they come against the foul players of the more prestigious races.
Blurb: For weight wouldn’t stop him, nor distance - Nor odds, though the others were fast - He’d race with a dogged persistence - And wear them all down at the last.

Title: Old Pipes and the Dryad
Author: Frank Stockton
Img_description: Rolling hills. Graphite filter.
Description: Old Pipes has grown to weak to call the cattle down from the hill, but when he rescues a dryad from within a tree she decides to help him out.
Blurb: This was that a kiss from a Dryad made a person ten years younger. The people of the village knew this, and they were very careful not to let any child of ten years or younger go into the woods where the Dryads were supposed to be; for if they should chance to be kissed by one of these tree-nymphs, they would be set back so far that they would cease to exist.

Title: The Old Woman and Her Pig
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: The face of an old woman with wrinkles. Graphite filter.
Description: After her little pig refuses to move into the stile, an old woman seeks help.
Blurb: “Water won’t quench fire; fire won’t burn stick; stick won’t beat dog; dog won’t bite pig; pig won’t get over the stile; and I shan’t get home till midnight.”

Title: On Kiley’s Run
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A shed on a plains, under a hill and by a river. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator tells of the lively community of workers on Kiley’s run, and how it has changed since being taken over by an overseas owner.
Blurb:
And far away one dimly sees
Beyond the stretch of forest trees —
Beyond the foothills dusk and dun —
The ranges sleeping in the sun.

Title: One of the Missing
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: Broken wood rubble.
Description: A Union scout finds himself underneath rubble with his own gun pointed at his head.
Blurb: When Jerome Searing recovered consciousness he did not at once understand what had occurred. It was, indeed, some time before he opened his eyes. For a while he believed that he had died and been buried, and he tried to recall some portions of the burial service.

Title: Only a Jockey
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A striped jockey on a racehorse. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator vents on the unjust disregard for the life of a young jockey.
Blurb: Fourteen years old, and what was he taught of it? - What did he know of God’s infinite grace?

Title: The Open Boat
Author: Stephen Crane
Img_description: Looking out onto a jungle island from a small boat. Graphite filter.
Description: Four men in a dinghy wait at sea for rescue.
Blurb: “If this old ninny-woman, Fate, cannot do better than this, she should be deprived of the management of men’s fortunes. She is an old hen who knows not her intention. If she has decided to drown me, why did she not do it in the beginning and save me all this trouble?”

Title: The Open Steeplechase
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A bridled horse racing down a track. Graphite filter.
Description: A country boy and his country horse join in the open steeplechase in the big city.
Blurb:
All ablazing with impatience, with excitement all aglow;
Before us like a ribbon stretched the steeplechasing track,
And the sun-rays glistened brightly on the chestnut and the black
As the starter’s words came slowly, ‘Are — you — ready? Go!’

Title: The Open Window
Author: Saki
Img_description: An open window overlooking a misty outdoors. Graphite filter.
Description: Framtom Nuttel is meeting a local woman when her niece tells him of how her aunt’s husband and brothers died in a tragic accident and that she acts as though it never happened and they’ll be back any day.
Blurb: Poor aunt always thinks that they will come back someday, they and the little brown spaniel that was lost with them, and walk in at that window just as they used to do.

Title: The Orator
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A gravestone. Graphite filter.
Description: Grigory, renowned for his moving speeches at weddings and funerals, is asked with haste to help out at a funeral that needs a good speaker. Grigory agrees and improvises a marvellous speech at the funeral, only to realise he messed up one small detail...
Blurb: “Put on your hat and coat this minute and come along. One of our fellows is dead, we are just sending him off to the other world, so you must do a bit of palavering by way of farewell to him. . .”

Title: The Other Gods
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: The full moon. Graphite filter
Description: Barzai the Wise and his disciple Atal scale the tallest peak of the mountains where Earth’s gods sometimes appear.
Blurb: “Barzai will behold the gods, the proud gods, the secret gods, the gods of earth who spurn the sight of men!”

Title: Our New Horse
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A bridled horse racing down a track. Graphite filter.
Description: A group of men decide to sell their aging racehorse. They claim it to be a young race maiden to fetch a good price.
Blurb:
‘We’ll call him a maiden, and treat ‘em
To trials will open their eyes,
‘We’ll run their best horses and beat ’em,
‘And then won’t they think him a prize.

Title: The Outrage
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A man with a suit and cane, tipping his hat.
Description: An association of thieves defend themselves from accusations of murder.
Blurb:
“Association of what?” he said, perplexed.
“The Association of Thieves,” the gentleman in the sandy suit coolly repeated. “As for myself, my comrades did me the signal honour of electing me as the spokesman of the deputation.”

Title: The Outsider
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A spired castle. Graphite filter
Description: The author describes how they lived their youth in a castle filled with only with books and no sight or sound from parent, guardian or any human being whatsoever.
Blurb: I know not where I was born, save that the castle was infinitely old and infinitely horrible; full of dark passages and having high ceilings where the eye could find only cobwebs and shadows.

Title: The Oval Portrait
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: An expressionless woman clutching her face. Graphite filter.
Description: Upon taking refuge in an abandoned house, a man finds an incredibly realistic portrait and a letter describing the tragedy of its origin.
Blurb: The chateau into which my valet had ventured ... was one of those piles of commingled gloom and grandeur which have so long frowned among the Appennines.

Title: Over the Range
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A little girl explains where people go when they die.
Blurb: Then a light came into the shy brown eye - And she smiled, for she thought the question strange - On a thing so certain — ‘When people die -‘They go to the country over the range.’

Title: A Painful Case
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: A 20th century city with trams and horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: A single man strikes up a conversation with a woman whose daughter is his own age. But the man and the older woman find more interest in each other.
Blurb: Captain Sinico encouraged his visits, thinking that his daughter’s hand was in question. He had dismissed his wife so sincerely from his gallery of pleasures that he did not suspect that anyone else would take an interest in her.

Title: A Pair of Silk Stockings
Author: Kate Chopin
Img_description: A woman with her hands on her lap and wearing gloves. Graphite Filter
Description: After coming into the possession of fifteen dollars, Mrs Sommers decides she can spoil herself a little and still save money for the more important things such as her children.
Blurb: How good was the touch of the raw silk to her flesh! She felt like lying back in the cushioned chair and revelling for a while in the luxury of it.

Title: The Park Of Kings
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A king's crown on a stool. Graphite filter.
Description: In the future, after royalty no longer rules the world, kings who are unable to move on and accept the new world are all placed together in a park. The people watch them from outside to get a glimpse into the past world of royalty.
Blurb: Then the popular government, which had long since abolished prisons, violence, and punishment, decided to build for them in a beautiful public park a large, light, and comfortable house with a common sittingroom, dining-room, and parlor, and with smaller but comfortable living-rooms.

Title: The Past Was Goodly Once
Author: William Ernest Henley
Img_description: A candle. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on the past.
Blurb: Nothing is left at last of what one time was all.

Title: Payable Gold
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A pickaxe laying on its head on rocky ground. Graphite filter.
Description: A man leaves his family to seek his fortune at a new gold field. But he worries he won’t be able to make it back.
Blurb: He was never quite the same after the affair of Forlorn Hope, and I often think how he must have “cried” sometimes “inside”.

Title: The Pearl of Love
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A drawing of inside an elaborate pillared structure with a jewled chandelier.
Description: The narrator tells of a prince who lost his beloved, and vowed to spend the rest of his life building a monument of her so glorious people would come from far and wide to see it.
Blurb: A building it should be of perfect grace and beauty, more marvellous than any other building had ever been or could ever be, so that to the end of time it should be a wonder.

Title: The Pedestrian
Author: Ray Bradbury
Img_description: The feet of a man walking along pavement, wearing business shoes. Graphite Filter.
Description: In 2053 A.D. a man walks alone through the streets as the soft sounds of people comes from inside the houses.
Blurb: Was that a murmur of laughter from within the moon-white house? He hesitated, but went on when nothing happened.

Title: The Pendulum
Author: Ray Bradbury
Img_description: A large sphere. Graphite Filter
Description: Layeville the scientist swings in a pendulum above the Earth.
Blurb: “We shall rebuild his machine, take his precious metals, and put up a monument to his slaughtering! We'll put him on exhibition for life within his executioning device!”

Title: The Philosophy of Relative Existences
Author: Frank Stockton
Img_description: A cliffside town. Graphite filter.
Description: Two travellers find a city, claimed by a local of a nearby village to be uninhabited. But once inside, the pair spot what they think are people running for cover.
Blurb: “Well, sirs, I scarcely can tell you; queer beings that are not flesh and blood, and that is all I know about it. A good many people living hereabouts have visited that place once in their lives, but I know of no one who has gone there a second time.”

Title: The Phoenix Bird
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: A mother looks on her baby in its coat and with a glowing halo.
Description: A fable of the phoenix born in the garden of Eden
Blurb: On Shakspeare's shoulder he sat in the guise of Odin's raven, and whispered in the poet's ear "Immortality!

Title: The Phoenix on the Sword
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Drawing of a man in roman armour holding an axe as a wolf-featured man leans over him.
Description: A group of rebels plan to kill the king of Aquilonia, Conan.
Blurb: “I am the force which has welded together the steel in each, and by the clay in each, I will crush them when the time comes. But that lies in the future; tonight the king dies.”

Title: Pickman’s Model
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A paintbrush held delicately in hand. Graphite filter
Description: Boston painter Thurber tells of being invited by a fellow painter of horrific scenes to see works that would be rejected by their local art clubs. But despite his strong heart and keen interest, Thurber grows disturbed by the lifelike style of the grotesque artworks.
Blurb: You recall that Pickman’s forte was faces. I don’t believe anybody since Goya could put so much of sheer hell into a set of features or a twist of expression.

Title: The Picture
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A hand delicately holding a small paintbrush. Graphite filter.
Description: A prince travels the world and grows bored, unimpressed by wealth, unenthused by activities and uninterested in women. When he finally finds a woman that steals his heart, she returns no feelings in kind.
Blurb: He was used to having women run after him, and so he had very little respect for them. But in this case the lady paid him no special attention at all.

Title: The Picture in the House
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: An old man with a long beard and long hair. Graphite filter
Description: A genealogist seeks shelter in what he presumes to be an abandoned house. But he finds a man inside with an extremely old-time accent and equally old antiques on the wall.
Blurb: Only the silent, sleepy, staring houses in the backwoods can tell all that has lain hidden since the early days; and they are not communicative, being loath to shake off the drowsiness which helps them forget.

Title: The Piebald Horses
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A bridled Piebald horse grazing on grass. Graphite filter.
Description: A heroic fable on how the beloved black-and-white-patterned piebald horses came to be.
Blurb: To whom can we turn, in deep trouble, in sickness, at the hour of death? God is too distant and awe-inspiring, and how dare one trouble the Heavenly Mother with the loathsome ills of mankind?

Title: A Piece of Steak
Author: Jack London
Img_description: Drawing of a man in a cap and a woman hold eachother near a table with a teacup and kettle.
Description: Two men box for fifteen rounds, the younger man for glory and the older man to feed his family.
Blurb: He lacked the wisdom, and the only way for him to get it was to buy it with Youth; and when wisdom was his, Youth would have been spent in buying it.

Title: The Piece of String
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A frayed piece of string. Graphite filter.
Blurb: It was market-day, and from all the country round Goderville the peasants and their wives were coming toward the town. The men walked slowly, throwing the whole body forward at every step of their lon...

Title: The Pit and the Pendulum
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A brick wall. Graphite filter.
Description: A man is imprisoned in a dark room, soon finding himself strapped to an agonisingly torturous machine.
Blurb: Then silence, and stillness, and night were the universe.

Title: The Planet of the Dead
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A tripod telescope looking up into the stars. Graphite filter
Description: Francis Melchior, a curious and nostalgic man is looking at a star when he falls unconscious and wakes up as if his entire life had been a dream.
Blurb: One midnight, when he was peering through the telescope, he fancied that the star looked a little larger and brighter than usual.

Title: The Plattner Story
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A chemistry beaker. Graphite Filter.
Description: Gottfried Plattner, teacher of modern languages, disappears after a chemistry accident, only to reappear nine days later.
Blurb: He held the medicine bottle in his left hand. The stuff began to smoke and melt, and then—exploded with deafening violence and a blinding flash.

Title: The Plutonian Drug
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A small vial with mist inside. Graphite filter
Description: Balcoth agrees to take the unstudied drug ‘Plutonian’ that Dr Manners claims will allow him to see time just as he sees the three dimensions of space now.
Blurb: Without surprise, he found that he was gazing simultaneously in two directions. On either hand, for a vast distance that was wholly void of normal perspective, a weird and peculiar landscape stretched away, traversed by an unbroken frieze or bas-relief of human figures that ran like a straight undeviating wall.

Title: The Poets of the Tomb
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A wooden coffin with a cross. Graphite filter.
Description: A criticism of life-hating poetry.
Blurb: They say that man is made of dirt, and die, of course, he must — But, all the same, a man is made of pretty solid dust.

Title: Polaris
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A flare of white particles. Graphite filter
Description: Under the light of the North Pole Star a man has visions of a ghostly city that become stronger and stronger each time, eventually allowing him to move and interact as an inhabitant.
Blurb: And it was under a horned waning moon that I saw the city for the first time. Still and somnolent did it lie, on a strange plateau in a hollow betwixt strange peaks.

Title: The Poor Relation’s Story
Author: Charles Dickens
Img_description: A man in a suit and tipping his tophat. Graphite filter.
Description: The poorest member of a family explains the truth behind his life.
Blurb: “This is the gentleman who, people say, is nobody’s enemy but his own. This is the gentleman who can’t say no.”

Title: Praise the Generous Gods
Author: William Ernest Henley
Img_description: The sunrise. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on the gift of life.
Blurb: It is common and divine.

Title: The Premature Burial
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A gravestone. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells stories of people suffering from that which scares himself most of all things, being buried alive. Suffering from catalepsy or something similar, he often falls into long comas and fears that one day he will be presumed dead and given one of these premature burials.
Blurb: There are certain themes of which the interest is all-absorbing, but which are too entirely horrible for the purposes of legitimate fiction.

Title: The Prince Has the Mumps
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A royal carriage in front of a spired building. Graphite Filter
Description: The crown prince is sick just before a very important speech he is to make. He is stressed that he will fail his duties until his father, the king, comes up with a plan so ridiculous it makes the prince feel even worse.
Blurb: “It’s the fashion in these times to pretend that a prince is just like any other man in the country, and not a bit better. That’s rot, of course, and no one knows it better than the people.”

Title: The Princess and the Pea
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: A king and queen stack pillows on top of a bed.
Description: A Queen devises a test to see if a girl is a real princess and fit for her son.
Blurb: But she said nothing, went into the bed-room, took all the bedding off the bedstead, and laid a pea on the bottom; then she took twenty mattresses and laid them on the pea, and then twenty eider-down beds on top of the mattresses.

Title: The Princess and the Puma
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: A stalking puma on a rock. Graphite filter.
Blurb: There had to be a king and queen, of course. The king was a terrible old man who wore six-shooters and spurs, and shouted in such a tremendous voice that the rattlers on the prairie would run into their holes under the prickly pear.

Title: The Private History of a Campaign that Failed
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A person sitting at the edge of a precipice overlooking a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A team of young confederate soldiers blunder their way through the U.S. civil war.
Blurb: You have heard from a great many people who did something in the war, is it not fair and right that you listen a little moment to one who started out to do something in it but didn’t?

Title: The Problem of Thor Bridge
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Neil Gibson comes to Holmes to help clear the name of his governess of the murder of Gibson’s wife. A motive, a note, and a gun all point guilt at the governess, but Gibson doesn’t believe it.
Blurb: “Then I can assure you that our relations were entirely and always those of an employer towards a young lady whom he never conversed with, or ever saw, save when she was in the company of his children.”

Title: The Puppet-show Man
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: A drawing of a man sitting at a table of half a dozen puppet sized humans pleading for his attention.
Description: A puppet master meets a physics lecturer and they discuss each others’ expertise.
Blurb: “‘The whole world is but a series of miracles,’ said the lecturer, 'but we are so accustomed to them that we call them everyday matters.’”

Title: The Purloined Letter
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A letter and a sheet of paper. Graphite filter
Description: Amateur detective C. Auguste Dupin is approached by the police to help with stopping the man who has blackmailed the queen.
Blurb: “Not altogether a fool,” said G., “but then he’s a poet, which I take to be only one remove from a fool.”

Title: The Purple Pileus
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: two tall, white mushrooms. Graphite filter.
Description: Mr. Coombes feels he has no respect from his wife or his friends. But then one day after leaving his house in shame, he comes across some peculiar mushrooms.
Blurb: A curious, tingling sensation began in his finger-tips and toes. His pulse began to move faster. The blood in his ears sounded like a mill-race.

Title: Queen of the Black Coast
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: A naked woman with a sword defends a fallen Conan from a long-armed, bat-headed beast.
Description: Within a day of learning of the infamous pirate-queen Bêlit, Conan finds himself face to face with the legend herself.
Blurb: “By Ishtar, I have never seen your like, though I have ranged the sea from the coasts of Zingara to the fires of the ultimate south. Whence come you?”

Title: The Queer Feet
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: Three waiters converse while hunched over. Black and white drawing.
Description: Father Brown is called to an exclusive club where a waiter has had a stroke, but soon after hearing the dying man’s confession he notices suspicious footsteps.
Blurb: First, there came a long rush of rapid little steps, such as a light man might make in winning a walking race. At a certain point they stopped and changed to a sort of slow, swinging stamp, numbering not a quarter of the steps, but occupying about the same time.

Title: A Queer Night in Paris
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: Four wine glasses being clinked together. Graphite Filter.
Description: Mattres Saval, on a visit to Paris to see a rendition of Henry VIII, happens upon a famous painter who invites Saval to a party.
Blurb: “You will bring up my dinner at once, and then carry to my new studio, 15 Boulevard de Clichy, thirty bottles of beer, and the ham I ordered this morning. We are going to have a housewarming.”

Title: The Quest of Iranon
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A person in the middle of a vast desert. Graphite filter
Description: A golden-haired boy roams from city to city in search of the great city of Aira, of which he tells glorious tales.
Blurb: Into the granite city of Teloth wandered the youth, vine-crowned, his yellow hair glistening with myrrh and his purple robe torn with briers of the mountain Sidrak that lies across the antique bridge of stone.

Title: The Ransom of Red Chief
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: A smiling boy. Graphite filter
Description: Two criminals decide to kidnap a rich man’s young boy for some quick money, but the boy turns out to be a lot of work.
Blurb: “Do you think anybody will pay out money to get a little imp like that back home?”

Title: Rapunzel
Author: Brothers Grimm
Img_description: A young woman with braids. Graphite filter.
Description: After stealing from the garden of an enchantress, a man and woman must give her their child. The child grows into a beautiful woman, all the while locked up in a tall tower.
Blurb: ‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel, Let down your hair to me.’

Title: The Rats in the Walls
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A broken brick wall. Graphite filter
Description: A man rebuilds his ancestral home and moves in, only to hear the sound of rats scurrying in the walls.
Blurb: Whether the arras actually moved I cannot say. I think it did, very slightly. But what I can swear to is that behind it I heard a low, distinct scurrying as of rats or mice.

Title: Rattle of Bones
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Drawing of a skeleton strangling a man on a wooden floor.
Description: Solomon Kane and a new acquantance arrive at a tavern with no customers nor staff besides its owner. Despite their suspicions they stay for the night, only to find more skeletons in more closets.
Blurb: “A strange tavern! What is the name, now? These German words come not easily to me—the Cleft Skull? A bloody name, i’faith.”

Title: The Raven
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A sitting raven. Graphite filter.
Description: A man in despair over a lost lover is visited by a raven that torments him over his tragic circumstances, while only ever saying one word.
Blurb: But the Raven, sitting lonely on the placid bust, spoke only — That one word, as if his soul in that one word he did outpour.

Title: The Reconciliation
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Drink being poured into a champagne flute . Graphite filter.
Description: Temple tries to reconcile with Findlay, who wronged him when they were younger. But he struggles to keep his temper.
Blurb: ‘There’s no woman worth a man’s friendship’

Title: The Recovery
Author: Kate Chopin
Img_description: A late 19th century city with trams and horses. Graphite Filter
Description: A woman sees for the first time after healing from her blindness.
Blurb: “The world has not changed,” she murmured; “it has only grown more beautiful. Oh, I had forgotten how beautiful!”

Title: The Red Ettin
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A knife with a wooden handle sticking out of outside grass.
Description: After a widow’s two sons come of age, she must send them away to seek their adventure. But the oldest and brashest of the two refuses to take advice.
Blurb: So he went, but as he was bringing home the water, a raven over his head cried to him to look, and he would see that the water was running out.

Title: The Red One
Author: Jack London
Img_description: Drawing of a man holding a gun poking out from trees.
Blurb: “And I shall talk to you and tell you the many secrets you want to know. Which will not matter, for you will be dead.”

Title: The Red Room
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A small candle in the dark. Graphite filter
Description: Residents of a house with a tragic history warn a man not to spend the night in the ‘red room’. But the man insists that he will be fine.
Blurb: My candle rolled away from me, and I snatched another as I rose. Abruptly this was blown out, as I swung it off the table, by the wind of my sudden movement, and immediately the two remaining candles followed.

Title: Red Shadows
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Drawing of a man stabbing another in the back as he opens a chest.
Description: Solomon Kane finds a dying girl, who tells of a bandits led by ‘Le Loup’. Kane tracks the murderer but ‘Le Loup’ continues to evade him.
Blurb: “A long trail, Monsieur,” said he. “It began in the mountains of France; it ends in an African jungle. I have wearied of the game at last, Monsieur—and you die.”

Title: The Red-Headed League
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A red-headed man presents a curious case to detective Sherlock Holmes concerning a peculiar company that only offered work to people with red hair.
Blurb: “As a rule,” said Holmes, “the more bizarre a thing is the less mysterious it proves to be. It is your commonplace, featureless crimes which are really puzzling, just as a commonplace face is the most difficult to identify. But I must be prompt over this matter.”

Title: A Reflection
Author: Kate Chopin
Img_description: A late 19th century city with trams and horses. Graphite Filter
Description: The narrator contemplates the ability of those more fortunate to stay in line with the procession of life.
Blurb: Ah! that moving procession that has left me by the road-side! Its fantastic colors are more brilliant and beautiful than the sun on the undulating waters.

Title: The Reigate Squires
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Watson and Holmes head to a country town for a break from detective work, but instead the crime follows suit manifesting in a burglary in a nearby estate and something even worse soon after.
Blurb: “Neither, sir. It was William the coachman. Shot through the heart, sir, and never spoke again.”

Title: The Relic
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A decorated silver box. Graphite Filter.
Description: Henri’s fiancée asks him to bring back from Germany a souvenir that will prove his love for her.
Blurb: You must bring me back something; a mere trifle, just a souvenir, but a souvenir that you have chosen for me. You must guess what I should like best, do you hear? And then I shall see whether you have any imagination.

Title: The Remarkable Case of Davidson’s Eyes
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A wooden, five-masted sailing ship on the sea. Graphite filter.
Description: After a heavy thunderstorm, Bellows finds his colleague Davidson acting disorientated. He clutches at things that don’t exist and is surprised when Bellows speaks, eventually explaining that his sight is of a completely different environment to the one he can feel and is in fact inhabiting.
Blurb: He was blind and helpless. We had to walk him down the passage, one at each elbow, to Boyce’s private room, and while Boyce talked to him there, and humored him about this ship idea, I went along the corridor and asked old Wade to come and look at him.

Title: A Report to an Academy
Author: Franz Kafka
Img_description: A stoic looking chimp. Graphite Filter.
Description: An ape tells a crowd of his pathway to walking and talking like a human.
Blurb: With an effort which up to this point has never been repeated on earth, I have attained the average education of a European man.

Title: A Reputation
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A man in a tuxedo tipping his hat. Graphite Filter.
Description: Saunders Rook wants very badly to be as popular as the others of his club of liberal professionals, so he blurts out the first thing he can think of that will get him some attention. Unfortunately, he leaves himself with no choice but to stick by what he says.
Blurb: It wasn’t always like that. Funny how little interest people took in me when I only wanted to live.

Title: Requiescat
Author: Oscar Wilde
Img_description: A gravestone. Graphite Filter.
Description: The narrator laments over a woman who has passed away.
Blurb:
She that was young and fair
Fallen to dust.

Title: The Resident Patient
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Mr. Blessington lives in a house turned general practice and expertised by the hired Dr. Trevelyan. After two strange men turn up, Blessington becomes panicked and sends the Dr. to ask Holmes for help.
Blurb:
“And no advice for me?” cried Blessington, in a breaking voice.
“My advice to your, sir, is to speak the truth.”

Title: A Retrieved Reformation
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: A man with a suit and cane, tipping his hat. Graphite filter.
Description: A notorious safe-cracker is released from jail, but soon after returning to his profession a young woman catches his eye.
Blurb: Jimmy Valentine looked into her eyes, forgot what he was, and became another man.

Title: Rip Van Winkle
Author: Washington Irving
Img_description: An old man with a long beard and long hair. Graphite filter.
Description: A Dutch-American villager in colonial America falls asleep on a hill and wakes up to find the world drastically changed.
Blurb: A tart temper never mellows with age, and a sharp tongue is the only edged tool that grows keener with constant use.

Title: Roach Hole
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A man with a black moustache and beard, and a wide-eyed stare. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator tells of a man from southern Russia who has an opinion on, interest in and even a knack for every facet of life there is. He and the narrator meet over their lives at work, in war and in politics with the zany man only growing more and more eccentric.
Blurb: “It is therefore perfectly evident, even to a two year-old infant, that nowadays candles burn four times as fast as a normal candle should.”

Title: The Roaring Days
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: The suns rays coming from a horizon. Graphite filter
Description: The narrator reminisces the exploration of Australia before it joined the industrialised world.
Blurb:
Their shining Eldorado,
Beneath the southern skies,
Was day and night for ever
Before their eager eyes.

Title: The Rocking-Horse Winner
Author: D. H. Lawrence
Img_description: A cat's eyes in the darkness. Graphite filter.
Blurb: There were a boy and two little girls. They lived in a pleasant house, with a garden, and they had discreet servants, and felt themselves superior to anyone in the neighbourhood.

Title: Rogues in the House
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Drawing of a man in a loincloth drops a naked woman into a pit.
Description: Conan is hired in a fight for power over the city.
Blurb: “I want you to kill a man for me.”

Title: The Rose Tree
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: An elegant-looking, young woman with braids smelling a tree. Graphite filter.
Description: A girl’s father remarries, and while the girl and her new stepbrother get along well, the stepmother grows jealous of the little girl’s beauty.
Blurb: And when the girl-baby grew white as milk, with cheeks like roses and lips like cherries, and when her hair, shining like golden silk, hung down to her feet so that her father and all the neighbours began to praise her looks, the stepmother fairly hated her, and did all in her power to spoil her looks.

Title: “A Rough Shed”
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A gripped pair of sheep shears, graphite filter.
Description: A labourer accounts his struggles in a shearer’s shed.
Blurb: I am a rouseabout of the rouseabouts. I have fallen so far that it is beneath me to try to climb to the proud position of ‘ringer’ of the shed.

Title: Rumpelstiltskin
Author: Brothers Grimm
Img_description: A blanketed baby in a basket. Graphite filter.
Description: A man boasts that his daughter can spin straw into gold. But when the king forces her to do so, she has to make a deal with a strange, small man.
Blurb: ‘Then say you will give me,’ said the little man, ‘the first little child that you may have when you are queen.’

Title: The Sad Story of a Dramatic Critic
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A man with a suit and cane, tipping his hat.
Description: The simple living and pragmatic Egbert Cummins is given the job of a theatre critic without having ever been to the theatre. At his first viewing, he becomes a little too immersed.
Blurb: But I could not sleep that night. I dreamt of actors—actors glaring, actors smiting their chests, actors flinging out a handful of extended fingers, actors smiling bitterly, laughing despairingly, falling hopelessly, dying idiotically.

Title: Saltbush Bill
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: An old man with a long beard and long hair. Graphite filter
Description: A group of ‘overlanders’ led by Saltbush Bill stop a while on a grassy plain, much to the dismay of ‘squatters.’
Blurb:
Now this is the law of the Overland that all in the West obey,
A man must cover with travelling sheep a six-mile stage a day.

Title: Sasha
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A fiddle and bow. Graphite filter.
Description: Fishermen, merchants and thieves alike come to the Gambrinous to drink, revel and most of all to see the legendary Sasha play on his fiddle. But on Russia’s horizon is war, and much worse.
Blurb: Everyone was overpowered by the desire to sing. Softened by beer, by his own kindness, and even by the coarse delight that his music was giving to others, Sasha was ready to play anything.

Title: The Satyr
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: sillhouettes of two lovers in the forest. Graphite Filter.
Description: After cottoning onto a potential affair, Raoul follows after his wife and her lover into the old, pagan forest.
Blurb: Adele exclaimed with delight; and neither she nor Olivier was aware of anything sinister or doubtful in the unison of exquisite beauty and gnarled quaintness which the old forest offered to them.

Title: A Scandal in Bohemia
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A drawing of a regal looking man in an old fashioned cloak, with a cane, holding a hat and wearing an small mask over the eyes.
Description: The soon-to-be king of Bohemia asks detective Sherlock Holmes to help him cover up a previous affair that could threaten his royal inheritance.
Blurb: “To Sherlock Holmes she is always the woman.”

Title: The Scarlet Citadel
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: A cloaked man thrusts his hands forward as a bird of prey flies away from him.
Description: Conan is betrayed by his ‘allies’. Including Strabonus, the King of Kogth; Almarus, King of Ophir; and the demonic necromancer, Tsotha-lanti.
Blurb: “You sit on satin and guzzle wine the people sweat for, and talk of divine rights of sovereignty—bah! I climbed out of the abyss of naked barbarism to the throne and in that climb I spilt my blood as freely as I spilt that of others. If either of us has the right to rule men, by Crom, it is I!”

Title: Sculptor
Author: C. C. MacApp
Img_description: Small flowering plants on the ground. Graphite Filter
Description: After fleeing the planet as a lone survivor eight years ago, a pirate has brought Jim back as a hostage forced to guide them through the foreign terrain for treasure, no matter what deadly things may lurk there.
Blurb: All he could say for sure was that when he’d come out of the delirium the seven figurines had been in the ship; each representing, with an exquisite and inexplicable art, one of the dead crewmen.

Title: Sea Curse
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: A masted ship at sea. Graphite filter.
Description: A woman, rumoured to be a witch, curses two sailors for the death of her daughter.
Blurb: I set the seal of death upon your brow, John Kulrek! You shall live in terror and die in horror far out upon the cold grey sea!

Title: The Sea Raiders
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A hand sticking out of the ocean. Graphite filter.
Description: Nothing can explain the decline of fish, disappearance of boats, and several dead whales washing onshore at Sidmouth, England. That is, until the retired Filon spots dozens of small animals on the shore during one of his walks.
Blurb: It would seem, indeed, that these large and agile creatures, living in the middle depths of the sea, must to a large extent, for ever remain unknown to us, since under water they are too nimble for nets, and it is only by such rare, unlooked-for accidents that specimens can be obtained.

Title: The Sealed Room
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A fountain pen writing on paper. Graphite filter.
Description: After helping an injured young man back to his strangely large mansion, Frank Alder discovers a room sealed with red wax.
Blurb: “Do not sell or let the house, for in either case my secret will be discovered. As long as you or Felix are in the house, I know that you will comply with my wishes. When Felix is twenty-one he may enter the room—not before.”

Title: The Searcher of the End House
Author: William Hope Hodgson
Img_description: A man sits up in bed as a ghostly figure leans over him.
Description: Carnacki discovers a haunting in his own mother’s house.
Blurb: “Of course it was absurd to try to make believe any longer. There was something strange about the house; and as soon as it was daylight, I set my mother to packing; and soon after breakfast, I saw her off by train.”

Title: Second Variety
Author: Phillip K. Dick
Img_description: A man holds a severed but smiling head which has large and small coils sprouting from the neck.
Description: The UN are winning the war against the Soviets thanks to an innovative weapon, but Major Hendricks wonders whether it ever ought to have been invented at all.
Blurb: They were not machines. They were living  things, spinning, creeping, shaking themselves up suddenly from the gray ash and darting toward a man, climbing up him, rushing for his throat. And that was what they had been designed to do. Their job.

Title: The Secret Garden
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: An older man is depicted a though he is falling or on the ground. Black and white sketch.
Description: A dead body is found beheaded at a party, and a Commandant is missing his sabre.
Blurb: “That I should have hunted mysteries all over the earth, and now one comes and settles in my own back-yard.”

Title: The Seed from the Sepulchre
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: Small blossoming flowers in the ground. Graphite filter.
Description: One of a pair of explorers in Venezuela returns to the other from a three day adventure appearing morose and with little to say about what he found. The pair set out again to explore, but the silent second of the pair grows sicker and sicker until the first finds something growing out of the top of his head.
Blurb: He was startled to find, amid the thick disheveled hair, a hard and pointed lump which resembled the tip of a beginning horn, rising under the still-unbroken skin. As if endowed with erectile and resistless life, it seemed to grow beneath his fingers.

Title: A Self-Made Man
Author: Stephen Crane
Img_description: A cigar being lit over a sleek lighter.
Description: Stephen Crane gives his guaranteed method to get rich in the form of a story. A man struggling to find work comes across a man in desperate need of someone trustworthy to read a letter for him.
Blurb: “What,” shouted the old man in a voice of admiration, “are you a lawyer as well as a reader?”

Title: A Sentimental Romance
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A beach shore with the sun setting. Graphite Filter.
Description: The author writes a letter to a long-time friend about their past relationship and current sickness.
Blurb: I am sitting at this moment at the writing-table, but I have only to lift my eyes from it to see the sea, that very sea with which you and I⁠—do you remember?⁠—were so poetically in love. But, even without looking up, I can feel it.

Title: ‘Sez You’
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: Rusty coins in the palms of someones hands. Graphite filter.
Description: The author compels the reader to strive on through hardship, and survive until their time comes.
Blurb:
When the heavy sand is yielding backward from your blistered feet,
And across the distant timber you can SEE the flowing heat;

Title: Shadows in the Moonlight
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: A bare-chested Conan wrestles with a giant ape in front of a distressed woman.
Description: Conan rescues Olivia from an assailant, but they find themselves on a strange island that gives Olivia horrifying dreams.
Blurb: “Pirates, storms, starvation—they are—all kinder than the people of Turan.”

Title: The Shape of Things
Author: Ray Bradbury
Img_description: Drawing of a man in pilot gear and a woman in a vehicle.
Description: Peter Horn’s wife, Polly Horn, gives birth to a healthy baby named Py, only, she gives birth to him into the wrong dimension.
Blurb: The small blue pyramid moved. It began to cry.

Title: She Walketh Veiled and Sleeping
Author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
Img_description: Two old-fashioned suffragettes with 'votes for women' sashes
Description: A short poem on women’s emancipation.
Blurb: She walketh veiled and sleeping - For she knoweth not her power.

Title: The She-Wolf
Author: Saki
Img_description: Three wine glasses being clinked together, graphite filter.
Description: After Leonard Blisiter boasts of learning ‘Siberian Magic’ overseas, his Aunt dares him to turn her into a wolf.
Blurb: “I don’t suppose Colonel Hampton would care to have his wife turned into a succession of fancy animals as though we were playing a round game with her,”

Title: Shearing at Castlereagh
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A hand holding a pair of rusty metal sheep shears. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on the hustle of a sheep-shearing shed.
Blurb:
The bell is set a-ringing, and the engine gives a toot,
There’s five and thirty shearers here are shearing for the loot.

Title: The Ship That Turned Aside
Author: G. Peyton Wertenbaker
Img_description: Drawing of four men in a field pointing to a city in the distance which is distorted by triangular shapes. Black and white sketch, above text of a story.
Description: A ship, heading from New York to Liverpool, comes across a strange display of lights in the sky. Soon after, the crew and passengers find themselves heading in a direction further off course than previously thought possible.
Blurb: “In the other case—our case—the same principle applies. How are we to steer a course through the fourth dimension?”

Title: The Shirt-Collar
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: Drawing of a boy pulling faces with his hands up to his nose.
Description: A shirt collar looks for an item to marry.
Blurb: “I have never seen anything so slim and delicate, so neat and soft before. May I venture to ask your name?”

Title: Shoes
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A pair of womens' stilleto pumps. Graphite Filter
Description: A man defends himself in court having been accused of kissing a woman against her will, citing his strange ‘condition’.
Blurb: “I got sumpin’ wrong with me, I guess. Always did have, ever since I was a kid. I ain’t a bad one, your honor. I go to church regular and I know my Bible and I ain’t never been in no kind of trouble before.”

Title: The Shunned House
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A gothic house on a hill. Graphite filter.
Description: A man and his uncle decide to investigate a local house that had been abandoned for having an alarming number of deaths inside.
Blurb: What I heard in my youth about the shunned house was merely that people died there in alarmingly great numbers.

Title: The Sign of the Broken Sword
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: Drawing of a suited man on a horse greeting another mounted man who is next to seemingly hundreds of other mounted men.
Description: Father Brown and his companion visit the effigy of a famous war hero, but Father Brown knows the truth behind the man.
Blurb: He was found swinging there after the Brazilians had retired, with his broken sword hung round his neck.

Title: The Signal Man
Author: Charles Dickens
Img_description: A train crossing a bridge and puffing smoke. Graphite filter.
Description: A rail signal man has visions of ghosts, trying to warn him of future accidents along the train tracks.
Blurb: So little sunlight ever found its way to this spot, that it had an earthy deadly smell; and so much cold wind rushed through it, that it struck chill to me, as if I had left the natural world.

Title: Silver Blaze
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: A prized race-horse disappears and its trainer is murdered. Holmes and Watson are on the case.
Blurb: The door was open; inside, huddled together upon a chair, Hunter was sunk in a state of absolute stupor, the favorite’s stall was empty, and there were no signs of his trainer.

Title: The Silver Key
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A detailed, silver box. Graphite filter
Description: Randolph Carter yearns to relive the dreams he had in his youth which have been replaced with a jaded reality. He journeys to an ancestral home to reconnect with the past.
Blurb: Wonder had gone away, and he had forgotten that all life is only a set of pictures in the brain, among which there is no difference betwixt those born of real things and those born of inward dreamings, and no cause to value the one above the other.

Title: The Sin of Monsieur Pettipon
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A large sailing ship. Graphite Filter.
Description: Pettipon, a steward of the ocean liner Voltaire, takes immense pride in his immaculate cleanliness. But one day one of his passengers presents him with a horrifyingly shameful bundle of brown fur.
Blurb: To him the art of being a steward was just as estimable as the art of being a poet; he was a Shelley of the dustpan; a Keats of the sheets.

Title: The Sins of Prince Saradine
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: Two men peer through a window at a man and woman having a fancy dinner.
Description: Father Brown and his reformed friend are invited to a prince’s house, but upon seeing a sketch of a brother a scandal is revealed.
Blurb: “His Highness,” he said, “has just arrived.”

Title: The Sisters
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: A small candle in the dark. Graphite filter.
Description: A young boy learns that his mentor and priest has passed away, so he visits the priest’s family.
Blurb: “You couldn’t tell when the breath went out of him. He had a beautiful death, God be praised.”

Title: The Sisters of Albano
Author: Mary Shelley
Img_description: A pair of holding hands. Graphite filter.
Description: A young woman falls in love with an outlaw and gets arrested. It’s up to her sister to get her back.
Blurb: His gun is a help to the imagination, and we may fancy him a bandit with his contadina love, the terror of all the neighbourhood, except of her, the most defenceless being in it.

Title: The Skull
Author: Phillip K. Dick
Img_description: A human skull. Graphite filter
Description: In the future, a hunter who lives outside the law is captured and sent back in time to kill a man before he starts a religious revolution.
Blurb: “And you can’t wait for him to start speaking; that’s what we must avoid! You must act in advance. Take chances; shoot as soon as you think you’ve found him.”

Title: Skulls in the Stars
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Drawing of a shadowy figure chasing an unaware person through a field.
Description: Traveller Solomon Kane is warned by the villagers to avoid the path over the moor, for there lies an unidentified, unholy fiend that has killed all who have tread there. Kane can’t resist the call for a challenge.
Blurb: None has ever seen, it and lived,  but  late-farers  have  heard  terrible  laughter  far  out  on  the  fen  and  men have  heard  the  horrid  shrieks  of  its  victims.

Title: A Slander
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: Four wine glasses being clinked together. Graphite filter.
Description: A man desperately tries to clear the rumour of him kissing the cook at his daughter’s wedding.
Blurb: “I’m not kissing,” said Ahineev in confusion. “Who told you so, you fool? I was only . . . I smacked my lips . . . in reference to . . . as an indication of. . . pleasure . . . at the sight of the fish.”

Title: A Slav Soul
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A town on a hill. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator recalls the strange servant of his childhood household - Yasha. A man of peculiar impulses and a ‘Slav Soul’.
Blurb: My imagination recalls with special vividness the eccentric figure of Yasha and the two companions⁠—I might almost call them friends⁠—who accompanied him along the path of life: Matsko, an old rejected cavalry horse, and the yard-dog Bouton.

Title: A Slip Under the Microscope
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A man with a suit and cane, tipping his hat.
Blurb: “There is one thing above matter,” said Hill promptly, feeling he had a better thing this time; aware too, of someone in the doorway behind him, and raising his voice a trifle for her benefit, “and that is, the delusion that there is something above matter.”

Title: The Slithering Shadow
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: A man falls through a trapdoor as a woman on a bed pulls a rope.
Description: Conan the Barbarian and Natala the Brythunian are left wandering the desert after their army was destroyed in battle.
Blurb: “You can’t fight a devil out of hell and come off with a whole skin!”

Title: The Sniper
Author: Liam O’Flaherty
Img_description: Eight soldiers with rifles on a beach facing an explosion
Description: A Republican sniper of the Irish civil war waits on a rooftop, pondering whether he can risk giving away his position by lighting his cigarette.
Blurb: Placing a cigarette between his lips, he struck a match, inhaled the smoke hurriedly and put out the light. Almost immediately, a bullet flattened itself against the parapet of the roof. The sniper took another whiff and put out the cigarette. Then he swore softly and crawled away to the left.

Title: The Snows of Kilimanjaro
Author: Ernest Hemmingway
Img_description: several men at a bar. Graphite filter.
Description: Harry and Helen are stranded on a mountain. Harry, dying from gangrene, reminisces on all his life regrets.
Blurb: He had seen the world change; not just the events; although he had seen many of them and had watched the people, but he had seen the subtler change and he could remember how the people were at different times. He had been in it and he had watched it and it was his duty to write of it; but now he never would.

Title: The Sobbin’ Women
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: A solem looking bride holding flowers. Graphite Filter.
Description: The Pontipee family live on a farm deep in the wooded valley amongst the bears, and are almost a legend among the straightforward townsfolk. The family mostly keep to themselves, but when the father and mother pass on, the sons start getting ideas.
Blurb: Harry kicked like a cow in fly-time at the bare idea of getting married, and tried to put it on to Halbert, who was next in line. And Halbert passed it on to Harvey, but Harvey said women was snares and delusions, or so he’d heard, and he wouldn’t have a strange woman around him for a brand-new plow.

Title: Soldier’s Home
Author: Ernest Hemmingway
Img_description: A stunned-looking, young man with a moustache. Graphite filter.
Description: After returning from war, a man struggles to reintegrate back into society.
Blurb: His town had heard too many atrocity stories to be thrilled by actualities. Krebs found that to be listened to at all he had to lie, and after he had done this twice he, too, had a reaction against the war and against talking about it.

Title: Son of a Sloganeer
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A blanket-wrapped baby in a basket. Graphie Filter.
Description: Mr. and Mrs. Bowser are a dynamic business duo running a success slogan company. But the one phrase they can’t agree on is their infant baby’s Christian name.
Blurb: It is not intelligent to continue to call him Baby and Junior indefinitely. I suggest that you send me without delay list of names you consider suitable for him. I will give them my careful attention and I hope we can reach an agreement today on this subject.

Title: A Son of the Gods
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A soldier next to a cannon. Graphite filter.
Description: A walking army cannot advance till a young soldier can scout ahead over the hill. It the way is safe he will come back down, but if it is not the entire army will witness him executed by the ambush.
Blurb: The soldier never becomes wholly familiar with the conception of his foes as men like himself; he cannot divest himself of the feeling that they are another order of beings, differently conditioned, in an environment not altogether of the earth.

Title: The Song And The Dance
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A cliffside town. Graphite filter.
Description: An artist is living in a small Russian town with several other asthetes. They judge the locals.
Blurb: There was so much drunkenness among the peasants, even before the festival, that in Dagileva a son broke his father’s head, and in Kruglitsi an old man drank himself to death.

Title: Song of the Future
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a dry plains. Graphite filter
Description: A poem on a new Australian identity.
Blurb: Our willing workmen, strong and skilled — Within our cities idle stand, — And cry aloud for leave to toil.

Title: A Sound of Thunder
Author: Ray Bradbury
Img_description: A cocked, smoking, shiny rifle. Graphite filter.
Description: A man travels into the past to take down the ultimate game.
Blurb: “We guarantee nothing,” said the official, “except the dinosaurs.”

Title: Spare That Tree
Author: C. C. MacApp
Img_description: A tree with winding branches in a forest. Graphite Filter
Description: Inspector Kruger is on a foreign planet, tasked with finding a tree that was stolen from an emperor of a planet allied to Earth. But on a world without humans he struggles to fit in.
Blurb:
The flitbot glared suspiciously. “Vegetable, animal, mineral or ’bot?”
“V-vegetable.”

Title: The Spring My Dear
Author: William Ernest Henley
Img_description: White clouds in the sky. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on the changing times.
Blurb: Are the skies the old — Immemorial blue?

Title: Spring Sowing
Author: Liam O’Flaherty
Img_description: The suns rays coming from a horizon. Graphite filter
Blurb: In my young days, when men worked from morning till night without tasting food, better work was done. But of course it can’t be expected to be the same as it was. The breed is getting weaker. So it is.

Title: Sredni Vashtar
Author: Saki
Img_description: A ferret. Graphite filter.
Description: A troubled young boy finds solace in a ferret found in his garden.
Blurb: He knew that the Woman would come out presently with that pursed smile he loathed so well on her face, and that in an hour or two the gardener would carry away his wonderful god, a god no longer, but a simple brown ferret in a hutch.

Title: Sssssssssshhhh!
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: An outstreched hand with a crooked finger. Graphite Filter.
Description: A journalist moves to a small town only to find people speaking to each other in cryptic signals.
Blurb: “This,” said Larry to himself, “seems to prove the theory that there are more cuckoos than clocks.”

Title: St. George Of Merrie England
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A young, armored man with a sword on horseback. Graphite filter.
Description: An evil witch abducts the child of an earl. But nothing can stop the young George from becoming the hero he was meant to be.
Blurb: But the babe was marked from the first for doughty deeds; for on his breast was pictured the living image of a dragon, on his right hand was a blood-red cross, and on his left leg showed the golden garter.

Title: The Star
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A star in space. Graphite Filter
Description: A star appears in the sky. The next day, it is larger. The next, larger still.
Blurb: “It would seem, gentlemen, if I may put the thing clearly and briefly, that—Man has lived in vain.”

Title: The Statement of Randolph Carter
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A cave with a stream of sunlight falling in. Graphite filter
Description: Defending himself of suspicion surrounding the now missing Warren, Carter tells of how he was dragged along by his friend Warren to an ancient cemetery to investigate occult findings discovered in strange, rare books.
Blurb: You can’t imagine, even from what you have read and from what I’ve told you, the things I shall have to see and do. It’s fiendish work, Carter, and I doubt if any man without ironclad sensibilities could ever see it through and come up alive and sane.

Title: The Steadfast Tin Soldier
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: An etch of a tin soldier and toy balleringa meeting amongst other toys.
Description: A toy solider with one leg stays strong through unfortunate events, thinking of the toy ballerina.
Blurb: The only ones who did not move from their places were the Tin Soldier and the Lady Dancer. She stood on tiptoe with outstretched arms, and he was just as persevering on his one leg; he never once turned away his eyes from her.

Title: Steelman’s Pupil
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: Hands holding half a dozen coins. Graphite filter.
Description: Steelman teaches his fellow vagrant the proper way to live on the streets.
Blurb: Your father’s dead. You ran away to sea and came out in the Bobbie Burns to Sydney. Your poor old mother’s in Aberdeen now—Bruce or Wallace Wynd will do. Your mother might be dead now—poor old soul!—any way, you’ll never see her again.

Title: The Stock-Broker’s Clerk
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Hall Pycroft comes to Holmes, suspicious of his new job. He has been hired by two men claiming to be brothers. The problem, they look a little too similar, and have never been seen in the same room.
Blurb: When I put that with the voice and figure being the same, and only those things altered which might be changed by a razor or a wig, I could not doubt that it was the same man. Of course you expect two brothers to be alike, but not that they should have the same tooth stuffed in the same way.

Title: The Stolen Bacillus
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A curved glass vial holding a misty gas. Graphite filter.
Description: A bacteriologist shows a man all the specimens in his lab, but the man takes a particular attention to deadly ‘bottled cholera’.
Blurb: “Once start him at the water supply, and before we could ring him in, and catch him again, he would have decimated the metropolis.”

Title: The Stolen Body
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: The blurry shadow of a human. Graphite filter.
Description: After a successful attempt by Mr. Bessel to contact Mr Vincey by projection through several streets, Mr. Vincey rushes to Mr. Bessel’s house to congratulate him, only to find the room wrecked and the man missing.
Blurb: The missing gentleman had rushed out of the gates of the Albany into Vigo Street, hatless and with disordered hair, and had vanished into the direction of Bond Street.

Title: The Stolen Crime
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A man shines a light into the ceiling illuminating a disembodied face. Black and white sketch.
Description: Two men argue over whether the perfect crime with no clues left behind is possible, and one man ventures his own perfect plan. A third man, listening on to the plan, decides soon after that he has somewhere to be.
Blurb: “Do you think I’m an utter fool—to tell the district attorney of my plan to commit an unusual crime, and the next day commit it under his very nose?”

Title: The Storm
Author: Kate Chopin
Img_description: A lone horserider staring off into the sky. graphite filter.
Description: During a storm, and while her husband and son wait it out at a nearby store, Calixta gives shelter to her old friend Mr. Alce.
Blurb: And when he possessed her, they seemed to swoon together at the very borderland of life’s mystery.

Title: A Story By Angela Poe
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: An old couple sitting on a bench drinking champagne. Graphite Filter.
Description: A staffer at a publisher is tasked with aiding the successful, but notoriously tacky romance author Angela Poe. She, however, turns out to be much less boring than he expects.
Blurb: The heroines were petite, unworldly, and given to calling the native flora pet names. And over all, insipid, lingering, and sweet as the taste of a giant marshmallow.

Title: The Story of the Last Trump
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A sunrise flaring over the horizon. Graphite filter
Description: A child of god knocks over the trumpet destined to hail Armageddon and it falls down to Earth. Down on the ground, one mechanic bets the other he can play every instrument in the shop, including the rusty trumpet.
Blurb: But his impression was this: that the flash that came with the sound came, not from the trumpet but to it, that it smote down to it and took it, and its shape was in the exact likeness of a hand and arm of fire.

Title: The Story of the Late Mr. Elvesham
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Drawing of an old man in a coat and a younger man in a suit standing by a draped dinner table.
Description: Edward Eden is approached by a strange man who reveals himself to be the famous philosopher Egbert Elvesham. Elvesham declares that he will bequeath his wealthy inheritance to Eden, but only if Eden agrees to take his name.
Blurb: I set this story down, not expecting it will be believed, but if possible, to prepare a way of escape for the next victim. He perhaps, may profit by my misfortune.

Title: The Story Of The Three Bears
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: An elegant-looking, young woman with braids smelling a tree. Graphite filter.
Description: Three bears make porridge and go out while it cools down. The impertinent, little Goldilocks comes in and eats it all up.
Blurb: And then she went to the porridge of the Little Wee Bear, and tasted it, and that was neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and she liked it so well that she ate it all up, every bit!

Title: A Story Without an End
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A coffing with a cross. Graphite Filter
Description: A man is called over to his neighbour’s house to aid a man who has attempted suicide.
Blurb: I have had burdens to bear that would have broken an elephant's back; the devil knows what I have suffered.

Title: The Strange Adventure of a Private Secretary in New York
Author: Algernon Blackwood
Img_description: A man with a top hat and a suit. Graphite Filter.
Blurb: “Few men,” replied Shorthouse, with the manner of making a great confidence, but entirely refusing to be drawn, “go through his experiences and reach his age without entertaining delusions of one kind or another.”

Title: The Strange High House in the Mist
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A gothic, wooden, three storeyed house.
Description: The philosopher Thomas Olney comes to teach at a college in Kingsport. He soon grows curious of a house on a high crag, with no apparent path through which to access it.
Blurb: Despite a conservative training—or because of it, for humdrum lives breed wistful longings of the unknown—he swore a great oath to scale that avoided northern cliff and visit the abnormally antique grey cottage in the sky.

Title: A Strange Story
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: A stunned looking man with a moustache. Graphite Filter.
Description: A father leaves to get medicine and never comes back.
Blurb: ...on the anniversary of the disappearance of John Smothers, who would now have been her grandfather if he had been alive and had a steady job.

Title: The Stranger
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A wooden fire. Graphite filter.
Description: A stranger appears at a campfire far out in the ‘Wild West’ and tells a story of his band of travellers being ambushed by an Apache band.
Blurb: A man is like a tree: in a forest of his fellows he will grow as straight as his generic and individual nature permits; alone in the open, he yields to the deforming stresses and tortions that environ him.

Title: The Student
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A large wood fire. Graphite filter.
Description: A clerical student, walking home through the cold winds of winter, considers how five hundred years ago people felt the same cold and suffering.
Blurb: Needles of ice stretched across the pools, and it felt cheerless, remote, and lonely in the forest. There was a whiff of winter.

Title: The Supernumerary Corpse
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A chemistry beaker. Graphite Filter.
Description: A disgruntled chemist decides to kill his manipulative superior with a diabolical concoction of chemicals. Some side effects may occur.
Blurb: My motives in the killing of Jasper Trilt, though imperative, were far from extraordinary. He had wronged me enough, in the course of a twelve years’ acquaintance, to warrant his death twice over.

Title: A Suspicious Gift
Author: Algernon Blackwood
Img_description: a man covering his face with his hand. Graphite filter.
Description: A man struggling for money is visited by a man who spontaneously offers him thousands of dollars.
Blurb: Blake never knew how he managed to smother the cry that sprang to his lips, but smother it he did. In a second he was at the door, his knees trembling, his mind in a sudden and dreadful turmoil.

Title: The Swagman’s Rest
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A stone grave with an wreath shape embossed upon it. Graphite filter.
Description: A heavy-drinking swagman asks to be buried under the bloodwood trees.
Blurb: Just take and shovel me out of the grave - And, maybe, I’ll bring you luck.

Title: The Tailor of Gloucester
Author: Beatrix Potter
Img_description: A mouse dressed in a fancy dress.
Description: A poor tailor is given the chance to make a coat for the Mayor of Gloucester, but he is down to his last skein of cherry-coloured twist.
Blurb: Out stepped a little live lady mouse, and made a curtsey to the tailor! Then she hopped away down off the dresser, and under the wainscot.

Title: The Tale of Jemima Puddle-Duck
Author: Beatrix Potter
Img_description: Coloured drawing of a duck wearing a bonnet and small coat.
Description: Jemima Puddle-Duck runs away from her farm to hatch her eggs, rather than let them be taken by the farmer.
Blurb: “I wish to hatch my own eggs; I will hatch them all by myself,”

Title: A Tale of Negative Gravity
Author: Frank Stockton
Img_description: A straight, dangling pair of legs in pants and dress shoes. graphite filter.
Description: A scientific man invents a machine to store up a force opposite to gravity.
Blurb: “I did not dare to call for assistance, for if any of the simple-minded inhabitants of the town had discovered me floating in the air they would have taken me for a demon, and would probably have shot at me.”

Title: The Tale of Peter Rabbit
Author: Beatrix Potter
Img_description: The mother rabbit hands the basket over, the rabbit in a blue coat looks off, distracted
Description: Peter the little rabbit ignores his mother’s warnings and ventures into the garden of the evil Mr. McGregory.
Blurb: “Now, my dears,” said old Mrs. Rabbit one morning, “you may go into the fields or down the lane, but don’t go into Mr. McGregor’s garden: your Father had an accident there; he was put in a pie by Mrs. McGregor.”

Title: Tattercoats
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: An elegant-looking, young woman with braids smelling a tree. Graphite filter.
Description: After his daughter dies in childbirth, a lord refuses to ever set eyes upon his new granddaughter, who grows up outcast and lonely.
Blurb: So he turned his back, and sat by his window looking out over the sea, and weeping great tears for his lost daughter.

Title: A Telephonic Conversation
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A solitary,colourless rotary telephone resting on a stooll
Blurb: Consider that a conversation by telephone—when you are simply sitting by and not taking any part in that conversation—is one of the solemnest curiosities of modern life. Yesterday I was writing a de...

Title: The Tell-Tale Heart
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A tense, staring eye of a man's face. Graphite filter
Description: A man attempts to convince the reader of his sanity, and to justify his grisly deeds.
Blurb: If still you think me mad, you will think so no longer when I describe the wise precautions I took for the concealment of the body.

Title: The Temple
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: The marbled pillars of a temple. Graphite filter
Description: After taking an ivory talisman off of a dead seaman’s body, the crew of a German submarine begin having delirious dreams and going insane.
Blurb: I am not given to emotion of any kind, but my amazement was very great when I saw what lay revealed in that electrical glow. And yet as one reared in the best Kultur of Prussia I should not have been amazed, for geology and tradition alike tell us of great transpositions in oceanic and continental areas.

Title: The Temptation of Harringay
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A man with a suit and cane, tipping his hat.
Description: Harringay goes to work on his portrait, only to find himself making it worse and worse to the point of it becoming almost... satanic.
Blurb: In a flash of passion, possibly with something of the courage of panic, he struck the brush full of bright red, athwart the picture; and then a very curious thing, a very strange thing indeed, occurred—if it did occur.

Title: Tempting Providence
Author: Aleksandr I. Kuprin
Img_description: A train crossing a bridge and puffing smoke. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells of how he met a civil engineer on a train. The engineer was anxiously awaiting to arrive and meet his family for the first time in years, but a different destiny awaited him...
Blurb: I agree that there are laws of Nature governing alike in their wisdom the courses of the stars and the digestion of beetles. I believe in such laws and I revere them. But there is Something or Somebody stronger than Fate, greater than the world.

Title: A Tent in Agony
Author: Stephen Crane
Img_description: A roaring grizzly bear. Graphite filter.
Description: A man holds the camp while others fetch supplies. Someone unexpected joins him.
Blurb: The bear snarled awfully and made a jump and a grab at his disappearing game. The little man, now without the tent, felt a tremendous paw grab his coat tails.

Title: Terrible Epps
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: Several wine glasses clinking together. Graphite filter.
Description: Tidbury Epps is an undistinguishable clerk who’s always looked over by his superiors. The only thing he has going for him is the chance of marrying Martha Ritter, but she won’t give him the chance unless he does something about his timid personality.
Blurb: It was the round black eyes of Martha Ritter, the new girl at the information desk, and the way she cocked her head on one side when she smiled, that first brought to Tidbury the alarming realization that his heart was something more than a pump.

Title: The Terrible Old Man
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: An old man with a long beard and long hair. Graphite filter
Description: Three robbers target a rich and reclusive old man, despite all the frightening rumours surrounding him.
Blurb: Little things make considerable excitement in little towns, which is the reason that Kingsport people talked all that spring and summer about the three unidentifiable bodies, horribly slashed as with many cutlasses, and horribly mangled as by the tread of many cruel boot-heels, which the tide washed in.

Title: “The Terror”
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: The intense eye of a staring man. graphite filter.
Description: A man, living alone save only his servant, begins to see someone sitting in a chair by his fire.
Blurb: “It is a mere hallucination, that is all.”

Title: The Terror of Blue John Gap
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A drawing of a cave wherein a man shines a light on an enormous cat-like beast that is reared onto its hind legs.
Description: Dr. James Hardcastle hears rumour that something lurking within an opening to an old mine is responsible for sheep going missing on moonless nights. He can’t help himself from investigating within the tunnel.
Blurb: Now I stood astonished before it, for there were three similar imprints upon its surface, enormous in size, irregular in outline, of a depth which indicated the ponderous weight which had left them.

Title: That Spot
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A squinting, panting, long-haired, long-snouted dog. Graphite filter.
Description: Two prospectors pay one hundred and ten dollars for a strong, healthy, and smart looking sled dog. But the dog turns out to be smarter than a dog ought to be.
Blurb: He always came back, and no one asked for their money. We didn’t want the money. We’d have paid handsomely for any one to take him off our hands for keeps’.

Title: There Will Come Soft Rains
Author: Ray Bradbury
Img_description: An oven. Graphite Filter.
Description: A house prepares the day for its owner, but something is missing.
Blurb: “Today is Mr. Featherstone’s birthday. Today is the anniversary of Tilita’s marriage. Insurance is payable, as are the water, gas, and light bills.”

Title: The Thief
Author: René Maizeroy
Img_description: A twisting tree. Graphite filter.
Blurb: While apparently thinking of something else, Dr. Sorbier had been listening quietly to those amazing accounts of burglaries and daring deeds that might have been taken from the trial of Cartouche. “As...

Title: The Thing in the Moonlight
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Mud caked ground. Graphite filter
Description: A man writes of a dream of strange creatures that come at night.
Blurb: Then one of them sniffed with singular sharpness, and raised his face to howl to the moon. The other dropped on all fours to run toward the car.

Title: The Thing Invisible
Author: William Hope Hodgson
Img_description: Chalk being drawn over a wood floor next to a candle and match. Graphite Filter.
Description: Carnacki is called in on account of people being stabbed by a dagger with no wielder.
Blurb: “And I found everyone in a half belief that the queer old weapon did really strike the butler, either by the aid of some inherent force, which I found them peculiarly unable to explain, or else in the hand of some invisible thing or monster of the Outer World!”

Title: The Thing on the Doorstep
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A brass, ring, door knocker. Graphite filter.
Description: Daniel Upton’s close friend Edward Derby is intelligent, but closeted and naive. After Derby gets married to the daughter of a family rumoured to be involved in the occult, Upton witnesses strange changes in his friend.
