Blurb: At first I ignored such references, but in time I began to question him guardedly, remembering what my friend’s daughter had said about Asenath’s hypnotic influence over the other girls at school—the cases where students had thought they were in her body looking across the room at themselves.

Title: Those Names
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A mob of shearers tell yarns with some local names sprinkled in.
Blurb: You’ve heard of Mungrybambone and the Gundabluey pine - Quobbotha, Girilambone, and Terramungamine - Quambone, Eunonyhareenyha, Wee Waa, and Buntijo.

Title: A Thousand Deaths
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A scientific beaker with liquid inside. Graphite filter.
Description: A man falls into the ocean and drowns, only to wake up surrounded by machinery and a mad scientist.
Blurb: Since then my life had been one long peregrination—from the Orient to the Occident, from the Arctic to the Antarctic—to find myself at last, an able seaman at thirty, in the full vigour of my manhood, drowning in San Francisco bay—

Title: The Three Feathers
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: An elegant-looking young woman with braids. Graphite filter.
Blurb: Once upon a time there lived a girl who was wooed and married by a man she never saw; for he came a-courting her after nightfall, and when they were married he never came home till it was dark, and al...

Title: The Three Heads Of The Well
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: An elegant-looking, young woman with braids smelling a tree. Graphite filter.
Description: After the Queen dies, the King marries an evil woman with an evil daughter. The King’s daughter, meanly treated by her new stepmother, chooses to go out into the world and seek her fortune.
Blurb: So she came to the well, on the brink of which she sate down, and no sooner had she done so, than a golden head without any body came up through the water, singing as it came.

Title: The Three Little Pigs
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A howling wolf. Graphite filter.
Description: Three pigs build a house to protect them from the big bad wolf.
Blurb: “Then I’ll huff and I’ll puff and I’ll blow your house in.”

Title: Three Questions
Author: Leo Tolstoy
Img_description: An old man with a white beard and white hair. Graphite filter.
Description: A king asks all his subjects three questions: What is most important, who to listen to, and when to begin?
Blurb: All the answers being different, the King agreed with none of them, and gave the reward to none. But still wishing to find the right answers to his questions, he decided to consult a hermit, widely renowned for his wisdom.

Title: The Three Sillies
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: The full moon. Graphite filter.
Blurb: Once upon a time, when folk were not so wise as they are nowadays, there lived a farmer and his wife who had one daughter. And she, being a pretty lass, was courted by the young squire when he came ho...

Title: Three Thanksgivings
Author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
Img_description: A letter with a wax seal. Graphite filter.
Description: Her daughter Jean, her son Andrew, and the persistent owner of her mortgage and desirer of her hand Mr. Butts all pressure the middle aged Mrs. Morrison to give up living alone. But Mrs. Morrison can’t bear the idea.
Blurb: “Well, then, you might just as well marry me now, and save two years of interest. It’ll be my house, either way—but you’ll be keepin’ it just the same.”

Title: The Three Tools of Death
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: Two men peer into a room where a man woman have a fancy dinner.
Blurb: “If ever I murdered somebody,” he added quite simply, “I dare say it might be an Optimist.”

Title: Through a Window
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: An open window overlooking a misty outdoors. Graphite filter.
Description: An injured man watches river workers through his open window.
Blurb: He had thought the window cheerful to begin with, but now he thanked God for it many times a day.

Title: Thumbelina
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: A tiny girl reaches out to a butterfly about her size while standing on a lillypad.
Description: A woman who longs for a child of her own, asks a fairy to grant her wish.
Blurb: In the swampy margin of a broad stream in the garden lived the toad, with her son. He was uglier even than his mother, and when he saw the pretty little maiden in her elegant bed, he could only cry, Croak, croak, croak.

Title: To Be Read at Dusk
Author: Charles Dickens
Img_description: A moustached man. Graphite Filter.
Description: Six men sit around a campfire. Several begin arguing about whether ghosts are real.
Blurb: ‘Now, I am not in the least mad, and am not in the least disposed to invest that phantom with any external existence out of myself. I think it is a warning to me that I am ill; and I think I had better be bled.’

Title: To Build a Fire
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A large woodfire. Graphite filter.
Description: A man finds himself alone in Alaska at -70 degrees Farenheit.
Blurb: The old-timer had been very serious in laying down the law that no man must travel alone in the Klondike after fifty below. Well, here he was.

Title: To Kill a Man
Author: Jack London
Img_description: The sillhouette of a gun pointing at a raised hand. Graphite Filter.
Description: Mrs. Setliffe comes across a burglar in her house and convinces him to stay for a conversation.
Blurb: “But you’ve sure got the spunk. And you’re trustful on top of it. There ain’t many women, or men either, who’d treat a man with a gun the way you’re treating me.”

Title: To the Sun
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: The sun in space. Graphite Filter
Blurb: Thy light is an eminence unto thee - And thou art upheld by the pillars of thy strength.

Title: The Toll-House
Author: W. W. Jacobs
Img_description: A large, gothic, spired house. Graphite filter.
Description: Four friends try to survive a night in a haunted house.
Blurb: “I’m a poor man, but I wouldn't spend the night in that house for a hundred pounds.”

Title: Tom Tit Tot
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: An elegant-looking, young woman with braids smelling a tree. Graphite filter.
Description: After a misunderstanding, a king weds a poor girl thinking she can spin five skeins in a day.
Blurb:
Once upon a time there was a woman and she baked five pies. But when they came out of the oven they were over-baked, and the crust was far too hard to eat. So she said to her daughter:
“Daughter,” say...

Title: The Tomb
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A cave with a stream of sunlight falling in. Graphite filter
Description: Jervas Dudley finds a tomb near his home and becomes desperate to see what’s inside.
Blurb: I shall never forget the afternoon when first I stumbled upon the half-hidden house of death.

Title: Too Early Spring
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: Two hands holding eachother.
Description: A man reminisces on a falling in love with a girl when he was young.
Blurb: I felt as if I could run forever and not stop. It was like finding something. I hadn’t imagined anybody could ever feel the way I did about some things. And here was another person, even if it was a girl.

Title: A Tooth for Paul Revere
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: A detailed, silver box. Graphite filter
Description: Lige Butterwick has a toothache, and only wants to get it fixed. But on his journey to find someone to pull it from his mouth he keeps finding himself in the middle of the American Revolution.
Blurb:
“The liberty tree!” said the red-faced man. “And may it soon be watered in the blood of tyrants!”
“The royal oak of England!” said the sharp-faced man. “And God save King George and loyalty!”

Title: The Tower of the Elephant
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Conan holds a sword to the neck of an elephant-headed man sitting on a chair.
Description: Conan the Barbarian hears of a mysterious jewel hidden in the top of a tower. Adventure Calls!
Blurb: “There are no guards in the gardens at night for a very good reason—that is, no human guards.”

Title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A mouse poking out from behind some wood. Graphite filter.
Description: A mouse from the country is invited by another mouse into the city.
Blurb: A Town Mouse and a Country Mouse were acquaintances, and the Country Mouse one day invited his friend to come and see him at his home in the fields. The Town Mouse came, and they sat down to a dinner ...

Title: The Transferred Ghost
Author: Frank Stockton
Img_description: An earing worn by a young woman with dark hair. graphite filter.
Description: While waiting to ask a young woman for her hand, a man meets a ghost who is interested in his plans.
Blurb: “I had no right to be the ghost of a man who was not dead.”

Title: A Transgression
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A blanketed baby in a basket. Graphite filter.
Description: Miguev finds a ‘transgression’ on his doorstep one day. Ashamed to tell his wife, he searches far and wide for someone to take responsibility for the ‘transgression’ off his hands.
Blurb: “I’ll have the law of you, and I’ll tell your wife, too...”

Title: The Transition of Juan Romero
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A cave with a stream of sunlight falling in. Graphite filter
Description: After discovering an abyss sinking into the ground, two labourers are woken by a sound coming from within that draws them to venture inside.
Blurb: Perhaps it was like the pulsing of the engines far down in a great liner, as sensed from the deck, yet it was not so mechanical; not so devoid of the element of life and consciousness.

Title: The Travelling Post Office
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A young man heads North-west to join the drovers, and one could only ever send him a letter by making it out to ‘Care of Conroy’s Sheep’, as the only chance of a postman ever finding the man is by spotting the travelling flock.
Blurb:
The mailman, if he’s extra tired, would pass them in his sleep,
It’s safest to address the note to ‘Care of Conroy’s sheep’,
For five and twenty thousand head can scarcely go astray,
You write to ‘Care of Conroy’s sheep along the Castlereagh.

Title: The Treader of the Dust
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A splayed open book. Graphite filter
Description: A man runs away from his house after being disturbed by the contents of an old book. On returning, his servant is missing.
Blurb: Dust lay everywhere: a fine gray dust like a powder of dead atoms. It had covered his manuscripts with a deep film, it had settled thickly upon the chairs, the lamp-shades, the volumes; and the rich poppy-like reds and yellows of the oriental rugs were bedimmed by its accumulation.

Title: The Treasure in the Forest
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A beach shore with the sun setting. Graphite Filter.
Description: Two men canoe to a forest to find a treasure they heard of from a man named Chang-Hi, before Chang-hi himself can retrieve it.
Blurb: The paper had the appearance of a rough map. By much folding it was creased and worn to the pitch of separation, and the second man held the discoloured fragments together where they had parted. On it one could dimly make out, in almost obliterated pencil, the outline of the bay.

Title: The Treasure of Vasco Gomez
Author: Stephen Vincent Benét
Img_description: A crab by a plant on the sand. graphite filter.
Description: A mutinous pirate crew abandons their captain Vasco Gomez on an island. But unbeknownst to them, the gold-hungry Gomez is exactly where he wants to be.
Blurb: When he had wakened, he lay there a moment without moving; entirely happy. He had known many women in his life, but today was the day of his true nuptials.

Title: The Tree
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A tree with winding branches. Graphite filter
Description: Two friends, both one of the two best sculptors in the world, are tasked with creating a monument for the Tyrant of Syracuse.
Blurb: On a verdant slope of Mount Maenalus, in Arcadia, there stands an olive grove about the ruins of a villa.

Title: The Triumphs of a Taxidermist
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: Many strands of bunched straw. graphite filter
Description: A drunk taxidermists boasts of all his terrible and dishonest works.
Blurb: They can only discover the fraud with a microscope, and they will hardly care to pull a nice specimen to bits for that.

Title: The True History Of Sir Thomas Thumb
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A large hairy cow or bull. Graphite filter.
Blurb: At the court of great King Arthur, who lived, as all know, when knights were bold, and ladies were fair indeed, one of the most renowned of men was the wizard Merlin. Never before or since was there s...

Title: The Truth About Pyecraft
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A ladder resting on a tall bookcase. Graphite filter.
Description: Mr. Formalyn gives a secret recipe to a friend trying to lose weight, only for the remedy to work only a little too well.
Blurb: He took hold of a framed engraving rather carelessly as he spoke and it gave way, and he flew back to the ceiling again, while the picture smashed onto the sofa.

Title: The Two Bags
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A cloth sack. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on perspective.
Blurb: Every man carries Two Bags about with him, one in front and one behind, and both are packed full of faults. The Bag in front contains his neighbours’ faults, the one behind his own. Hence it is that m...

Title: The Two Devines
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A hand holding a pair of rusty metal sheep shears. Graphite filter.
Description: Two brothers outskill shearers here, there and everywhere.
Blurb:
But there wasn’t a man in the shearers’ lines
That could shear a sheep with the two Devines.

Title: Two Friends
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A rocky creek in a forest.
Description: Two friends venture out into uncontrolled territory during war to fish once again like old times.
Blurb: Every Sunday he met in this very spot Monsieur Sauvage, a stout, jolly, little man, a draper in the Rue Notre Dame de Lorette, and also an ardent fisherman. They often spent half the day side by side, rod in hand and feet dangling over the water, and a warm friendship had sprung up between the two.

Title: Two Gallants
Author: James Joyce
Img_description: An old man with a harp. Graphite filter.
Description: Two men discuss their pursuits of women, but one starts to doubt the point of it all.
Blurb: “You can never know women.”

Title: Two Little Soldiers
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A bucket being carried by someone in a dress. Graphite filter.
Description: Two young soldiers see a girl taking a pail to a fro past where they sit and begin to talk with her.
Blurb: Soon they would see the girl, coming through the fields, and it pleased them to watch the sparkling sunbeams reflected from her shining pail. They never spoke of her. They were just glad to see her, without understanding why.

Title: The Two Sisters
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A castle. Graphite filter.
Description: A kind and helpful girl sets off to find servant work, but finds herself working for a witch.
Blurb: But there was one thing the witch-woman said she must never do; and that was look up the chimney!

Title: The Ugly Duckling
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: Three children look at three swans on a river.
Description: A duckling is born ugly and large. It struggles to fit in with any of the animals or humans.
Blurb: At last the large egg broke, and a young one crept forth crying, “Peep, peep.” It was very large and ugly.

Title: The Uncharted Isle
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: Looking out onto a jungle island from a small rowboat. Graphite filter.
Description: After becoming the only survivor of catastrophe at sea, Irwin maroons at an island with unrecognisable flora. But the plants are soon the least distressing thing he finds.
Blurb: None of them appeared to notice me; and I went up to a group of three who were studying one of the long scrolls I have mentioned, and addressed them. For all answer, they bent closer above the scroll; and even when I plucked one of them by the sleeve, it was evident that he did not observe me.

Title: An Uncomfortable Bed
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A bed with a large, decorated, wooden backing. Graphite filter.
Description: A man arrives at a chateau, paranoid that he is the impending victim of some practical joke at the hands of his friends.
Blurb: I advanced with short steps, carefully examining the apartment. Nothing. I inspected every article, one after the other. Still nothing.

Title: Under the Knife
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A box of surgical instruments. Graphite filter.
Description: After finding out that he needs surgery done on the morrow, a man becomes certain that it will kill him.
Blurb: Then with a chilly, unemotional clearness, I perceived that I was not yet dead. I was still in my body; but all the multitudinous sensations that come sweeping from it to make up the background of consciousness had gone, leaving me free of it all.

Title: Under the Shadow of Kiley’s Hill
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A window overgrown with vines. Graphite filter.
Description: An old family home is empty, with all the children having left to find their way through the world.
Blurb: Gone is the garden they kept with care; Left to decay at its own sweet will.

Title: The Unexpected
Author: Jack London
Img_description: Drawing of four men in a canoe on the water.
Description: A woman marries out of a typical rural English life into one of hardship and adventure in the Canadian gold rush. And as her life becomes more and more unexpected she must become more and more resolute.
Blurb: But the Great Unexpected was yet to come into her life and put its test upon her.

Title: The Unfamiliar
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A quaint town on a hillside. Graphite Filter.
Description: A lost man who speaks no English is found in a small town. He is put to work on the farms but struggles to fit in with anyone due to peculiar cultural differences.
Blurb: “Perhaps the man never saw a mowing-machine before. I remember how scared I was when I saw the first automobile come roaring and snorting along the road. And so were you, Ben Crosby.”

Title: The Union Buries Its Dead
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A curved, grave headstone, graphite filter.
Description: A funeral procession pays their respects to a man of whom no one even knows the name.
Blurb: You’d have taken more notice if you’d known that he was doomed to die in the hour, and that those were the last words he would say to any man in this world.

Title: The Unnamable
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: Eyes in the darkness. Graphite filter
Description: In an effort to prove that there exists things which can only be described as ‘unnamable’, an author tells of a horror that he read off in an ancestor’s diary.
Blurb: “Common sense” in reflecting on these subjects, I assured my friend with some warmth, is merely a stupid absence of imagination and mental flexibility.

Title: The Unparalleled Adventures of One Hans Pfaal
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: The moon, zoomed in. Graphite Filter.
Description: A man hovers down at Rotterdam in an air balloon and just before leaving drops a letter in which he reveals himself as the missing Hans Pfaal who has gone on a remarkable adventure further than any before.
Blurb: “I resolved, let what would ensue, to force a passage, if I could, to the moon.”

Title: The Unparalleled Invasion
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A mist in a glass vial. Graphite Filter.
Description: As industrialisation causes the population of China to grow rapidly, the rest of the world grows wary.
Blurb: “From this airship, as it curved its flight back and forth over the city, fell missiles—strange, harmless missiles, tubes of fragile glass that shattered into thousands of fragments on the streets and house-tops.”

Title: An Unwritten Novel
Author: Virginia Woolf
Img_description: A steam train travelling across a brdige. Graphite filter.
Description: After noticing a woman with an extremely sorrow expression on her face, the protagonist imagines her story.
Blurb: “Births, deaths, marriages, Court Circular, the habits of birds, Leonardo da Vinci, the Sandhills murder, high wages and the cost of living—oh, take what you like,”

Title: The Valley of Spiders
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A white mess of spiderwebs. Graphite filter.
Description: Three men are chasing a girl through a valley for an unknown reason, when they come across different animals fleeing from something deeper within.
Blurb: They became aware of a squealing. Athwart the path a huge boar rushed, turning his head but for one instant to glance at them, and then hurling on down the valley again. And at that, all three stopped and sat in their saddles, staring into the thickening haze that was coming upon them.

Title: Vanka
Author: Anton Chekhov
Img_description: A splayed open book. Graphite filter.
Description: An orphaned boy writes to his grandfather to take him away from his abusive life as a servant.
Blurb: “Dear grandfather, Konstantin Makaritch,” he wrote, “I am writing you a letter. I wish you a happy Christmas, and all blessings from God Almighty. I have neither father nor mother, you are the only one left me.”

Title: The Veldt
Author: Ray Bradbury
Img_description: A relaxed and regal looking lion lying on the ground. Graphite Filter.
Description: The Hadleys begin to worry that their children—and themselves—have become too obsessed with the 3d film machine in the nursery.
Blurb: It won’t hurt for the children to be locked out of it a while. Too much of anything isn’t good for anyone. And it was clearly indicated that the children had been spending a little too much time on Africa.

Title: A Vendetta
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A cliffside town. Graphite Filter.
Description: An old widow’s only son is murdered, so she takes it upon herself to seek vengeance with not strength but cunning.
Blurb: He had neither brothers nor cousins. No man was there to carry on the vendetta. His mother, the old woman, alone pondered over it.

Title: The Very Old Folk
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A large, bridled horse rearing up. Graphite filter
Blurb: It was the Terrible Season of the autumn, and the wild people in the mountains were preparing for the frightful ceremonies which only rumour told of in the towns.

Title: The Veteran
Author: Stephen Crane
Img_description: A burning house. Graphite filter.
Description: After an elderly veteran admits to running away at the sight of his first battle, his grandson doesn’t know what to think of his hero.
Blurb: “I thought they were all shooting at me. Yes, sir, I thought every man in the other army was aiming at me in particular, and only me. And it seemed so darned unreasonable”

Title: A Vine on a House
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: Gnarly roots and vines. Graphite filter
Description: A vine at an abandoned house mysteriously begins to shake on its own, spooking the locals.
Blurb: Presently both men started from their seats in surprise: a long vine that covered half the front of the house and dangled its branches from the edge of the porch above them was visibly and audibly agitated, shaking violently in every stem and leaf.

Title: A Vintage from Atlantis
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A wooden, five-masted sailing ship on the sea. Graphite filter
Description: A crew of sailors find a mysterious bottle on a beach, temptingly smelling like a wine from a different era, aged to perfection.
Blurb: Truly, there should be a rare vintage within, a wine that was mellowed in the youth of the world, before the founding of Rome and Athens.

Title: The Virgin
Author: Rudyard Kipling
Img_description: A masted ship at sea. Graphite filter.
Description: A poem on a man’s first love.
Blurb: Try as he will, no man breaks wholly loose; From his first love, no matter who she be.

Title: A Vision of Judgment
Author: H. G. Wells
Img_description: A stone grave with an wreath shape embossed upon it. Graphite filter.
Description: The narrator, having died, sees humanities best and worst line up to be judged by god.
Blurb: “There’s Darwin,” he said, going off at a tangent. “He’ll catch it! And there—you see—? That tall, important-looking man trying to catch the eye of the Lord God, that’s the Duke. But there’s a lot of people one doesn’t know.”

Title: A Voice from the Town
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: An old man returns to town from the bush to realise his youth has gone away.
Blurb: I am back into civilisation - Once more in the stir and the strife - But the old joys have lost their sensation — The light has gone out of my life.

Title: Von Kempelen and His Discovery
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: A cat's eyes in the darkness. Graphite filter.
Blurb: A discovery which declares, in so many words, that beyond its intrinsic worth for manufacturing purposes (whatever that worth may be), gold now is, or at least soon will be (for it cannot be supposed that Von Kempelen can long retain his secret), of no greater value than lead, and of far inferior value to silver.

Title: A Voyage  To Sfanmoë
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: A misty planet. Graphite filter
Description: As Atlantis sinks, two scientists plan to escape the earth and find refuge on Venus.
Blurb: And though the peoples of Poseidonis continued to regard them as possible saviors, whose knowledge and resource were well-nigh superhuman, they had secretly abandoned all effort to salvage the doomed isle.

Title: Wanted by the Police
Author: Henry Lawson
Img_description: A farmstation on a hill.
Description: A family is visited by two runaway thieves needing shelter.
Blurb: So we form Prisoners’ Aid Societies, and Prisoners’ Defence Societies, and subscribe to them and praise them and love them and encourage them to protect or defend men from the very laws that we pay so dearly to maintain.

Title: Was it Heaven? Or Hell?
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: An expressionless woman clutching her face. Graphite filter.
Blurb: In it a lie had no place. In it a lie was unthinkable. In it speech was restricted to absolute truth, iron-bound truth, implacable and uncompromising truth, let the resulting consequences be what they might.

Title: The Water of Life
Author: Brothers Grimm
Img_description: A lone horserider. Graphite filter.
Description: A dying kings’ sons set out to find the water of life that may save him.
Blurb: He heard a loud laugh ringing round him, and found that the path was closed behind him, so that he was shut in all round. He next tried to get off his horse and make his way on foot, but again the laugh rang in his ears, and he found himself unable to move a step.

Title: The Wedding-Knell
Author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
Img_description: A bell hanging above a church. Graphite filter.
Description: After marrying two others first, a woman marries a man that has waited for her since their youth. But upon turning up to the church a funeral knell rings instead of a wedding peal.
Blurb: But so many weddings have been ushered in with the merriest peal of the bells, and yet turned out unhappily, that I shall hope for better fortune under such different auspices.

Title: The Wee Bannock
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A castle. Graphite filter.
Description: After an old woman cooks two oatmeal bannocks, one decides to run away.
Blurb: Now just as they were toasting away, smelling so fresh and tasty, in came the old man, and seeing them look so crisp and nice, takes up one of them and snaps a piece out of it. On this the other bannock thought it high time to be off, so up it jumps and away it trundles as fast as ever it could.

Title: The Well
Author: W. W. Jacobs
Img_description: A round, stone well, seen from inside. Graphite filter.
Description: Jem Benson’s cousin, Wilfred, alludes having some private letters between the Jem and a woman not his wife.
Blurb: “Smoke your cigar in peace,” she said quietly. “I am settled here for a quiet talk. Has anything been heard of Wilfred yet?” - “Nothing.”

Title: The Well of the World’s End
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A frog with a blank expression. Graphite filter.
Description: A young girl is asked by her step-mother to fetch water from the Well of the World’s End with a sieve.
Blurb: “Go, fill it at the Well of the World’s End and bring it home to me full, or woe betide you.”

Title: The Wendigo
Author: Algernon Blackwood
Img_description: A spruce tree in the snow. Graphite filter
Description: A party of five are hunting moose in the Canadian backwoods when they get the sense that something is out there with them.
Blurb: And it was in that moment of distress and confusion that the whip of terror laid its most nicely calculated lash about his heart.

Title: What Stumped the Bluejays
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A open mouthed bluejay on a fence. Graphite filter.
Description: A man, claiming to understand animals, tells of how a bluejay couldn’t figure out where all his acorns were going after trying to hide them in a hole in a house’s roof.
Blurb: You think a cat can swear. Well, a cat can; but you give a bluejay a subject that calls for his reserve powers, and where is your cat!

Title: What the Moon Brings
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A full moon at night. Graphite filter
Description: A man walks through a dream-like garden and discovers horrors within.
Blurb:
I hate the moon—I am afraid of it—for when it shines on certain scenes familiar and loved it sometimes makes them unfamiliar and hideous.
It was in the spectral summer when the moon shone down...

Title: When the World Was Young
Author: Jack London
Img_description: A man in a forest shines a light on a large, naked, bearded man. Black and white drawing.
Description: While sneaking through the forest estate of a rich lawyer, a burglar comes across something scarier than any wild animal.
Blurb: Looking about him, he noticed that the coyote had ceased its noise and was running away along the crest of the hill, and behind it, in full pursuit, no longer chanting, ran the naked creature he had encountered in the garden.

Title: Where Is The Tropic Of Capricorn??
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A 20th century city street. Graphite Filter.
Description: Peter Mullaney, falls short of his dream of becoming a cop by being one eighth of an inch under regulation height, but is determined as ever to prove himself and get in.
Blurb: “Pether,” said Officer Gaffney, dubiously, scratching his head with the tip of his night-stick, “I disrimimber but I think—I think, mind ye, it’s in the Bronx.”

Title: The Whirligig of Life
Author: O. Henry
Img_description: A gold ring. Graphite filter.
Description: In the mountains, a man and a woman come to their local Justice-of-the-Peace to petition for divorce.
Blurb: “We-all can’t git along together nohow. It’s lonesome enough fur to live in the mount’ins when a man and a woman keers fur one another”

Title: The Whistling Room
Author: William Hope Hodgson
Img_description: Drawing of a slightly distressed woman in a light gown.
Description: Carnacki is called to help at a house with a mysterious whistling sound with no apparent source.
Blurb: “Then I heard it, an extraordinary hooning whistle, monstrous and inhuman, coming from far away through corridors to my right.”

Title: The White People
Author: Arthur Machen
Img_description: A splayed open book. Graphite filter.
Description: Two men are debating what real evil is, when one brings up a mysterious diary in which a young girl wrote an unsettling but intriguing stream of dreams and fairytales.
Blurb: “And let me tell you this: our higher senses are so blunted, we are so drenched with materialism, that we should probably fail to recognize real wickedness if we encountered it.”

Title: The White Ship
Author: H. P. Lovecraft
Img_description: A lighthouse on a rocky shore. Graphite filter
Description: Basil Elton, keeper of a lighthouse, answers the call from a mysterious white ship and joins it’s captain on a journey to the South.
Blurb: Out of the South it would glide very smoothly and silently over the sea. And whether the sea was rough or calm, and whether the wind was friendly or adverse, it would always glide smoothly and silently, its sails distant and its long strange tiers of oars moving rhythmically.

Title: The Wicked Prince
Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Img_description: A drawing of a prince dressed in a lavish red uniform
Description: An arrogant and warmongering prince vows to defeat God Himself.
Blurb: “Prince, you are mighty indeed, but God’s power is much greater than yours; we dare not obey your orders.”

Title: The Widower Turmore
Author: Ambrose Bierce
Img_description: A brick wall. Graphite filter.
Description: Joram Turmore is proud member of the Turmore family, who have never earnt an honest dollar since the seventeenth century. Worried that poverty may force him into labour, Joram finds a rich bachelorette to save him.
Blurb: Laborare est errare.

Title: The Widow’s Might
Author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
Img_description: A letter with a wax seal. Graphite filter.
Description: Mrs. McPherson tells her children that they won’t be getting any inheritance today.
Blurb: “What are we going to do with Mother?”

Title: William Wilson
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
Img_description: Little fragments of shattered glass. Graphite filter.
Description: William Wilson tells of his childhood, in which he met another boy of the same name. And as he soon discovers, the same clothes. And then the similarities only reveal themselves worse and worse.
Blurb: Not thus he appeared—assuredly not thus—in the vivacity of his waking hours. The same name! the same contour of person! the same day of arrival at the academy! And then his dogged and meaningless imitation of my gait, my voice, my habits, and my manner!

Title: The Wind’s Message
Author: Banjo Paterson
Img_description: A kangaroo on a plains. Graphite filter.
Description: A whisper reaches the city folk from the outback, tempting them to set out into the bush.
Blurb: A sound of voices silent now and songs of long ago.

Title: Wings in the Night
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Drawing of a man with short hair wrestling a winged demon in the clouds.
Description: Solomon Kane comes across a desecrated village that seems to have been attacked from above.
Blurb: “The wings! the wings! They come again! Ahhh, mercy, the wings!”

Title: Wireless Confusion
Author: Algernon Blackwood
Img_description: A blue-bottle fly on wood, graphite filter.
Description: A man spontaneously begins to see the things in front of him grow and shrink to absurd proportions.
Blurb: The fly grew abruptly into gigantic proportions, became blurred and indistinct as it did so, covered the entire pane with its furry, dark, ugly mass, and frightened him so that he stepped back with a cry and nearly lost his balance altogether.

Title: The Wise Men Of Gotham
Author: Flora Annie Steel
Img_description: A worried looking, white rabbit. Graphite filter.
Description: Six stories of the wise men of Gotham, who are perhaps not so wise.
Blurb: And every man did count eleven, and the twelfth man did never count himself.

Title: Wit Inspirations of the “Two-Year-Olds”
Author: Mark Twain
Img_description: A smug baby being held by its mother. Graphite filter.
Description: A man wonders what would have happened to him if he had spoken as “smartly” as the new generation when he himself was two years old.
Blurb: “Father, I have an invincible antipathy to that name.”

Title: A Witch Shall Be Born
Author: Robert E. Howard
Img_description: Drawing of arrows flying at a monstrous fish in front of a sworded-wielding man and unconscious, naked woman.
Description: Queen Taramis is imprisoned by her twin sister, who steals her place as Queen. But Conan, who is acting as captain of the Queen’s guard, sees through the ruse.
Blurb: ‘Every century a witch shall be born.’

Title: The Wolf in Sheep’s Clothing
Author: Aesop
Img_description: A howling wolf. Graphite filter.
Description: A small fable on karma.
Blurb: A Wolf resolved to disguise himself in order that he might prey upon a flock of sheep without fear of detection. So he clothed himself in a sheepskin, and slipped among the sheep when they were out at...

Title: Work, Death and Sickness
Author: Leo Tolstoy
Img_description: The sun rising over the horizon. Graphite filter.
Description: God introduces struggle to mankind in an attempt to force them to live in peace.
Blurb: ‘Knowing that each of them may die at any moment,’ thought God, ‘they will not, by grasping at gains that may last so short a time, spoil the hours of life allotted to them.’

Title: The Wreck
Author: Guy de Maupassant
Img_description: A masted ship. Graphite filter.
Description: A man tells of how he found himself trapped on a shipwreck with an English family.
Blurb: We were on deck in an instant. It was too late. The water circled us about and was running toward the coast at tremendous speed. No, it did not run, it glided, crept, spread like an immense, limitless blot. The water was barely a few centimeters deep, but the rising flood had gone so far that we no longer saw the vanishing line of the imperceptible tide.

Title: The Wrong Shape
Author: G. K. Chesterton
Img_description: A moustached man looks at tan older man holding up and staring at a piece of paper.
Blurb: The modern mind always mixes up two different ideas: mystery in the sense of what is marvellous, and mystery in the sense of what is complicated.

Title: The Wrongdoing of Edwin Dell
Author: Richard Connell
Img_description: A 20th century city with horse-drawn carriages. Graphite filter.
Description: Edwin Dell, a sheltered boy is finally heading off to the big city of New York. Despite his mother’s warnings to avoid girls, he finds himself at the centre of attention of a particularly forthcoming woman.
Blurb: He had been aware that there were many girls in New York, but he had ignored them. This girl was hard to ignore.

Title: Xeethra
Author: Clark Ashton Smith
Img_description: Drawing of a young boy in front of a strange tree thick with leaves. Nearby are strange looking beings.
Description: A young goat shepherd discovers a mysterious cave which leads to a strange land he doesn’t recognise. But after eating a dark-red fruit from one of the local trees, he has visions of a different life as a king of some mystical, far-away land.
Blurb: “These things were illusions, designed to lead you astray; and the cave, I wot, was no honest cave but an entrance into hell.”

Title: The Yellow Face
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Img_description: A man in a bowler hat and a popped collar. Graphite filter
Description: Grand Munro comes to Holmes, suspicious of his wife’s fidelity after she asked for one hundred pounds and refused to explain why.
Blurb: “One does not like to speak of one’s domestic affairs to strangers. It seems dreadful to discuss the conduct of one’s wife with two men whom I have never seen before. It’s horrible to have to do it. But I’ve got to the end of my tether, and I must have advice.”

Title: The Yellow Wallpaper
Author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
Img_description: Drawing of a woman in a 19th century dress writing on a wooden rocking chair by a window.
Description: A woman, restrained to her house by her husband and sister-in-law, begins obsessing over wallpaper she finds disturbing.
Blurb: At first he meant to repaper the room, but afterwards he said that I was letting it get the better of me, and that nothing was worse for a nervous patient than to give way to such fancies.

Title: Young Goodman Brown
Author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
Img_description: A large twisting tree in a forest. Graphite filter.. Graphite filter.
Description: A man leaves his wife to head off into the forest, where he meets with a mysterious character and his serpentine staff.
Blurb: But the only thing about him that could be fixed upon as remarkable was his staff, which bore the likeness of a great black snake, so curiously wrought that it might almost be seen to twist and wriggle itself like a living serpent.

Title: Youth
Author: Isaac Asimov
Img_description: Drawing of a large boy pushing a small mammal into a cloth bag.
Description: Young Red and Slim find two small animals and keep them in a cage, but the animals look at them with a hint of intelligence in their eyes.
Blurb: They were small, and sort of disgusting-looking. The animals moved quickly as the canvas lifted and were on the side toward the youngsters.
